This bill was a stunt when it was first debated, and it is still a stunt. The genesis of this bill is a classic example of how this government operates and how quickly it can act when it spots a political opportunity, as compared to a substantive public policy challenge. The bill, when it was first introduced to the House last year, sought to overcome the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission’s decision to reject an application by the Catholic Education Office in Sydney for an exemption under the Sex Discrimination Act to allow it to offer 12 male-only scholarships to students undertaking primary teaching. The government wasted no time drafting and introducing this bill, which deflects attention away from the government’s neglect of these issues by attacking the anti-discrimination system in this country. The education minister was even quicker to get out there and make as much noise as possible in the hope that a few headlines relating to 12 teaching scholarships would be sufficient for the government to look as though it was doing something about boys’ education and attracting men into a career in teaching. Maybe it would relieve the minister of responsibility for developing solutions to the real barriers to getting more men into teaching that have been talked about for years and that were explored in some detail in the Boys: Getting it right report.

The speed with which the minister and the government jumped onto this issue makes you wonder what they have been doing while other crucial parts of our education and training system have been falling apart. If only the minister for education had been half as quick to identify the skills shortage as a problem and actually do something about it. Or maybe he could get started on issues like the 40 per cent of trainees and apprentices who do not complete their qualifications and the fall for the first time in the number of applicants to universities.

To understand why the ALP is so sceptical of the merits of this bill you just have to look at where it came from and the timing of the bill. As I said, it was introduced to parliament early last year at around the same time that the Catholic Education Office in Sydney was advised by the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission that its application for an exemption under the Sex Discrimination Act had been refused. Interestingly, it was also around the same time that the then Leader of the Opposition, Mark Latham, took the opportunity in a speech at the National Press Club to highlight the problems facing boys and young men in our society and particularly in our schools. All of a sudden, the government found itself being called to account for its inaction in an area it liked to claim as its own. But, instead of engaging with the opposition in a meaningful and constructive debate about the reasons for boys’ comparative underperformance in education and what can be done to better meet their needs, the government immediately grabbed the HREOC decision and with this bill tried to turn the debate into one about the Sex Discrimination Act rather than the government’s failure to address the real issues.

That is the background to this bill, and that is why we are so sceptical about its merits and the government’s motivations. As speaker after speaker has said in this debate, the Labor Party quite rightly regards this bill as a political stunt. For the purposes of this debate, let us give the government some credit and pretend that there are no politics behind this bill. Let us have an objective analysis of the bill. What does it seek to do? Will it achieve that purpose? What are the implications of the bill?

First of all, the bill seeks to amend the Sex Discrimination Act to provide a permanent exemption for the provision of gender-specific scholarships that can be offered to students in a teaching course. These scholarships must be designed to address gender imbalance in teaching, in particular the shortage of males in preschool and primary teaching, to improve educational outcomes for boys and to provide both girls and boys with suitable male role models.

As with any bill, it is fair to ask whether the initiative proposed will achieve what it sets out to do. Will providing male-only scholarships lead to significant numbers of additional male teachers in our classrooms? Of course, the answer to that question is no. That was the message that came out loud and clear in the evidence put to HREOC in the Sydney CEO case and in submissions to the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee’s inquiry into this bill and to the House of Representatives inquiry into boys’ education.

Whether you read the HREOC decision, the Senate report or Boys: Getting it right, it is clear that men are choosing not to enter the teaching profession for a number of reasons, none of which have anything to do with any real or perceived discrimination within the profession and none of which call for the provision of male-only scholarships as a solution. Time and time again submissions to HREOC and the parliamentary inquiries made the point that men have other choices open to them and turn away from teaching for a number of reasons including the status of teachers in the community, child protection issues and the pay and conditions of teachers relative to other careers.

Nowhere in the speeches I have heard from the minister or other speakers in this debate has it been explained just how the male-only scholarships and the undermining of the Sex Discrimination Act address any of those factors that deter men from a career in teaching. Where scholarships have been offered they have clearly not been enough on their own to overcome those other factors. Again, I point to the article in the Australian on 15 March showing that the 12 scholarships offered by the Catholic Education Office did not attract sufficient applicants to fill even those scholarships.

On the bill’s stated aim to increase the number of male teachers: there is no evidence that amending the SDA to allow for male-only scholarships will lead to more male teachers. Of course, the whole point of this exercise is supposed to be about the educational outcomes for students, particularly for boys, and the explanatory memorandum to the bill presumes that more male teachers equals better educational outcomes for boys. Let us see whether this bill is going to achieve those better educational outcomes. Again, this is not supported in the evidence presented to the various inquiries into this matter. The overwhelming response from participants in those inquiries was that it is the quality of the teacher that counts rather than the gender of the teacher. The submission to the Senate inquiry from the Australian Council for Educational Research stated:

quote.para: ... the quality of teaching and learning provision are by far the most salient influences on students’ cognitive, affective and behavioural outcomes of schooling—not teacher gender.

speech.para: Dr Ken Rowe from ACER backed that up in his evidence before the inquiry when he said:

quote.para: ... it does not matter a hoot whether or not the teacher is male or female; it depends on the quality of the teaching and learning provision in the classroom. ... providing teacher training scholarships for persons of one gender is missing the whole point. We want high-quality people regardless of their gender.

speech.para: That was the approach adopted by the House of Representatives committee when it recommended in Boys: Getting it right that the Commonwealth government provide a substantial number of HECS-free merit based scholarships for equal numbers of males and females to undertake teacher training. In its response to the inquiry’s report the government rejected that recommendation on the basis that it did not believe that a scholarship mechanism would be likely to make an impact on the gender imbalance in schools.

The Catholic Education Office, on the other hand, have picked up that idea and were granted an exemption by HREOC to offer a total of 24 scholarships, 12 male and 12 female, to students taking up a teaching course in 2005. The CEO are to be congratulated for their approach to this matter, because it is obvious that for them it is all about attracting quality teachers. Sure they want more male teachers, but they have acknowledged that it is quality not simple gender balance that counts. Unable to fill the 12 scholarships available to male teaching students this year, the CEO were adamant that there was no question of lowering standards just to fill the quota of places.

So the measures in the bill will not increase the number of male teachers, and there is no evidence that the ratio of male teachers in our schools is a factor affecting the educational outcomes of male students. This is sounding very much like the reasons that HREOC gave for rejecting the application from the Catholic Education Office in the first place—they could not demonstrate that the scholarships were necessary or that they would be effective. In seeking to override the commission’s decision through this legislation the government has offered no new or compelling evidence to convince us on any of those points. This is all about political posturing.

I said that an objective analysis of the bill would also consider the implications of allowing it to pass. We on the Labor side believe that it would have the effect of weakening the Sex Discrimination Act by allowing for discrimination on the basis of gender in circumstances which are not acceptable under the existing permanent exemptions for special measures in the act. The bill allows for positive discrimination in favour of men in circumstances where there is no evidence of entrenched discrimination against men in the teaching profession. This was also a major factor in the commission’s decision in the Sydney CEO case. HREOC were not prepared to waive the provisions of the SDA when it is clear that men are not deterred from teaching as a career because of any discrimination against them, either in entering teaching courses or in obtaining teaching positions or promotions.

In fact, the experience of men in the teaching profession is just the opposite. Although there are fewer male teachers than female teachers across the profession, there are many more men occupying senior leadership positions in schools and education departments. The lack of men in teaching is not the result of discrimination but a choice men make because they do not see it as an attractive career option, for the reasons I have outlined. Amending the Sex Discrimination Act to allow for discrimination in favour of men does nothing to address those issues and undermines the whole purpose of the act, which is to protect against real and entrenched discrimination. For these reasons, the bill does not deserve our support and will not receive our support. The bill is unnecessary and will not achieve the objective of getting more men into teaching.

The government is always pointing the finger at the ALP and saying, ‘You vote against these things, but what would you do?’ In the lead-up to last year’s election we made it very clear what we would do. In contrast to the government, whose response to this serious issue of the lack of male teachers and role models in our schools is to pull this stunt amending the Sex Discrimination Act, Labor developed a five-point plan for getting more male teachers into the profession. It is a plan that is based on the issues raised in the House of Representatives and Senate inquiries into this bill. It is a real and comprehensive policy aimed at addressing those issues.

We would start with a national campaign aimed at attracting quality entrants to teaching, targeting men with relevant skills and backgrounds. We would encourage more male mentors to work with schools and parents, including involving fathers in reading to students, using technology, vocational education, music, drama and sporting activities. We would provide incentives for quality teaching, including for teachers who have the skills needed to improve the learning outcomes of boys. We would target improvements in teaching skills for males through the Commonwealth professional development program and in the development of national teaching standards. We would also develop student discipline and welfare programs, many of which would be targeted at boys. Very importantly, we would give schools the resources that they need to provide quality education for all their students—boys and girls.

I think our whole approach to this has demonstrated that the Labor Party are much more serious about this issue than the government. As I said at the outset, I am bemused that the government is persisting with this bill when it has been so clearly demonstrated that it will achieve nothing effective in increasing the number of male teachers and does nothing more than posture on the Sex Discrimination Act, undermining the very important anti-discrimination legislation in this country. For all those reasons, Labor will be opposing this bill and we call on the government to get serious about this issue rather than just play politics.

talk.start.para: —in reply—I thank the members for Jagajaga, Denison, Brisbane, Cunningham, Lingiari, Gorton, Isaacs, Capricornia, Fisher, Bowman, Macquarie and Bass for their contributions to this debate. The government has obviously committed to providing high-quality education for children throughout Australia. We believe that both male and female teachers play an important role in providing high-quality education to boys and girls.

speech.para: The Sex Discrimination Amendment (Teaching Profession) Bill 2004 is a sensible strategy to assist in addressing the imbalance in the number of men and women in the profession, in the interests of providing children with both male and female role models in schools. The bill facilitates that by permitting scholarships for that purpose for persons of a particular gender in respect of participation in a teaching course. If the parliament passes the bill, the government will be leading by example and will commit $1 million in providing teacher scholarships for male students in first-year primary teacher education. The bill is just one of a number of government strategies to either support male teachers or address particular educational needs of boys in schools. It is not a measure that should be seen in isolation.

Having heard the debate, I would have to say that the hypocrisy of my colleagues opposite is quite breathtaking. Here is a party whose most recent former leader claimed to be a champion of the cause of providing more male role models to young boys, yet, when it comes to supporting a practical amendment to achieve that, the Labor Party is opposed to it. Here is a party that thinks it is a good idea to put a quota on the number of women who might enter the parliament, yet, when it comes to putting more male teachers into primary school classrooms, it is somehow affronted by that.

The picture becomes even murkier when we consider the number of other exemptions that have been granted without so much as a whimper by the opposition. An exemption was allowed, for instance, for the Tasmanian Metro bus service to advertise for female-only bus drivers. Several universities have sought to offer women-only courses and academic positions, and the South Australian Trades and Labour Council has offered women-only work experience programs. Given the opposition that we are hearing on the grounds of discrimination, you would think we would have heard protest on those matters, but the silence is clearly deafening in relation to such issues when they are raised.

The hypocrisy of this position is even more stark when we consider the actions of the Labor government in Western Australia. In Western Australia, a range of teaching scholarships have been offered to people completing the final year of their degree at a Western Australian university. Male teachers were identified as one of six areas of need for the 2004 year in Western Australia. Accordingly, 37 scholarships were offered specifically to males who agreed to go into primary school teaching, despite the Western Australian government having no exemption for scholarships, I might say, from the Sex Discrimination Act. It is unclear whether an exemption from their own Equal Opportunity Act was ultimately sought, but the Western Australian scholarship information guide specifically sought applications from people who would qualify as, among other things, mathematics teachers, physical education teaches, science teachers and male primary teachers. I understand the scholarships have since been withdrawn. They would not want comparisons to be made when opposition was being mounted here.

I think you can see that Labor, at both federal and state levels, has lost sight of the importance of this issue for children. When you see the response to this matter, any suggestion that politics is being played on this side of the House speaks for itself. A number of members asked for evidence that the bill would work—the members for Denison, Jagajaga, Cunningham and Capricornia made this request.

A number of educational authorities are pursuing strategies for encouraging men into teaching and consider offering scholarships an important category. The New South Wales Catholic Education Office clearly thought that offering scholarships to males was a useful and relevant strategy, which is why it initially went to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission to seek an exemption. Similarly, in its submission to the Senate committee inquiry on this bill, the Association of Independent Schools in Victoria indicated that a number of its schools thought offering scholarships was a useful option to get more men into teaching.

The Association of Independent Schools of South Australia also indicated that an amendment could assist in increasing the number of male teachers. The Western Australian government, as I have said, has already made such offers, although belatedly withdrawing them when under political pressure. So these are the very educational authorities grappling with this issue every day, who believe that this would be a practical measure. The government wants to give them that option.

It has been argued by some that this measure would not be useful. I think that came from the members for Cunningham, Lingiari and Capricornia. The fact is that this bill will not alone solve the shortfall. We have not asserted that. Of course it is correct, but that is no reason to stand against this useful and sensible measure to address the problem. The Sex Discrimination Act 1984 is within our jurisdiction, and it has been shown to be a barrier to male scholarships. It is an area in which the parliament can now act. The bill and the government’s commitment of $1 million for scholarships to encourage men into teaching complement the other major strategies for addressing the particular challenge of increasing educational outcomes for boys. Boys education is a priority area for the $159.2 million Australian Government Quality Teacher Program. It includes the provision of $27 million over six years to the year 2008 for boys education.

It has been argued that there was no discrimination against men entering the teaching profession and therefore amending the act to address the issue was not appropriate. This view was put by the members for Jagajaga, Gorton, Isaacs and Capricornia. The government do not contend that there is discrimination against men seeking to enter the teaching profession. Our position is simply that there is a serious shortage of males in teaching, especially primary teaching, and that offering scholarships to males is a relevant and sensible policy response among other measures. We need to put the needs of Australia’s children first and to encourage a better balance of males and females in the teaching profession to get more males into schools.

I note that people have been commenting on these issues. I went recently to a very small school at Brooklyn in my electorate. It is an exceptional school, because it has a number of male teachers. The importance of male role models was acknowledged by the principal and the parent groups that I met with. Obviously, in a school which has a very large proportion of boys amongst its number, boys were benefiting substantially from the wider representation.

The member for Brisbane claimed that the measure puts gender ahead of merit. This measure is all about achieving the best quality educational outcomes for male and female school students by bringing the best quality male teachers into the profession, which is not attracting sufficient quality male applicants at this time. The measure is about encouraging the best quality male applicants side by side with the best female quality applicants. By emphasising the importance of the teaching profession, I think the government will help to attract better candidates overall.

There were issues raised about this bill not addressing the real reason men are not entering the teaching profession—namely, the status of the profession. The same members, I think with the addition of the member for Brisbane, were raising that issue. This bill underlines the government’s esteem for the teaching profession and, with other measures, its commitment to encouraging more men into teaching. The government has never suggested the bill is a complete solution but it is an important part of the solution. It complements other measures such as the Boys Education Lighthouse Schools initiative and the Success for Boys initiative.

Other issues were raised in relation to salaries by the members for Lingiari and Gorton. The government does not employ teachers. It does not determine their remuneration, but it is important that teachers are appropriately rewarded for quality teaching. The Minister for Education, Science and Training was asked about teacher remuneration on 11 March. He said:

quote.para: ... the most important thing that our society needs to do is raise the respect that we have for teaching as a profession and to support that with serious resources for their ongoing training and professional development.

speech.para: He added:

quote.para: I think by any standard most Australians would certainly agree that teachers deserve more pay, a higher level of pay, but I think equally they would expect that professionalism and quality is rewarded.

speech.para: The Prime Minister said that he completely agreed the teaching profession should be a more respected and more rewarded profession. This bill is an important step, as I say, amongst another initiatives to help underline the importance of the teaching profession.

It has been suggested that this is an attack on the Sex Discrimination Act. I would like to say that legislative exemptions are not made lightly. In fact, since 1996 the government has added no new exemptions to the Sex Discrimination Act. This is a specific and targeted exemption in gender-neutral terms. It is based on commonsense to address an identified problem. For the member for Brisbane, I will comment on the exemption mechanism. He suggested that the exemption mechanism is available where scholarships for males are proposed. The Catholic Education Office case, including the ultimate resolution of the case, showed that the exemption mechanism of section 44 of the act is not a viable alternative if we want to give educational authorities the flexibility they need to address this particular question. It took the Catholic Education Office 18 months to obtain an exemption, which in the end was not the exemption that it had first sought.

The Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission administers the exemption mechanism and has indicated its opposition to male-only scholarships, unless framed in accordance with its preferred approach—that is, that it is coupled with the scholarships for females. The government want flexibility in this area and, in our view, it is ridiculous if every single authority that wants to offer male scholarships has to go through the lengthy process with HREOC that we saw in the case that brought this matter to light. Educational authorities need an option which, in our view, enables them to act now.

It has been suggested by the members for Denison, Brisbane, Cunningham, Lingiari, Gorton, Isaacs and Capricornia that the bill is no longer necessary. They must have all been reading from the same script. I would like to address this argument by simply acknowledging that the exemption from the Sex Discrimination Act granted to the Catholic Education Office in no way renders this bill redundant. The bill is not directed to the specific case involving the Catholic Education Office but is framed generally to facilitate measures to address the shortage of male teachers Australia-wide. We want educational authorities to be able to act as they see appropriate, and we think this amendment will give them that capacity.

The members for Capricornia, Cunningham, Lingiari, Gorton and Isaacs argued that the lower than expected take-up rate of scholarships offered by the Sydney Catholic Education Office demonstrates that the government’s proposed measure will not work. The lower than expected take-up of scholarships underlines the challenge of attracting more men into primary teaching. It is not evidence that scholarships cannot play an important part in encouraging interest in teaching. The Department of Education, Science and Training is developing advice for the minister on possible complementary measures such as mentoring and awareness-raising activities that might further encourage young men interested in undertaking primary teaching and enhance the impact of the scholarships on those taking them up.

The member for Brisbane argues that the better course of action would have been to offer HECS-free scholarships for teaching. The government has rejected the proposed HECS-free scholarship mechanism because evidence suggests that HECS is not a major determinant in student choices. However, the government is sympathetic to the reasoning that more male teachers are needed because of the importance of providing good role models, and this bill is an important part of that strategy.
In conclusion, the shortage of male teachers in schools is a problem that all sides of the parliament recognise. As my colleague the Minister for Education, Science and Training has pointed out:

quote.para: It will do this country no good if we spend the next decade hand-wringing and clinging to misplaced but well-intentioned ideological purity if we produce a generation of young men who are disengaged, who are disillusioned and who feel ill-prepared for the future.

speech.para: The proportion of primary teachers who are male has fallen to 20.9 per cent and only 18.8 per cent of students training to become primary teachers are men. The government are not content to ignore the problem. We think the education of our children is far too important to be put on the backburner. This bill is just one of a number of strategies that the government are pursuing to address that very problem. It is a very important part of the solution, and for that reason I commend the bill to the House.
Question put:

motion.para: That the bill be now read a second time.
That the bill be now read a third time.

debateinfo.title: HIGHER EDUCATION SUPPORT AMENDMENT (ABOLITION OF COMPULSORY UP-FRONT STUDENT UNION FEES) BILL 2005

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 16 March, on motion by Dr Nelson:

motion.para: That the bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —Labor will oppose the Higher Education Support Amendment (Abolition of Compulsory Up-front Student Union Fees) Bill 2005 and defend the ability of students to protect their own interests. This bill will have two significant impacts. From 1 January next year, any higher education provider—primarily universities—who is receiving Commonwealth support under the Higher Education Support Act will be prevented from making membership of student organisations a condition of enrolment. Frankly, this is basically redundant. Students already have the option of opting out of membership of student organisations, and the fact that virtually none of them avail themselves of this option shows the complete lack of a groundswell among students for this bill.

speech.para: Secondly, the bill prevents higher education providers from making a condition of enrolment payment of any fee ‘for the provision to students of an amenity, facility or service that is not of an academic nature’. So providers cannot make payment of fees for those purposes a condition of enrolment. Enforcement of these policies would become a condition of receiving a grant, with two tiers of penalty available to the Commonwealth. The bill inserts a provision which allows the minister to reduce Commonwealth funding for higher education institutions by $100 per federally funded student place if the above conditions are breached. As the conditions above are to be inserted in subdivision 19D, the fairness requirements, failure to comply could invoke section 19-65 jeopardising a provider’s status under the act. If the minister chose to invoke section 19-65, over $5 billion in Commonwealth funding to universities could be lost if they were to ignore these conditions and continue with their current arrangements requiring students to pay a fee to student organisations. Talk about heavy-handed! A very heavy handed method is being imposed on universities by this government.

The government is not about to increase universities’ funding commensurate to the loss of revenue that universities and student organisations will face if this bill goes through. It is typical of this government’s track record: micromanaging, intervening in universities’ daily affairs and placing more conditions on declining government support. This is funding extortion on a massive scale. At present every university in the country is free to independently determine whether or not students are to become members of their student organisation as part of the enrolment process and what contribution they will make to these organisations.

It is no coincidence that each and every university recognises the benefits of the current arrangements. The current policy on membership of student organisations is good, sensible, practical policy, which is why every university in the country has implemented it. Of course, some students will object to various positions being taken on various issues by their student organisations. Even the Liberal Party would have to agree that unanimity in any democratic organisation is hard to come by. Witness the leadership debate going on in the Liberal party at the moment. However, opposition by a minority over a particular issue is not an argument in favour of this bill.

First and foremost, the bill before us will destroy vital campus services that support university students. Health services, child care, sport and legal support services are all hanging in the balance. I just want to talk briefly about the child-care centre at my local university, La Trobe University. It delivers an outstanding service to students who are parents. The La Trobe Students Representative Council has organised a subsidy for students whose children are at this child-care centre. If you are in that increasing band of people who go back to university to reskill and better themselves through education, then my local student organisation will help you do that. They will make sure that you can afford the child care that you need. This child-care centre provides not only subsidised child-care places but also many very flexible arrangements that parents would be very hard-pressed to find at other child-care centres in the area. Without this valuable service—and it will go if this legislation gets through the parliament—many parents who are students simply will not be able to afford child care and will not be able to afford to stay at university. Around 250 families use this particular child-care centre. So those families will either have to pay through the nose for child care or no longer continue their university studies.

There is no doubt that student organisations help keep students at university by offering the necessary subsidies and services that cash-strapped universities just cannot offer. Single parents may suffer the most from the bill before us. They absolutely rely on campus child care to allow them to improve their skills and they would not be able to study without their subsidised support. It certainly makes the justification of the Minister for Education, Science and Training for this bill absurd. He said in parliament on 16 March:

quote.para: ... why is a single mother who is training to be a nurse paying for the canoeing club or the mountaineers?

speech.para: Minister, the single mother is probably only able to complete her training as a nurse thanks to her student organisation’s child-care subsidy of 41 per cent. That is the level of the subsidy that is being provided for child care at this university. In fact, her biggest barriers at the moment are not child care; they are much more likely to be the massive HECS debt that she will be hit with when she graduates or the FEE-HELP loan that she will be paying off into her old age because of this government’s lack of funding of affordable HECS places. That is certainly leaving students with massive levels of debt.

Unfortunately, we have an education minister who just wants to trivialise this issue. He went on the warpath when he introduced this legislation in the parliament to destroy student organisations because—and I am sure all the students around the country have heard him say this—their sausage rolls are too expensive and the catering staff did not smile at the minister who was threatening their livelihoods. This minister loves to trivialise critical issues like investment in Australia’s education and training by resorting to these hokey anecdotes that sometimes really stretch the truth.

At least one vice-chancellor, though—and I suspect he is joined by many others—has seen through the minister’s efforts to take attention away from the real obstinacy at the core of this bill. Professor Gavin Brown wrote about Brendan Nelson in ‘Orbiter Dicta’, his column in Sydney University’s ‘Uninews’, on 24 March this year, and he said:

quote.para: He alleges that one can achieve a 30 cent discount and a free bonus smile by shopping around. Perhaps one of the campus food outlets had a bad hair day when his government inspectors visited—or perhaps he made the story up.

speech.para: This was from a vice-chancellor who has probably seen his fair share of student protest against his actions. But this government chooses to ignore the valuable contribution that student organisations make in so many ways. One of those very important ways is the sporting organisations, making vibrant campus life, creating the opportunities for the promotion of health and fitness in the general community, not just for university students, and training generations of Olympians and elite sportspeople.

Many prominent Australians were so alarmed at the introduction of this bill that they took out an advertisement in major papers around the country condemning the government’s move to destroy university sport. It is this group that has warned the Howard government that attacks on student organisations will be catastrophic for university sport, as well as for the academic and social life on our university campuses. The government thinks it knows better than people like Shane Gould, John Coates, Kevin Gosper, Stuart MacGill, Geoff Lawson, Phil Kearns, Liz Ellis, Phil Waugh and Ric Charlesworth. All of these great Australian sportspeople know what will happen on our university campuses, and they are the ones who are speaking out against this government’s legislation because they want to protect the great contribution that sporting organisations, subsidised by student fees, provide on our university campuses. We know that we will lose not only valuable participation in sport and fitness activities that student organisations promote but also the sporting figures that do all Australians proud when they represent Australia around the world.

But it is not only sport and it is not only child care; there are so many other services provided by student organisations. Another one is the advocacy services. The government completely ignores the help that individual students get from their student organisations. Students at a particular university were recently examined on material that had not been taught in their course. Individual students had not had any luck getting their marks changed, so they went to the student organisation for help. The student association advocated on their behalf, and the university, after six months of discussion, eventually recognised that mistakes had been made in this particular course and changed the arrangements.

This kind of persistent work, practical advocacy by student organisations for individual students and groups of students, happens every day in our universities. The organisations of students go in to bat for these students because the student fees allow it and pay them to do so. That is one of the critical advocacy roles that will go if this bill becomes law, because it will not be a profit for anybody else to do it. It is a service that automatic membership ensures at the moment. Unfortunately, it is under dire threat. What is more, if the student organisation does not provide that service, the only other avenue left to students would be to resort to expensive legal representation, which of course the vast majority of students just could not afford.
Another example of the willingness of the Minister for Education, Science and Training to say and do anything to get publicity on this issue was when he glibly told Kerry O’Brien on the 7.30 Report:

quote.para: Well, the experience in Western Australia, where voluntary student unionism like this was introduced in 1994, was that these services not only survived, in many cases they actually flourished.

speech.para: What an extraordinary statement! The Western Australian experience shows that the minister is certainly not averse to using what can only be described as Orwellian language, which we have come to expect especially from him. Student representation and services were decimated under this type of legislation in Western Australia, and student services were lost. Let us look at the facts. The legislation damaged services at all Western Australian universities. Edith Cowan University Guild went into liquidation and closed all of its services. Murdoch University Guild was in such a bad financial position that its auditors could not sign off on its accounts and it survived on loans from the university. At Curtin they survived, but only after shedding most representation, welfare and social services. Flourishing, I don’t think!

This bill is clearly payback to students for daring to criticise the Howard government’s massive HECS hikes and its attacks on university students and their families. Students, of course, have just been standing up for themselves and for the students who will come in the future. This government does not like the fact that student organisations regularly and effectively remind the Australian public that, even before the 25 per cent fee hike hit students, HECS fees have nearly doubled since this government was elected in 1996. Since the 25 per cent fee hike was allowed by this government, nearly 30 universities have put up their fees—most of them by the full 25 per cent. The government does not like the fact that student organisations remind the public that it is this government which allows Australians with lower marks to jump the queue and buy a place at university by paying $100,000 or more. A medical degree at Melbourne University today can cost $210,000, despite critical shortages of doctors across Australia.

It is this government that has seen the national HECS debt rise to $11 billion. Our graduates are carrying $11 billion in HECS debt. We know also that this government is going to see an explosion in FEE-HELP loans when this new area of student debt blows out to $3 billion by 2008-09. So this government does not like it much when student organisations remind the public that, according to one study, Australia now has the fourth highest fee structure in the world. And what does this government want to do? It wants to shut down any dissent about these issues on our university campuses.

Of course, we know that attacking student organisations has assumed the status of a holy crusade for a band of zealots on the other side. I think we are up to the seventh crusade against the humble student organisation. The members opposite have tried every single avenue they could to satisfy their desire for retribution against their enemies in student politics in the 1970s. They have tried very unsuccessfully to hold referenda on university campuses on the payment of fees. They failed in that democratic approach.

Next they tried the courts. They were rebuffed in the courts. In 2002 they even went to the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission with a challenge to the existing membership arrangements at James Cook University. Once again, the outcome was a setback for those who seek to undermine student organisations. So the only option left is to try yet again for legislative intervention into our universities.

So the Australian Liberal Students Federation—always a minority on campuses—has been campaigning to win the support of Liberal parliamentarians to impose their will on students. They cannot win elections on campus, so they come here to the parliament. So here we are again, as we were in 1999 and again last year just before the election when former Minister David Kemp and the current minister moved unsuccessfully to legislate against student organisations. We are back here again, with Liberal students, past and present, attempting to impose their will on students in universities via this parliament.

I have to say the minister is showing he is more than up to the task of playing student politics with this blatantly ideological attack on student organisations. This is even more accurate than it might sound at first. A recent article in the Australian reported that the President of the Australian Liberal Students Federation ‘helped education minister Brendan Nelson draft the legislation’. What more evidence do we need that this bill is about nothing more than petty vendettas that originate in student politics? The Liberal Students Federation president went on to say—and you will like this, Mr Deputy Speaker McMullan:

quote.para: “Our organisation has absolutely no sympathy for the vice-chancellors and university administration ...
“These people have been shop stewards in suits for the past 90 years on this.

speech.para: That is the vice-chancellors of our universities! I wonder whether Brendan Nelson got his inspiration from the Liberal Students Federation’s views of vice-chancellors and universities when he was drafting his extraordinarily interventionist university reforms back in 2003. I wonder whether the minister has read about some of the support that student organisations have received from fairly high places. Maybe he is not familiar with those views. One view states:

quote.para: “The funding and ... provision of the various student services would be impossible unless there was some requirement to pay a contribution towards them ... The fact that some people object to the way in which some public funds are spent does not mean that they are therefore exempted from paying taxes.

speech.para: Who was that? It was none other than Peter Costello, the federal Treasurer and former student politician, writing in Monash University’s publication Lot’s Wife, back in 1978. The Treasurer is not alone; he has a senior colleague who agrees with him. Here is what the current Minister for Human Services had to say about the Liberal Party’s plans, when he wrote in Sydney University’s student paper when he was SRC President in 1986 and when the current Prime Minister was the Leader of the Opposition. Joe Hockey said:

quote.para: “It has taken 120 years of student union membership at Sydney University to provide the facilities we all take for granted. It can all end in one foul political swoop.

speech.para: It will be a ‘foul’ political swoop if this legislation goes through. Joe Hockey went on to say back in 1986 that current sporting facilities would be sold and ‘Sydney University Rugby Club would close down’—this is according to the government’s Minister for Human Services. So I look forward to seeing these two unwavering men of principle crossing the floor to fight for what they believe in.

A similar comment was made on Tuesday, 10 May 2005 in the Queensland parliament by Michael Horan, the former leader of the Queensland Nationals. Mr Horan wrote to the Minister for Education, Science and Training and others in the government in the following terms:

quote.para: I think the Commonwealth government should put in place a way in which universities like USQ—

speech.para: the University of Southern Queensland—

quote.para: can provide within their structure a service fee which they can then use to assist the student guild to continue providing sporting facilities, recreational facilities, and counselling and support services.

speech.para: It would seem that people from all sides of politics, particularly the government’s side, can see the value of student organisations and have seen that for a very long time—all except those who are falling into line behind the current minister for education.

The government have shown that they would love nothing more than to take away from the students of today the terrific opportunities that they had when they were students themselves. So many of the coalition ministers, including the current minister for education, got a free education under Labor governments. But as soon as they got into government they hiked up HECS fees, slashed billions of dollars from universities and introduced full fees of up to $210,000.

Now the government wants to do the same with student clubs and societies. It seems that many of the government’s ministers were very happy to take student money when it came to subsidising their sporting careers at university. Now that they are out to destroy student services I think it is only fair that they should have to pay back what they took from student organisations when they were at university. That is what they are planning to do to the students of today. They are planning to make sure that these students have to pay the full costs of sporting organisations, so it is only fair that they pay back the benefit they got from the student sporting facilities they used when they were students at their universities.

Take the Treasurer, for example. He was very active in student organisations. He was a member of the Monash University AFL club. We figured out that in today’s terms he would owe about $5,000. That is how much the Treasurer should have to pay back to that sporting organisation for the benefit he got when he was at Monash. If the Minister for Human Services crosses the floor and sticks up for what he used to believe in he would not have to pay, but if he decides to fall in behind the minister for education and ignore what his real views are about the effect of this bill then the Minister for Human Services would also owe about $5,000 for the time when he was an active member of the Sydney University rugby club. It looks like what he said back in 1986 will be right—with fees like that, sporting clubs will have to close down or be sold off to survive. I think the Minister for Human Services got it dead right back in 1986, and I certainly hope he will vote with us to oppose this legislation.

The Minister for Health and Ageing was also an active member of Sydney University’s rugby club. He would also owe over $5,000 for all the benefit he got from that. The Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations was a member of the athletics club at Melbourne University. There is also Senator Kemp; and the member for Wentworth also got a big benefit, again from the Sydney University rugby club. The rugby club at Sydney University has been very kind to members of this government and given them a lot of subsidised access to their facilities—subsidised access that will not be available to that rugby club if this bill goes through the parliament. All these people should either pay up or, if they have any principles left, oppose this legislation.

Lastly, the positive role that student organisations have played in cultivating active citizenship must not be forgotten in this debate. That is true across the political spectrum, as we have seen by the number of people in senior positions of the government—the Treasurer, the Minister for Human Services, the Minister for Health and Ageing and the member for Wentworth were all active members of their student organisations and they got a lot of experience when they were in those student organisations that has assisted them to go on and play the role they do in the public life of the nation. We can see that on all sides of politics—but not only politics. Many members of the judiciary, leading figures in the arts and the media, and many public commentators have cut their teeth in student organisations. That experience will not be there for them any longer. If the ideology and arrogant excesses of this government see this bill become law, the positive influence of student organisations on society and democracy will disappear.

We will be fighting this legislation, which will be terribly damaging to the services provided to students on our university campuses. We will do everything we can to convince the Senate not to be blinded by this government’s ideology and the settling of some very old scores. We will do everything we can to protect student organisations from a government determined to do away with some of the most important services on our university campuses, services that provide so much of university and campus life, services that can make a difference to so many disadvantaged students and services that make sure sporting facilities are affordable. Labor will continue to fight for all of these things against what is just an ideological attack by a government determined to settle a very old score.

talk.start.para: —I have been waiting for a long time to witness today’s debate and it is indeed a privilege to be a participant and a supporter of the Higher Education Support Amendment (Abolition of Compulsory Up-front Student Union Fees) Bill 2005. Today is an historic day for all Australians who believe in freedom of association for students—voluntary student unionism. The member for Jagajaga just spoke—what a negative, whingeing, miserable member of this House she is.
—She’s consistent!

—True, she is consistent. She makes the assumption that with voluntary student unionism unions will collapse. In other words, she is saying that no student would see any benefit in giving money to join a student union. I think she is very wrong. I think student unions, just like any other association, can be responsive to their members and can determine what sorts of services and facilities their members and potential members would want and offer them. I put down all that doom and gloom to a lot of negativity and scaremongering from the member for Jagajaga. And the experience in Western Australia has proved her wrong.

speech.para: On several occasions there has been an attempt to get legislation through this parliament to give tertiary students, who, by and large, are adults, the right to join or not to join a student association. Unfortunately, on these previous occasions the bill has failed to pass the Senate. But I make a prediction today: this bill will have a very different fate. I have been advised that the bill will reach the Senate in August of this year, when the coalition will have a majority in the Senate. Let me remind all those members on the other side who have been listed to speak against this bill, lest the lessons of history be forgotten, that the coalition majority in the Senate is a legacy that was left to this government by their former leader Mark Latham.

So today I rejoice and join with other former Liberal students around the country and around the world who have fought the battle and waited for decades for this day. It is very pleasing indeed to have in the chamber my colleague, good friend and former Liberal student ally the member for Casey, who I believe will be speaking very soon on this bill. I would also like to put on the record that I am very privileged to have been a member, an executive member and president of the longest running Liberal club in this country. I wear it as a badge of honour and I take issue with the member for Jagajaga.

It seems that the president of the Australian Liberal Students Federation has really got under the member for Jagajaga’s skin. He is just a poor, ordinary student engaged in public debate, putting forward his view that people of his generation at university should have the right to choose. I wonder what the member for Jagajaga has to fear from students who are exercising their democratic voice. She stated that this legislation was driven towards one view, a uniformity of view. That is not the case. Students have the right to express, and do express, all sorts of views. They can express extremist views if they like—and we have seen plenty of those, paid for through student funds compulsorily acquired—but they should do it with their own money or money they have raised and not with funds compulsorily acquired from students, many of whom disagree with their arguments and their political campaigns—on which I will have something to say a little later on.

We cannot mention Liberal students without mentioning their passion and dedication to the Liberal Party. These young warriors on campus have been the brunt of criticism and ridicule from people in privileged positions such as the member for Jagajaga. But I am proud to say that I was part of a group—and they still have these characteristics today—that will not be politically blackmailed or intimidated into being politically correct. Our political process in this country would be the poorer without these people who are the true believers in the Liberal Party and who are engaged in the political process out of a conviction of upholding the very basic values and tenets of the Liberal Party such as freedom of association. Freedom of association is one of the pillars the Liberal Party stands for. And it is not a freedom to be compromised. You cannot be ‘just a little’ compelled to pay for some of the services that members of parliament think students should want to have. That is a choice for them to make. You either trust students to make a decision about what is in their best interests or you do not. It is as simple as that.

Some on the other side of this debate are trying to obscure the issue by claiming there should be a compulsory fee for so-called services instead of a general fee that is used for some services and for political campaigns and organisations. The distinction made by the member for Jagajaga is an absolute fraud. Voluntary student representation—for want of another name—still takes money from students. We only have to look at the example of legislation in Victoria. The misguided belief in Victoria was that this would end the practice of students’ money being used to fund political campaigns and organisations with which they disagree. But the legislation failed dramatically to stop students’ money from being misallocated by a few student activists.

In the year ending December 2004, Monash University collected over $8½ million of compulsorily acquired fees, supposedly for essential services, and 56 per cent of this was spent on administration. At my old university, the University of Melbourne, an extraordinary 72 per cent of compulsorily acquired student money went into profits or administrative costs. These so-called profits can be and have been used to fund political campaigns and to support political organisations with which individual students often disagree. We saw under the Victorian legislation a Clayton’s version of voluntary student unionism. We had the absolutely abominable act by the Monash University Student Association, after the S11 tragedy, of using student money to produce stickers that read ‘Bomb the White House’, a statement with which I vehemently disagree. Had these student activists used their own money, or money specifically raised to pay for their stickers, I would still oppose their argument. They can do what they wish with their own money but not with money they have effectively stolen from students. Across the country, in Western Australia, the Murdoch University student guild occupied the university senate building, causing $12,000 worth of damage. Is this the so-called advocacy the member for Jagajaga holds up as an example of how students should behave?

Most student unions unashamedly campaigned against the Howard government at the last federal election, which may perhaps explain the passion with which the member for Jagajaga defends them. We only have to look at the Northern Territory University union, which took out a full-page advertisement in the Northern Territory News urging a vote against my good friend and colleague the member for Solomon. Whatever views one may hold about particular candidates, one thing is for sure: there is no unanimity of political opinion amongst students on campus. Some vote Labor, some vote Liberal and some vote for an assortment of other parties. You cannot use student funds in such a blatant manner that can affect the result of an election.

We saw another disgraceful example at the 2004 Australian National University open day. They had an effigy of the Prime Minister. It was advertised that the effigy was available for anyone to have a swing at. All this was paid for with funds compulsorily acquired for students.

And let not the northern, sunny state of Queensland be left out of some of these disgraceful examples. The University of Queensland’s union deserves comment because it has been one of the consistently outrageous wasters of compulsorily acquired union funds. It paid for a women-only surf camp. It employed a researcher to explore the feminist reclamation of an extremely crude word which refers to female genitalia. This so-called research is now included in the 2005 union survival guide. What an absolute joke!

We do not hear the member for Jagajaga or the Labor Party referring to any of these examples of so-called union services in education. This union from the University of Queensland could not even manage to keep their own union offices clean enough to pass their own workplace and safety requirements. What a joke and what a disgrace. This is the result of lack of accountability when students are forced to pay money and student unions and student union activists have very little, if any, accountability.

But first prize for a bold and unprecedented theft of student money must go to my old university—to the Melbourne University Student Union, the extravagant arrogance of the union and the saga that is still unfolding in the courts. In 2001, the student union entered into a contract with a company called Optima. The contract purported to bind the university as guarantor for a $44 million apartment complex. Two Labor Club members—the signatory to the contract, Darren Ray, and the student union president, Scott Crawford—kept this contract a secret from the union executive. Of course, the fraud squad and the liquidators eventually moved in. The matter is now in the courts. No doubt we will be hearing from Mr Landeryou, apparently the main beneficiary of this contract, who fled to Costa Rica but who has recently returned.

Who is Mr Landeryou? None other than a former Labor club president at the Melbourne University Student Union. When he was president, he so outraged students that he was the first ever student union president at the University of Melbourne to be sacked—sacked by an overwhelming majority of students. I take great pride in having been involved in that campaign, in a cross-party coalition to rid Melbourne University Student Union of Mr Landeryou and his general secretary, Keir Semmens. He was sacked amid allegations of corruption and misuse of power. Under the system of compulsory unionism, political decisions were made to cut funds to organisations that did not align with the Labor club. Bullying and intimidation were an integral part of the arrogance with which the Labor club dominated at the university of Melbourne.

Some things never change. Obviously Mr Landeryou could not keep away from his former student union. In recent court proceedings he has been alleged to be the beneficiary of this $44 million contract. The whole affair stinks of Khemlani-esque proportions. Allegations of international money transfers, forgery and phoney directors abound.

The close colleagues and friends of Mr Landeryou at university included some of today’s aspiring Labor Party politicians, Evan Thornley and Richard Marles—the former contributing to the Labor Party’s failed and embarrassing policy of Noodle Nation and the latter being an extremely uninspiring drone of the union movement who is alienating scores of Labor Party members in his often described dodgy attempts at stacking out the seat of Corio. Indeed, some of these Labor student politicians do learn some very valuable lessons on campus using the compulsorily acquired union funds.

These Labor Party boys were bullies and thugs then, and nothing has changed. I was at university when these Labor Party boys were arrogantly pushing their weight around on campus. They were political thugs, and by all accounts they continue to be. I say to those in the Labor Party, ‘Do not surrender your party to these sorts of individuals. They will corrode from within what integrity is left.’ Instead, what do I find with all these pleas of mine to help the Labor Party become a decent opposition that the Australian people deserve and an integral part of a democracy? We have not only a cheer squad: more than that, we have the pro bono defence team for the disgraced Andrew Landeryou. That is what you will see in this debate. There is a whole list of them. They will come out and defend a system that lets someone like that not only flourish and grow but continue to do so even after he had left university.

Perhaps there is still some hope for them. Perhaps if they listened to one of their own on the other side, the member for Melbourne Ports, they would rethink their position. In a very enlightened article entitled ‘Extremists and vice-chancellors’, the honourable member said:

quote.para: The power of AUS, for all its bash merchants, could have been dissolved virtually overnight if governments and university administrators had acted to make the decision of any student to become part of it voluntary.

speech.para: He continued:

quote.para: What was required was not any suppression or any fresh coercion, but simply a removal of coercive power from a body which had no entitlement to it.

speech.para: The clarity of the honourable member’s observations continued when he stated:

quote.para: It is interesting to consider whether or not the establishment—the governments and university administrations who continued to force students to support AUS—ever wondered or cared what students thought of them and what kind of an image of their own values they were projecting to students at large. Why the establishment seemed so unwilling to permit freedom of association for students, either on individual campuses or nationally (and the one necessarily implied the other), remains a mystery to many ...

speech.para: Indeed, those questions are still relevant and should be pondered very deeply by members on the other side.

A debate on voluntary student unionism would be incomplete without a particular reference to the honourable Norman Moore, MLC, former minister for education in Western Australia, one of the few courageous visionaries who ensured that students in that state—70,000 of them—enjoyed freedom of association from about 1995 to 2003, when the state Labor government abolished it. His good work, his preparation and his determination to do the right thing by students gives us some examples to disprove the doom and gloom predictions of the member for Jagajaga.

What did we see? At the University of Western Australia the student union was better focused on student services and student needs. A new system of subsidised textbooks and legal services were offered. So the argument by members on the other side of the House that services would collapse is not only morally bankrupt but also intellectually hollow. They know it is not true. They engage in emotive arguments. The argument they most often put forward is about the sporting elite. Good gracious me! As a Victorian, I was surprised that the member for Jagajaga was such a fan of rugby. She talked on and on about rugby and asked why the government were not listening to Kevin Gosper and Ric Charlesworth, among other sports people. I could pose a similar question. Perhaps if there were a panel of about 12 famous sports people, they could make better leadership decisions in the Labor Party and come up with better policies. But we are the government—elected overwhelmingly by the Australian people. This measure is a basic part of our Liberal Party platform and we will introduce it.

Let me say this to those on the other side who claim that rugby teams will suffer. No student going to any university, particularly Sydney University, should be forced to subsidise the rugby team. It has been put to me that many famous and wealthy people, part of the Sydney establishment, were involved in the Sydney University Rugby Club, and that they would not be particularly happy with this legislation. I am not going to be intimidated and I say, ‘Too bad.’ You like your rugby club, which competes professionally with other league teams, and students will support it. Or, if you are so wealthy and influential, you support it. I will not stand aside from something I believe in strongly because a few blokes in Sydney have an emotional attachment to their rugby team.

I have campaigned for voluntary student unionism for all my political life, for 18 years. It is something I believe in strongly and something I have fought for, along with many others. I am extremely proud—I did not know how long I would have to wait—of the courage that this government and this minister have shown in doing the right thing by students. We do not live in the Dark Ages any more. We need to take university representation into the 21st century. I commend the bill to the House and look forward to its passage through the Senate, where we will be watching and cheering it on with great happiness.

talk.start.para: —It is with some pleasure that I stand this afternoon to indicate my opposition to the government’s Higher Education Support Amendment (Abolition of Compulsory Up-front Student Union Fees) Bill 2005. The opposition is determined to raise very serious issues concerning this bill. For the education of the member for Indi, rugby is not a game played just in New South Wales and Queensland. One of our most famous Australians, who represented the Wallabies in rugby, cut his teeth at Melbourne University in the Melbourne University Rugby Club—namely, Weary Dunlop. So rather than having a side debate about the Sydney University Rugby Club, let us concentrate on what this debate is really about.

speech.para: There is a view in Australia that we as a community are not bludgers. We are a community that prides ourselves on a hard day’s work for a fair day’s pay, and believes in paying its way. That is the crux of this debate. For our gifted young who are fortunate enough to go to university, university does not just offer one of the best education opportunities in terms of a simple focus on education—it also appropriately offers a terrific opportunity for a well-rounded education. We as a community have to focus on developing well-rounded young Australians because they are the future of this nation. That is about guaranteeing that they are exposed to a wealth of opportunities, not just a narrow-minded focus on tuition through their university or TAFE opportunities. For those reasons, I say that, unfortunately, this bill is a prime example of the government’s narrow-minded intention to stamp out any activities and organisations that do not fall into line with its politics.

I know from when we were in government—it does not matter who is in government—that there will be opposition from student organisations to decisions of the government. I think back to the hard decision that the Labor Party made—in over 13 years of very tough decisions—to introduce the Higher Education Contribution Scheme. That was opposed by student unions. They had a view that no young person should make any contribution to the cost of their education. They campaigned in the streets. They campaigned on the campuses. They were often led by representatives of Liberal Party organisations on student campuses who had a view that students should not pay their way. They did it when we were in government in the same way as they are doing it now, when there is an alternative government in place. That is the nature of free speech. It is a part of students’ development. They are entitled to have their view in life.

But this society has to start fronting up to the fact that, whether this government likes it or not, student unions are not trade unions. I am pleased to say that I have had a history in the trade union movement. There is a wealth of difference between a student union and a trade union. The problem is that the Howard government has decided to crush trade unions—that is a debate for another day. So be it. Alternative governments in the past, both within Australia and beyond Australia, have had a determination to destroy organised labour in Australia. Let us draw a line in the debate. It is about time we also fronted up to the fact that the Howard government is wrong in its view: student unions are not trade unions. The government, unfortunately, does not understand the distinction.

The government does not understand that no student organisation in Australia forces students to be a member of that organisation. I once attended university. I chose to be a member of the Labor club. Unlike the member for Indi, for example, I did not concentrate my university days on student politics. Unlike the member for Indi, many of my mates were too busy pursuing part-time work to assist with the costs of pursuing a university opportunity. We came from large families where education was second to no other priorities in those families.

The member for Indi had her fun on university campuses and is consumed with student politics. All I can say is that it is about time she got out of her cocoon and actually looked to the broader aspects of life and to the terrific range of services offered on university campuses to young Australians aimed at trying to guarantee that they are given the best opportunities and the most rounded educational opportunities in life. That is why voluntary membership of university student organisations already exists.

We also have to deal with a bit of history. The tradition of student unions or guilds dates back to the early 1800s when the original Cambridge and Oxford unions were established as community centres for students. Today they are infamous debating chambers and they stand for the great tradition—and, I believe, the inalienable right—of freedom of speech.

From time to time governments change. Student unions, irrespective of who is in government, will find fault with the government of the day. Let them express their views. Let them demonstrate. Let them have their campaigns on HECS, Iraq, refugees—on every issue under the sun. That is part of their personal development. It is part of encouraging them to think and to express a point of view.

When you go through some of the leading activists on university campuses you find that, while they may have started with what would be perceived by the government to be a rather radical point of view, as time goes on they sit on the other side of the business fence and are consumed by making a dollar and economic opportunity more than going back to their days of radical university activities. As they go through life, they develop different ideas about what is right and wrong.

My friends, it therefore concerns me greatly that this government, an Australian government of the 21st century, seems determined to undermine the rights of freedom of speech and freedom of association, not only through this bill but through many other insidious pieces of legislation, particularly in the area of industrial relations.

The truth is that this debate is taking Australia back to the Dark Ages. That is because we have a government at the moment that is not consumed with the big picture but consumed with insidious little issues on the way, based on their particular hatreds or the pet subjects that they want to settle scores on. That is also reflected in the nature of the budget that they brought in this week. So let us make sure that, in thinking about this bill, we try to take a picture of Australia as a leading nation in the 21st century in the free world.

Unfortunately, we have a government with no vision for Australia’s future—a government that is squandering a once in a lifetime surge in world economic growth driven by the resource boom and once in a lifetime terms of trade, by failing to invest in Australia’s productive capacity, skills, training and infrastructure to underpin and guarantee our future growth. Unfortunately, rather than investing in Australia’s productive capacity, this government cannot see beyond driving economic growth by fuelling consumption through tax cuts to the big spenders.

I have no problems voting against a tax cut for myself. I do not consider that someone on about $108,000 per year, someone like me, is entitled to a tax cut while a child-care worker, a nurse or a maths or science teacher gets six bucks. Nor do I consider it appropriate that someone who is going to get a highly rewarding superannuation payment from the Australian taxpayers is entitled to a further increase in that entitlement by abolishing the superannuation tax surcharge. I think I am doing all right, unlike a lot of the constituents that I represent in the northern suburbs of Melbourne.

Let us get our priorities right. Let us start working out how we can create a system that encourages people, through wages and tax incentives, to want to be child-care workers, nurses, maths or science teachers, bricklayers, boilermakers or welders. Those are our priorities. Those are the bottlenecks that are going to hold back Australia’s economic growth sooner rather than later. But they are not the priorities in the current government’s approach to economic management. They are driven by a narrow-minded debate about hatred of student unions. What is that going to do for Australia’s economic future? Nought. It is going to make no contribution at all to Australia’s productive future.

Let us get our priorities right. Let us start investing in our productive capacity. Let us start trying to work out what we have to do to invest in our future skills and infrastructure development. Let us make sure that we actually reward hardworking low-income Australian families, who struggle to live from day to day let alone week to week. Those are the people who are the engine room of economic growth in Australia—not politicians, who are not entitled to a wage increase or an improvement in their superannuation entitlements, which are the real priorities of the current budget that is being debated in the House.

It is no wonder, therefore, when you think about this being a major priority of the Howard government’s agenda, as expressed by the member for Indi, that we have our minds off the fact that economic growth in Australia is slowing. We have our minds off the fact that the budget predicts a permanent downgrade in expected future growth rates from 2008-09. That is what we should be debating at the moment: how we meet that challenge as a community.

It is also no wonder that, despite the extraordinary surge in Australia’s terms of trade to their best level in 50 years, Australia has experienced the longest run of trade deficits in our history. Those are the real facts. When do you hear the Treasurer talk about those issues as priorities? He does not want to talk about them because they mean actually having a bit of leadership and making a few hard decisions—just as Labor, with its priorities to create opportunities for young people in education, developed the HECS system when in government; just as Labor did something about traditional apprenticeships, because we need the most skilled work force in the world, where well-rounded young Australians can meet all challenges. What is the government’s response? It has increased HECS and, if you are dumb and rich, you can get to university, but encouraging university activities is not a priority.

Despite record demand and record prices and a rate of export growth at just two per cent, down from 10 per cent when this government came to power in March 1996, it is no wonder that Australia’s current account deficit is now 6.5 per cent of GDP, higher than at any point in 50 years. They are the real facts; they are the economic statistics behind the challenges that confront Australia at the moment. This is what happens when you drive the economy with unsustainable consumption instead of productivity. That is what happens when you have a government that focuses on petty issues like crushing student unions rather than the real debate that confronts Australia. It loses sight of the big picture and the real issues.

This bill is a prime example of the Howard government’s mean-spirited and small-minded approach to Australian public policy and what we as a community should see as our priorities. The bill, and it is interesting, will make Australia one of the only countries in the OECD not to charge fees to support student services at university. What types of services are we talking about? Firstly, there are sporting clubs. I do not care whether it is cricket, hockey, rugby, Aussie rules or whatever. What is wrong with encouraging students to participate in sporting activities at university? Nothing whatsoever. There are health and fitness clubs, medical clinics, debating societies, housing and accommodation, social clubs, arts activities and student welfare. If you are a young person coming from a country area to a foreign campus in a capital city, unless you were born with a silver spoon in your mouth and went to an elite boarding school in a capital city, you need this type of assistance when you arrive in an area unknown to you. You need these services to assist you in the adjustment to university life.
