They are also places where lifelong friendships and deep relationships are forged on many fronts. They are places where many young people have their first exposure to a diverse community. People come from all over the country and, indeed, from all over the world—from rural centres and cities, from all kinds of socioeconomic and political backgrounds and with all kinds of skills and interests. It is about the Australian way of life. In essence, they are places of socialisation where we mature as young adults and develop a sense of place in the nation and the world. They are places to encourage new ideas and dreams. The new ideas first hatched on these campuses will shape and develop kindred spirits and help us as a nation to mature and nurture our place in the world.

Student unions are about our future leaders. Our elite athletes and artists will be discovered and developed on university campuses. So I am going to vote for a well-rounded education. That is why I am pleased to oppose this bill. I do not care what university students campaign for or against. That is the nature of freedom of speech. They have campaigned against us in the past when we were in government and, when we form government in the future, without a doubt they will campaign against us again, just as they campaign against the current government. They were on the streets during the last election campaign. They have been on the streets about Iraq. I tell you what: we copped a hiding from some of those student unions about our position on Iraq too—so what? They are entitled to their view about life. It is about freedom of speech and association.

Let us front up to the fact that the real debate is about allowing university students to participate in a vibrant non-academic life—in sporting clubs, in the arts, in debating and in many other social activities. Do not deny students these opportunities by being mean-spirited. Encourage and cultivate them. We are all big enough to cop criticism; we cop it at home with our own kids. I have two kids at university. They certainly do not agree with me about everything, in the same way that I had debates with my father about decisions he had to make when he was in government. That is the nature of freedom of speech and we should be encouraging and fostering it.

For students, campuses can be daunting. That hand of friendship through clubs and associations is important in assisting students to adapt to university and make new friends, some of which are long lasting. It is reflected on the other side of the House: many long friendships are established at university—not just in the Young Liberal club but also in sporting activities such as the rugby club at the University of Sydney. I am proud that we achieved that, irrespective of the views on the other side of the House.

Students with special needs, like single mothers, will suffer if we do not face our responsibilities to encourage and foster these services. These students rely on access to good-quality, convenient and affordable child-care services, to medical clinics, to assistance in obtaining part-time work and to assistance in finding accommodation. It is our responsibility to assist these young people. It is our responsibility to invest in their future. The Australian Labor Party, in its opposition to this bill, is not driven by ideology; we accept the role of student unions. Let them criticise the government of the day. I think it is terrific to have such a fertile debate in the Australian community.

By encouraging these services we can guarantee university students a well-rounded education. Let’s encourage them to fully participate in the community life of their universities. Without compulsory fees, these services will be significantly reduced and it will be harder for our young people to participate and develop themselves through university life. It is about services and facilities; it is not about ideology or a mean-spirited approach to education in Australia. I am proud to stand in opposition to this bill. We are not talking about trade unionism; we are talking about services needed by ordinary young Australian men and women, and by those who come to Australia from overseas to study, to assist them in developing and educating themselves.

talk.start.para: —After listening to the bizarre and rambling dissertation of the member for Batman on the Higher Education Support Amendment (Abolition of Compulsory Up-front Student Union Fees) Bill 2005, I have heard some arguments from the Labor Party that I have never heard before. Somehow mateship and friendship in Australia are totally reliant on compulsory unionism. I have never heard such a ridiculous proposition. Bizarre claims were also made about the right to protest. No-one cares about what student unions do as long as they do it without forcibly acquiring the money of every other student to do it, which seems to be the point that the previous speaker misses entirely. Whether he misses it deliberately or through utter ignorance, I fear it is the latter. This debate sums up so much about the difference between this side of the House and the other. Simple matters of freedom, choice and conscience are difficult and complicated questions for the Australian Labor Party.
—What about the three-year-old behind barbed wire at Villawood? You talk about freedom!

—The member for Corio seeks to interject. I would have thought that he would be a secret supporter of this bill. Compulsory unionism at Melbourne university has brought forth Richard Marles, who is about to steamroll him in Corio. I would have thought that the member for Corio would have been very happy with the recent developments with Mr Landeryou—but I will come back to that later in this debate. I am very glad that the next recipient of corrupt Labor student unions is in the House to speak on this bill following me.

speech.para: This legislation is simply about the principle of freedom of association—the principle that students going to university should be able to choose whether they belong to an organisation or not. Through the industrial relations reform agenda of the government, we have introduced voluntary membership to unions against the wishes of those opposite. Campuses remain the last bastion of compulsory unionism. That fundamental principle, the freedom to decide whether or not to belong to a union, is one that those on this side of the House have always stood up for and will always stand up for while those on the other side of the House have always opposed it.

In a choice between the right of someone to choose to belong to an organisation, the Labor Party will always subjugate that right because they will always do everything they can for their union mates. They have always been opponents of freedom of association for a number of reasons—not just philosophically but also pragmatically because they rely on the funds that compulsory membership brings. It brings a great deal of money to the Australian Labor Party, as a previous speaker, the member for Indi, pointed out. Unions contribute massive amounts to Labor coffers. Where compulsory unionism still exists it means, in frank terms, that workers have their money taken against their will. Part of that money is donated to the Australian Labor Party against the will of workers.

With the opposition of the Labor Party we have forged many improvements in Australian workplaces. This bill, which deals with voluntary membership of student organisations, is not a simple or radical bill; it is a bill that simply says: if students wish to join a union they can, but they will not be forced to join a union if they do not like the services it offers; they will not be forced to join a union to fund the bizarre and wasteful excesses of student unions.

Aside from addressing important issues of freedom of choice, this bill exposes another great hypocrisy of the Australian Labor Party, particularly from the opposition’s lead speaker, the member for Jagajaga, who has spoken today—and has bleated it persistently since this bill was first introduced—of her so-called concern for the financial burdens that students on Australian campuses face. It is beyond belief that members opposite can say on the one hand that they want to relieve financial burdens on students but, on the other, oppose a bill which will abolish the only compulsory up-front fee that is charged to all students. Unlike HECS, the fees charged by student unions must be paid in full and must be paid up-front. There is no allowance for deferred payments whatsoever. And being up-front, these fees are a far greater burden on low-income university students.

On that point I want address the misrepresentation of a previous speaker by a member on the other side who said that perhaps Liberal students on campuses did not understand many of the burdens of students because they had not had part-time jobs. I can tell him that the member for Indi, whom he made that accusation about, worked part time all through her university career. I worked a night shift as a part-time cook all the way through university to fund my way through. That is precisely one of the reasons why so many students object to having their hard earned earnings taken by a student union that wastes them or, in the case of Melbourne university, goes bankrupt.

By virtue of the fact that those opposite, such as the member for Corio, mentioned nothing of the excesses of student unions, I say to them: ‘You support them.’ A compulsory student union has engaged in fraud and mismanagement of the highest order and members of the Labor Party are appearing before court, but the opposition comes into this House and carries on like a parrot and addresses none of those issues. I say to the people of Australia: the members opposite, by their silence, support the very fraud of those student unions that we have seen at Melbourne university.

The union fees charged are grossly inequitable. They pose a barrier. We are saying that, if unions offered good services that students wanted to pay for, they would have no trouble attracting members. Those opposite fear student unions might have trouble attracting members because of the very behaviour that the member for Indi outlined in her contribution and the behaviour that I have already alluded to and will allude to further in this contribution.

For decades student unions have been grossly unrepresentative of the student population. The previous speaker from the other side spoke of how healthy it is to have a debate, how healthy it is to protest. No-one cares what a student union of leftists does: no-one cares if they dye their hair green and roll down the gutters outside Melbourne university—no-one cares less. What they care about is having to fund it. Why should every student on every campus have to fund every Labor Party loop? That is the only point. If what they were protesting about were so good, people would join that union voluntarily in droves, but this is something that completely eludes those opposite.

The member for Indi outlined some of the very examples of the wastefulness of student unions. She spoke of the Monash Student Association printing stickers, paid for by every student forced to belong to that union, saying: ‘Bomb the White House’. How ridiculous! Every student was forced to pay for that sticker—something those opposite, including the member for Corio through his silence, obviously support. The fact that the member for Corio is silent is something that would almost make the front page in this place. I think he is reflecting on where a former Melbourne student union president is right now. What part of Geelong is Richard Marles in as we have this debate? What part of Corio is he in? Which street is he driving down? Which factory is he recruiting members from? That is what the member for Corio is thinking. That is what he is reflecting on today as we take part in this debate. I would to say to him: think again; vote with us on this bill—it is in your own interests.

The member for Indi outlined some of those examples of wastefulness. We have had recently the best one that absolutely nails the pathetic case put forward by those opposite. That is the University of New South Wales guild that actually used compulsorily acquired student funds to have a $600 prize for the campus that brought in the most protesters against this bill, so even to get protesters against this bill they had to use compulsorily acquired student funds to pay for protesters. This is something you would see in the Eastern bloc. It is absolutely ridiculous but those opposite somehow manage—I do not know whether they practise in the morning putting on a straight face before they come in here—to defend this rubbish. They are more than happy to do it.

These student protests are not the expression of the beliefs of students on campus. They are just a cynical attempt by student leaders to try to trick the public into believing that there is some sort of dissatisfaction on campuses with this bill. Last year the same students led protests against the government’s introduction of higher education reform. They have done so in the past; they will do so again.

Some of the most conclusive proof of just how biased these student unions are while not representing students is how in the last election the National Union of Students spent $250,000 of their money campaigning against the Howard government. They did not spend any money campaigning against anybody else. They just decided that with the compulsorily acquired funds they would campaign for the Labor Party, so no wonder you get those opposite defending the indefensible. The ALP claims that it supports the plight of university students, but it is happy to sit back and let $250,000 of compulsorily acquired money from students—those who work in the part-time jobs that the previous Labor speaker was talking of—just be taken away and given to the ALP. Of course you can see why they are prepared to defend the indefensible. These are the sorts of outrageous ways in which student unions on Australian campuses waste the hard earned money that they acquire from students. These are the things that Australian students are forced to fund against their will, just to get an education.

But potentially even more damning than such offensive campaigns is the serious financial mismanagement that the member for Indi spoke about that occurs with these compulsorily acquired funds. Last year we had the example—and it is very much up in lights now, and the member for Corio would be very familiar with all the principal players—of the collapse of the Melbourne university student union, with the university forced to expend hundreds of thousands of dollars in a corruption probe with concerns raised about the signing of many controversial contracts following the election of a Labor Party aligned administration. Many of the wrongdoings of these characters have been exposed in great detail. We have had this cat and mouse chase with Mr Andrew Landeryou, who left the country and has come back and is now operating a web site, I believe, on which he is going to tell all on the Labor Party—so that is one to log into every day, member for Corio—about everything that has been going on in the Labor Party to do with this deal. But the bottom line is you had the member for Jagajaga worrying about student unions not existing under voluntary membership and worrying that if you actually gave people a choice they might not join. She was very worried that student unions might not succeed. With compulsory membership at Melbourne university the union collapsed! That is the absolute hypocrisy of it. I say to the member for Boothby that I am worried that they actually do not see the irony in this. If I thought they went back to their offices and thought this was a bit of a tough gig—trying to defend this indefensible, corrupt, criminal behaviour—but they would do it, that would be one thing. They are ignorant. I think they have an absolute morality gap on this sort of thing.

The investigation is ongoing. We are sure that will unfold in great detail over the coming weeks and months. But what did it all mean for those students at Melbourne university, those students who paid that compulsory fee of $382? What it meant was that the union which forced them to join against their will took their money and sent itself broke. What did they get for their money? Where was this greater good that those opposite speak of? The member for Jagajaga went out of her way, as did the previous speaker, the member for Batman, to criticise the Australian Liberal Students Federation. Let me say quite openly: I was a member of the Australian Liberal Students Federation and, yes, I was a president of the Melbourne University Liberal Club—and proudly so. What I say to her is that without the Australian Liberal Students Federation and the Julian Barendses and the Rohan D’ Souzas of Melbourne university, this scandal would never have been uncovered. The Australian Liberal Students Federation are the only organisation that have acted in the interests of all students. Without their actions, without their investigative work, this corruption would still be going on today. So, rather than criticise them, those opposite—if they genuinely believe they have the interests of all students at heart—would be praising them.

Only by passing this bill can we grant students genuine choice about whether or not they wish to join a student union. All we are saying is that we will give students the choice. They have choices everywhere else. That is a big problem for the Labor Party. The students are 18. They can choose what car they drive, they can choose where they work and they can choose what university they go to, but clearly those opposite believe, in some condescending way, that they are not capable of making a choice about whether or not to join a union. We say that if they are old enough to vote and old enough to go to a campus they can choose whether they buy a product or not. They can choose whether they are going to join the union. That is what we are doing: we are giving them a choice that they should have and that they should have had years ago.

Those opposite do low-income students an extraordinary disservice in failing to let them have that choice. The problem for those opposite, as I said at the start of the speech, is that allowing choice and freedom of association is abhorrent to them because it would expose student unions—the sorts of people that come up through the Labor Party ranks and the sorts of people that the member for Corio is familiar with—to the reality of the outside world. The real fear is that it would force student unions to offer services students want.

This was the experience in Western Australia. Those opposite do not have to fear what would happen under voluntary student unionism: you know. As the member for Indi said, it was introduced in Western Australia and none of the doomsday predictions eventuated. Student unions lowered their fees and offered better services. None of the dire predictions of the student unions or, might I say, the vice-chancellors came true. Rather, we saw what commonsense would naturally predict. We saw a voluntary regime where unions could charge what they wanted. They started to provide services to students that students actually wanted and, far from reducing services, the evidence is that they increased them. They provided voluntary union guild loans, which had not previously been available, and the list goes on. None of this should be a surprise. Our modern economy—the member for Batman also tried to address this in his rambling, rolling dissertation—runs on the basis of choice. The government does not prescribe what goods consumers must buy. It allows them to make an informed decision, and that same process is needed with respect to compulsory student unionism.

In concluding, this debate says a lot about the differences between this side of the House and the other. The Labor Party love to mouth words about freedom of speech and of choice and about students’ rights, but the thing you can always rely on with the Labor Party is that, if there is a choice between an individual’s personal rights and the Labor Party’s collective self-interest, it is always the latter that prevails. The Labor Party’s primary objective is to look after themselves. That has always been the way and the students of Australia ought to know it, and they ought to know it in this debate. The Labor Party will always abandon individual interests in favour of their own collective self-interest.

It is a pleasure to speak in this long overdue debate. It is a pleasure to speak on it after the member for Indi, who worked so hard for voluntary student unionism in the time I was with her on campus, and after the member for Boothby, who did the same thing in South Australia. This is a bill that should have been passed decades ago. The fact that compulsory student unionism still exists on university campuses, which hold themselves out to be bastions of freedom, is a sorry reflection not just on that collective roadblock opposite but on the university administrators and vice-chancellors who, for reasons of convenience, sit happily by as willing and meek shop stewards. This bill should be passed and should have been passed decades ago. I commend it to the House.

talk.start.para: —I rise today in full and total opposition to the Higher Education Support Amendment (Abolition of Compulsory Up-front Student Union Fees) Bill 2005. Members opposite have been trying to kill off student organisations in Australia for years. Anti-student organisation legislation has been moved in this place on numerous occasions and, to the credit of the senators involved, those bills received the treatment that I believe they deserved. In the past, bills like this have created a convenient opportunity for Liberal and National MPs to make anti-student union speeches safe in the knowledge that no real damage would be done. Unfortunately, the same cannot be said today. In a very short while—in fact, on 1 July—the coalition will gain control of both houses of parliament and bills like the one we are debating today will become reality.

speech.para: I was listening with interest to the previous speaker, the member for Casey. He said it was about time we had this debate. Let me tell him and others that I had the privilege of participating in exactly the same debate back in March 1999 in this very place. At the time, there was great consideration of a higher education amendment bill and we argued—very strongly, I believe—to reject the bill, and it was rejected.

In recalling that particular debate, I have had a little look at the Hansard of March 1999. The member for Bruce, on our side, made a great contribution to that debate at the time, and I have no hesitation in referring to it here today. I recall it for the benefit of members. I find it interesting, considering the speaker who just addressed the House and the considerations that he was putting forward. I want to refer in part, if I may, to part of the speech that the member for Bruce delivered. He was lifting these words out of a publication that had appeared some years earlier on the issue of compulsory unionism. He said that the article was not recommending the abolition of it. His quote from the article went on:

quote.para: ... since the various student unions do have a positive contribution to offer to student welfare and student education they should be supported by all those who profit from them. It seems reasonable that all those who do profit should make some contribution in return. The funding and therefore provision of the various student services would be impossible unless there was some requirement to pay a contribution towards them.

The fact that some people object to the way in which some public funds are spent does not mean that they are therefore exempted from paying taxes. The fact that there are some political donations made on behalf of SRCs and AUS. that may be abhorrent to some people who have contributed union fees does not mean we should therefore create a situation whereby all activities including those that are profitable to the people concerned are financially penalised by voluntary payments ... the facilities of student unions are only practical on the basis of compulsory contributions ...

speech.para: The member for Bruce pointed out very carefully that those words were uttered by the current Treasurer when he was in the student movement during his days at university. I think it is a good idea to remember how people can be convinced to change their minds, but one wonders how we can ever believe anybody when words like those are said so stridently.

Student organisations have been a part of campus life in Australia for the better part of a century. I understand that when Bob Hawke was a student the then peak national student organisation, the National Union of Australian University Students, had Liberal Party members and Liberal Party sympathisers on the national executive. Whatever the differences between student advocates and the government of the time, until now no Australian government has had the arrogance to really seek to destroy student organisations. Now student organisations are facing extinction at the hands of a government caught up in outdated ideology.

I would like to use my time here today to address some of the arguments used by the government to justify their attacks on Australian students and to talk about some of the ramifications of the passage of this bill. A common argument used by coalition MPs and right-wing commentators is that compulsory union fees are a breach of freedom of association—that is, students are somehow forced to accept the services pressed upon them by their student association. At one point someone even took that argument to the Victorian Supreme Court. Unsurprisingly, the case was rejected. The court found that if you choose to attend a university you choose to accept the conditions of enrolment at that campus, including the payment of fees to the relevant campus organisation. When people say that student organisations make an essential contribution to the university experience they are not just defending their former classmates but stating a fact recognised by the Victorian Supreme Court.

Another fact ignored by the freedom of association argument is the democratic nature of student organisations. If the students on a particular campus want to reduce the amount of money that each member pays, they are free to do so through their own processes. If students at the University of Canberra, for example, decide that they no longer want their own campus based organisation, there is nothing to stop them taking the decision to wind up their association. Conservative politicians love to use the word ‘freedom’ when attacking student organisations because it is the only argument that sounds vaguely credible.

Student organisations provide myriad services to students on campus. Members opposite try to use the political activities conducted by student organisations to support an argument in favour of destroying them. Forget for the moment that an opinionated student population could be considered a positive side effect of having a decent education system and that student politicians are democratically elected, these organisations provide much more than the political advocacy that is sometimes seen on the six o’clock news.

Student organisations provide support so fundamental to campus life that it is often taken for granted by some of their members. These organisations distribute information on local transport arrangements, employment opportunities and ways of avoiding drink spiking—a terrible problem amongst the young at the moment. Counselling, and suicide and rape prevention programs are examples of services provided and paid for by student organisations. Other examples quoted by ACT universities include advice on Centrelink programs, legal advice, health advice, financial advice, rooms where young women can congregate and discuss issues, sexual harassment contact officers and self-defence classes. They also provide subsidised food and coffee, and photocopying, printing and faxing facilities.

When I mention those issues, I cannot help but reflect upon the Minister for Education, Science and Training being absolutely obsessed, during the opening of this debate some weeks ago, with the price of sausage rolls. I felt that that was a bit of an insult. I am sure that the provision of services by student associations through universities in this country goes far beyond the level of the price of a sausage roll. I found that comment quite demeaning to the whole debate.

Under the current system, many campus organisations provide on-campus advocacy services for students. In practice that means that if a student feels that he or she has been unfairly treated they can seek advice from their student association. Here in the ACT if a student at the University of Canberra thinks they have been discriminated against or harassed, or if they need help dealing with the university bureaucracy for any reason, their student association is there to help. They have a full-time advocacy officer employed to ensure that students’ rights are maintained.

Office bearers at the Australian National University Students Association earn less than the minimum wage they would receive at McDonald’s or Woolworths. Despite this, anyone who has walked through the main courtyard at ANU during their O week market day will know that the lack of remuneration has not dampened their spirits at all. They have sailing, rugby and hiking clubs. They have debating, law, literary and Baha’i societies. The lists are long but comprehensive and it is voluntary for whoever wishes to join any one of them.

ANU students organise political debates between Labor and Liberal parliamentarians. Latter year students volunteer as mentors for campus newcomers and ANU Students Association representatives mediate between students and faculty representatives during disputes. To take away their student associations is to take away all these services and more. The services and advocacy provided to Canberra students by Canberra students affect the entire university experience. Attacking those organisations will deny future students the experiences enjoyed by many of the members opposite.

Let us look at this in a more purely political sense. In their eagerness to write off student organisations as one-eyed, left-leaning organisations, government members are offending a great number of conservative students who will suffer alongside Labor, Greens and Democrats, and anyone else for that matter, voting students at universities. That is why I believe student organisations are finding support in some unlikely places.

The Victorian state branch of The Nationals has recognised the effect this legislation will have on rural campuses and their surrounding areas, and it has rejected this legislation, comparing the collection of student union fees to government rates and taxes. Coalition members and senators from rural areas would do well to consider the contribution that regional campuses make to local economies. Student organisations provide services, infrastructure and jobs in many rural areas. As their funding is cut, so too will be the services they provide and the jobs associated with that service provision. The Nationals senator elect Barnaby Joyce was quoted in the Australian on 27 April this year, refuting previous claims that he planned to support VSU and declaring his opposition to the bill in its current form. If that report is accurate, he is to be commended for having the courage of his convictions.

When the coalition government authorised Australian universities to raise HECS fees and introduce up-front fee places, many student organisations reacted by organising protests. The protest events were designed to register students’ opposition to increased fees and up-front fee places and could not have endeared their organisers to the campus vice-chancellors. Despite this the Group of Eight universities and the Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee, both populated by the same vice-chancellors who faced student protesters just last year, have publicly declared their opposition to government interference in the collection of student fees. In a press release issued last July, the Vice-Chancellors Committee described the government’s decision not to proceed with a bill remarkably similar to the one we are debating today as commonsense. In a press release issued in December last year, the Chair of the Group of Eight said:

quote.para: Any move by the federal government to dictate the purposes for which universal student service fees may be collected and disbursed will interfere in the autonomy of universities and damage the character of the cultural, social, sporting and learning environment of the university.

speech.para: That pretty much sums it up. Interfering with the collection of fees is an unwarranted, unwanted intrusion on the part of the federal government and will hurt the university environment in many ways. If the Minister for Education, Science and Training thinks he knows more about the value of student organisations and their contribution to daily life on campus than the Vice-Chancellor of the Australian National University, he is more arrogant than anyone could have guessed.

The students do not want this bill, the university vice-chancellors do not want this bill and some of the more level-headed coalition parliamentarians really and honestly do not want this bill. At the federal level this bill has failed before, and if commonsense prevails it will fail again.

Reference was made by the previous speaker to the situation in Western Australia. While anti-student union legislation has a habit of failing at the federal level, VSU has been tried at the state level, with disastrous results. Conservative governments in Western Australia and Victoria brought in anti-student union legislation during the 1990s and their student populations paid the price. Under VSU, Curtin University in Western Australia was forced to drastically reduce the level of support provided to students. Emergency loans, subsidised catering and rape referrals are just some of the services that were cut as a result of that policy. To their credit the Gallop and Bracks Labor governments repealed the state VSU legislation and, thanks to the support of organisations like NUS, campus organisations managed to weather that storm.

Under the legislation being debated today, the attacks on student organisations will be on a national scale. There will be no support from sympathetic organisations in other states because everyone will have the same problem. Students nationwide will pay the price for coalition ideology, and the experience of going to university may never be the same.

Far from being unique to Australia, universities all around the world recognise the need for student run organisations. Fees charged by Australian student unions pale in comparison with our international competitors. The highest fee charged by an Australian student organisation is between $500 and $600, which is about a quarter or a fifth of some of the charges faced, for example, by equivalent universities in the US. Australia has the dubious honour of being one of a very small minority of countries that questions the need for student organisations.

International students contribute approximately $1.7 billion per year in tuition fees and charges, and approximately $5.9 billion per year to the Australian economy overall. In exchange for the fees charged, student associations and unions provide much needed support for international students. Moving away from home can be stressful enough for domestic students, but international students face added pressure from cultural and language barriers. Threatening the services and support provided by student organisations can only diminish the appeal of Australian university places, which is one thing that we do not want to do. If Australian campuses lose the funds provided by international students, it is unlikely, given its recent track record, that this government would cover any gap created in that way. There will be less funding available and students will suffer.

The arguments put up in support of bills like this over the decades, and this matter has been debated on so many occasions in the past, are based on outdated ideology and without any vision for the future of education in Australia. We have heard members opposite try in vain to argue that universal student unionism is in violation of the principles of freedom, and we have heard members give their highly unflattering opinions of student politicians. What we have not heard is how this legislation is going to help students or contribute to a positive university experience.

I have outlined just a few of the positive contributions that student organisations currently make to campus life, but nobody has said how taking away services and removing student advocates is going to help anyone. I have never heard of a student wishing away the information or advocacy services provided by their student association or union. I would be surprised to find a student who did not appreciate advice from an older student mentor, and I would be shocked to meet a student who received help from their student association with a successful academic appeal yet remained ungrateful.

I refuse to believe that the Liberal and National caucuses are united behind such a bloody-minded attack, and I call on members opposite to exercise their consciences and vote down this bill. I would like to again refer to words the current Treasurer wrote some years ago. He said:

quote.para: The fact that some people object to the way in which some public funds are spent does not mean that they are therefore exempted from paying taxes. The fact that there are some political donations made on behalf of SRCs and AUS that may be abhorrent to some people who have contributed union fees does not mean we should therefore create a situation whereby all activities including those that are profitable to the people concerned are financially penalised by voluntary payments.

speech.para: I could not have put it better myself. I suggest that those opposite make the time to reflect upon the words of the current Treasurer when he was giving that opinion some years ago now on the right to have voluntary union fees in universities in Australia.

talk.start.para: —There is a romantic nostalgia today about university unions. I think of that scene in the 1981 British film Chariots of Fire where a young Harold Abrahams is at his university orientation. He avoids the spruiker of the Fabian Society; he joins the Gilbert and Sullivan Society; and he is of course the star recruit of the Cambridge Athletics Club. But this picture of extramural life has about as much to do with Australian students today as other aspects of the University of Cambridge in the 1920s.

speech.para: When universities were almost exclusively populated by full-time undergraduate students fresh out of school, compulsory union fees were accepted as a part of university life. However, today, higher education has changed dramatically so that there are more part-time, mature age, external and overseas students than ever before. The Dawkins reforms of the late 1980s mean that many universities are now spread over a number of campuses and students on outlying campuses cannot possibly access the main union building or union services. People now take cross-institutional courses, and they often get a bill for union fees from two universities.

Is it really fair to slug an external student a fee for union services when they may never visit the campus? At Deakin University, for example—in the member for Corio’s electorate, perhaps—37 per cent of students are external students. Most of them will never visit Geelong—not to study, anyway. They cannot possibly access the university services. Is it really appropriate to expect a mature age student or a part-time student who attends lectures in the evenings after work to pay for services when they have no time or interest in participating in campus life?

Like many in this debate, especially the previous speakers the member for Indi and the member for Casey, I can claim a longstanding interest in the issue of university union fees and the campaign for VSU. It was the issue which drew me into politics. As President of the Adelaide Medical Students Society in 1989, I was able to achieve half union fees for clinical year, off-campus, medical, dental and agricultural science students at the University of Adelaide. I did it with the support of the University of Adelaide Liberal Club and the students themselves. The argument then, as now, was that students who cannot possibly use the services should not have to pay for them.

We have all heard of the financial problems that university unions will have under VSU. Currently, there is obviously a bit of fat in the system. Last year, during the six-week period of the federal election campaign, the National Union of Students spent over $75,000 on broadcasting electoral advertisements, over $40,000 on publishing these electoral advertisements, nearly $50,000 on producing campaign material like how-to-vote cards, posters or pamphlets and just under $90,000 on direct mailing. That is over a quarter of a million dollars of students’ money being used in a federal election campaign. This is hardly core business of student unions. This is hardly student services. To emphasise the point, the mailing address for the electoral return for the National Union of Students is care of Trades Hall, Victoria.

Locally, in my electorate of Boothby, students’ funds are being funnelled to party political campaigns. I have received a leaked memo which showed that the Union Board of Flinders University on Monday, 7 June last year resolved:

motion.para: That the Union, jointly with SAFU (Students Association of Flinders University), request SOC (Student Organisation Committee) use its small projects fund to contribute $8,000 to a cross campus 2004 Federal Election material fund with information on the importance of preferencing the Coalition last.

speech.para: That resolution was moved by a staff member of a South Australian Labor senator. When you can do things like that, when you have control of student funds, it takes the work out of fundraising. This shows that student unions have been captured by the Labor Party and they are not representative of the general student body which funds their activities.
Last year’s minutes of the National Union of Students SA executive show that they established a federal election committee, and the SA President, Ms Meagan Hackett said:

quote.para: I am asking each campus student union and /or association to donate money to this campaign, to ensure that education remains one of the most topical election issues …

speech.para: According to Ms Hackett:

quote.para: The Flinders University Union has so far committed $6000 while UniSA will donate between $3000-6000 as well.

speech.para: Committee members included representatives from all three universities.

I also have a copy of a letter which was sent out to voters in the seat of Hindmarsh from the National Union of Students. Far from making education topical, the direct mail campaign was directed against the Liberal candidate in Hindmarsh and urged voters: ‘Don’t let Simon Birmingham and John Howard take away our future.’

talk.start.para: —That’s what you’re doing. Very perceptive.
(Mr Baldwin)—The member for Grayndler will cease interjecting.
—Hindmarsh was won by 108 votes. Student funds diverted to the campaign may have made a difference in that seat.
Mr Albanese interjecting—
—He will respect the chair as well.

—Unions will have fewer resources for these sorts of activities under voluntary student unionism. But I have a sneaking feeling that, faced with a choice between counselling and paying money to the federal election campaign, student funds are still going to find their way into the federal election campaigns in 2007, in 2010, in 2013 and so on.

speech.para: Since the introduction of the tertiary education charge in 1986 and the introduction of HECS by the Hawke Labor government in 1988, student rallies have traditionally been against fees. The recent National Day of Action was the first student march I have ever seen which was in favour of fees. Not surprisingly, it was very poorly attended. The member for Casey talked of the University of New South Wales offering students funds to actually encourage people to bring along people to the march.

In George Orwell’s Animal Farm, the revolutionary call to arms for the animals was ‘Four legs good, two legs bad’. It seems that the message from recent student marches has been ‘Union fees good, HECS fees bad’. In other words, whether the fees are good ones or bad ones all depends on who receives them. A dollar from a student going towards their HECS fees is bad. A dollar from a student going towards their union fees is very good. This point is emphasised by the Senate Employment, Workplace Relations, Small Business and Education Committee’s report into the 1999 VSU legislation, which gave the bill a resounding recommendation. That committee suggested that opponents of voluntary student unionism then, as they are now, were guided by their vested interests in union administration and party affiliated student bodies.

Australia is a nation leading the world in developing a cultural environment free of discrimination. This freedom encompasses diversity on all grounds, including race, sex and colour. However, discrimination on one ground still exists within our education system—the compulsory nature of membership of a student union. Membership of any association should be the free choice of every individual—

talk.start.para: —Like the AMA.

—The Australian Medical Association is a voluntary association. Its has as its members about 50 per cent of medical practitioners. You would be much closer to the Doctors Reform Society of Australia. Membership of any association should be the free choice of any individual, but this is critical when the organisation is, by its very nature, political. Despite claims to the contrary, students have no option to conscientiously object to the activities of their student unions. They cannot withdraw. As it stands, all students are required to be members of their respective student unions on campus. For example, I know personally of a student who was threatened with disenrolment and forfeiture of his place in law for not paying his union fees. There is compulsion at the university level; there is compulsion at a national level. Each university is associated with the National Union of Students, and they pay a fee of $5 per student to the NUS for each enrolled student, regardless of whether they wish to join. This is the same NUS who spent $250,000 of student money in last year’s federal election campaign.

speech.para: One argument we often hear in favour of compulsion involves comparing a union fee to government taxation. I am sorry to break the news, but university unions are not a fourth level of government in Australia. Freedom of association is a fundamental right, one which is implicit in our Australian way of life and guaranteed to us under the Universal Declaration of Human Rights. The rest of the Australian community is bound by these logical and rational principles of freedom of association. In some areas, such as workplace relations, this House has itself legislated to enact such freedoms—for example, the 1996 Workplace Relations Act, which gave the idea of freedom of association the status of a basic human right in Australian law.

Another argument which supports voluntary membership relates to the activities of the unions. The forced contributions of students often go to blatantly political causes. Historically, the Australian Union of Students supported extremely divisive issues. In the 1970s, the AUS supported radical pro-Palestinian Liberation Organisation resolutions. They passed resolutions saying that marriage was a form of prostitution. They gave money to the Shining Path guerrilla movement in South America. We had compulsory student unionism but, led by people like the Treasurer and the health minister, campuses disaffiliated from the Australian Union of Students because they were so far removed from and so unrepresentative of the opinions of students. At a campus level, the problem is that these political escapades on issues which divide popular opinion are just not the domain of organisations whose members are not members of their own free will.

The successor of the Australian Union of Students, the National Union of Students, regularly engages in similar escapades, as the election return I have previously mentioned demonstrates. As an example, recently the National Union of Students spent compulsorily acquired student funds on protesting the government’s immigration policy at the Baxter detention centre, regardless of whether students agreed.

Individual student unions or guilds have been associated with protests that have left substantial damage bills, such as the $11,000-worth of damage inflicted on the Murdoch University Senate building. The president of that student guild, who was in his 12th year of study at the time, claimed that the protest was not organised by the guild, yet he conceded that both he and other guild members were present. This is not the type of behaviour which should be subsidised by students at large who have no choice about whether they pay for it.

In Victoria, as we have heard, the Melbourne University Student Union was wound up early last year. This happened under the compulsory unionism regime. After the VSU legislation comes into force from 1 January next year, if a university union fails because of mismanagement or some of the misadventures we have seen, we will be told: ‘It is all due to VSU.’ None of it will be due to the responsibility of the administration. But the Melbourne University Student Union was wound up after a student housing lease deal went bad, exposing the union to losses of up to $40 million. Several matters were referred to the police, and the liquidator recommended investigation into corporate governance issues such as falsification of records and conflicts of interest. Their financial records show expenses such as $213,000 on legal fees in 2002. Furthermore, in the Age of 26 July 2003, Darren Ray, the 2002 union president, admitted winning his election by ‘proving that the union paid for an axe used in a rampage by a minority of students who wrecked the office of the Vice-Chancellor.’ These are not the expenses that give value to students for their union fees.

Forced membership has created a culture of economic inefficiency. Voluntary student unionism will unleash powerful market forces on the student services sector, which will provide better, more efficient, greater value services to students at a lower cost. Currently, under the climate of coercion, students pay substantial up-front union fees of around $300 but up to $500 in New South Wales and receive no choice in the services provided to them. Quite obviously, different students place different demands on student services. Some students are heavy users of all facilities, while some students use few or none of the services on offer. Clearly, this cross-subsidy is inefficient. The end result is substantial overuse of many services, many of them subsidised out of students’ pockets. This is the classical free rider problem in economics. Free market forces are the key to efficiency, greater welfare and a more sensible allocation of available resources to students. A user-pays system will always be more efficient in the long run and will be more beneficial to students, despite the protests of those who gain the most from a system which compulsorily acquires fees and allocates benefits.

If a group of people wish to pool some resources to collectively partake of products and services then there should be no legislative proscription on this. Similarly, there should be no legislation which allows the compulsion of people to be such members. Historically the idea of a voluntary communal effort has worked quite well. Although largely forgotten, in the early 20th century friendly societies provided excellent service under this concept. People would of their own volition undertake to be a member of a friendly society, pay a fee and gain the benefits of communal products and services in certain areas. In Australia this was once well evidenced by friendly societies facilitating the delivery of medical and pharmaceutical services. They were the catalyst for networks of regional hospitals and friendly society pharmacies. The key difference is that it was voluntary. You opted to join; you had a choice. Importantly, only the people who derived value from such services were members. Those who did not wish to participate were never compelled to do so. That is very different from the situation with student unions today.

I would like to address the issue of sport. It is an issue close to my own heart. All of my family have had a big involvement in university sport—intervarsity and so on. Voluntary student unionism should not be an obstacle to playing sport. It should not be an obstacle to successful university games, successful intervarsity competitions or even Australia’s gold medal haul at the Olympic Games. There are really two issues here: participation and resources. Does Kevan Gosper really believe that our budding Olympians will only participate in university sport if they are compelled to do so? Does he really believe that these people who are so motivated that they will go all the way to the pinnacle of their sport need to be compelled to join their union and that otherwise they will spend university life sitting on the lawns drinking a milkshake? Come on! That is the East German, Soviet style model of mass participation. On the issue of resources, we need to remember that at many universities the sporting grounds are provided by the university, not by the union. Moreover, most university sporting clubs compete in competitions against non-university clubs whose only revenue is the funds they raise themselves.

The issue of child care is emotive. In my state of South Australia there are three university child-care centres. At the University of Adelaide over 58 per cent of all child-care places are used by staff. Only 16 per cent are used by students of the university. Why should the general student population subsidise child care for staff of the university? The Waite Campus Children’s Centre on the Urrbrae campus of the University of Adelaide in my electorate is situated at a facility that is primarily research based. As such, only a very small group of undergraduate students has ever used child care at this facility. In 2003 the University of Adelaide embarked on a misadventure of allocating child-care places to be managed by the student union. They actually lost the government benefits for these places, which was a disaster for students and showed why unions should not politicise child care.

Child care is an important issue. It should not be addressed through compulsory student unionism. We have allocated over $8 billion over the next four years for the child-care benefit and the Child Care Support Program. The government recognises child care as an important issue, and the suggestion that only university unions can have a real effect on the affordability, availability and quality of child care is preposterous. It is time to subject student unions to the same conditions under which individuals, small businesses and corporations in Australia have thrived—the strongest force for efficiency and best practice that the world has ever known, the dual concepts of freedom and choice. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I am extremely happy to oppose the Higher Education Support Amendment (Abolition of Compulsory Up-front Student Union Fees) Bill 2005. I am even happier to do so, having heard the first three speakers on the government side, and I am very pleased that it will be opposed at every stage of its passage by the Labor caucus. I had no idea just how precious the people on the other side of the House are. I did not realise that they spent all of their university education time fighting battles in student politics and apparently losing. According to them, those past defeats have to be put right, and every university in the country is going to feel it.

speech.para: They just do not get it. Universities are not there just to turn out units of production for the corporations they speak about so wisely. Universities are not there just to turn out Liberal politicians. Universities remain, and have to remain, the guardians of knowledge, the bastions of freedom of ideas and freedom of ideals. They have that purpose and they must retain it. This is just one piece of legislation in a suite of legislation that basically wants to diminish and undo the roles that universities have taken on, roles that Australians are rightly proud of. Our universities have been incubators of ideas and knowledge. We are not a huge country; we do not have great population size and we will never have market size or proximity to bigger markets. We have always had to compete on knowledge, on our cleverness, and unfortunately under the Howard government cleverness is something that is not nurtured. It is something the government want to diminish on all fronts, and I guess this bill is just another of those fronts.

This bill seeks to prohibit higher education providers from requiring students to join associations or to pay fees on enrolment that do not relate directly to their courses. In other words, universities cannot assist student organisations to collect those compulsory fees so that they can provide important services and amenities. Interestingly, not surprisingly, if those universities breach this legislation in any way they will be fined to the tune of $100 per student. Just imagine—and I am sure Lord Nelson imagines this all the time—if universities were to fail this ideological impost of his, the government would be able to rip out another $5 billion from university funding. That is some stick, but that is what is happening.

This government’s longstanding ideological obsession with student organisations over the past 25 years is well known. It rests on some ability to say that this is another form of political unionism. Antiunionism is something, but it is also anti-intellectualism of the worst kind. It opposes freedom of ideas and freedom of expression of ideals that run counter to its rather limited set of ideals and ideas, which are, of course, user pays, survival of the fittest and move delivery of every government service to its private sector mates.

This legislation is just another attempt to bully universities and students into this government’s miserable agenda. It has an appalling record in higher education. This is now the fourth attempt by this government to ban automatic membership of student organisations, having had its legislation knocked back in 1999, 2001 and 2003. But it keeps trying. This latest move comes in the wake of the government winning a majority in the Senate to take effect after July this year. Here we have a government drunk on power—pretty drunk this week, I would have thought, if the corridors of power are any guide—determined to flex those unchecked muscles by bullying universities and students into submission. It is working on its hit list. It is payback time. Look out Australia—students are first.

This government tries to hide its dogged pursuit of student organisations under the guise of this wonderful word ‘choice’—freedom of choice—arguing that universal membership of student organisations compromises freedom and civil liberties. It is an infringement, it says, of the freedom of association. Individual choice is an important part of democracy, but the whole plank of civilised society rests on a simple principle: individuals all contributing so that the whole may benefit. Democracy comes with responsibility for all. That is what student unionism implies. It says that you have a responsibility to help others. It is a pretty simple principle. Fortunately in Australia I think it is one most Australians are proud of.

But we have to move to a new way of thinking, apparently. The Liberal government’s thinking is: survival of the richest. It is some sort of new approach to Darwinian processes. I reckon it would make a good PhD topic, actually. It was the survival of the fittest. Now it is the survival of the offspring of the most wealthy—a new selection process put in place by the Howard government.

Silencing dissent is another goal. This legislation certainly is an attempt to silence student organisations, because they have been successful in highlighting the antistudent, antieducation and antiknowledge policies of the Howard government. Students dared to criticise the Howard government’s massive HECS hikes. No wonder. I despair when I think of when my daughter will be able to get around to having children. She has to pay that HECS debt back. She has to work, as she did throughout her studies as well. This bill is political retribution against student organisations that have opposed decisions made by the Howard government to cut billions of dollars from university funding, to double the HECS fees over the past eight years, to allow increases up to a further 25 per cent, which 30 universities, I think, have taken on, and to allow the student to staff ratio to increase by more than 30 per cent. These policies have allowed universities to enrol students paying $100,000 and up to $200,000 in some universities while students with better marks miss out on places and to slug students with bigger HECS debts, adding to the $11 billion of already-owed HECS debts. But the obsession goes on. It has been going on for a quarter of a century, so I guess we have to see it through.

Young Liberal students apparently could not get the numbers on campus, so they have asked their parliamentary mates now to force their will upon students. Current membership arrangements are not, as it is claimed by the Liberal Party, an infringement of the freedom of association. That has been tested by High Court cases and by the ACCC, but that is not good enough for the government.

This legislation, they think, will achieve a great deal. Fortunately the Group of Eight—the AVCC—similarly noted their disappointment that the minister and the government have chosen to ignore their strong support for a compulsory service fee. They argued that to introduce this new legislation on the premise that these fees represent the last bastion of compulsory unionism is akin to using an elephant to squash an ant. Students fees fund much more than a small number of elected representatives. Penalising universities that seek to levy a compulsory fee for health services, for example, will be a watershed in the history of higher education and may forever change the sense of campus community that has a long and proud tradition in this country.

I congratulate the universities. When they are under extreme pressure to deliver financial imperatives imposed by this government and to deliver an agenda that I know many of them find unpalatable they show some courage. I am pleased to say that those sentiments were endorsed recently by University of Newcastle Vice-Chancellor Professor Nick Saunders, who also stated on the public record that voluntary student unionism would result in a depletion of services and facilities for students on campus. Heaven help us at Newcastle University, because he knows our university cannot pick up the bill for those services.

Most people, with the exception apparently of those sitting opposite, understand that student organisations make a valuable contribution to university life and provide vital services and support. Those services include child care, free employment services, advocacy and welfare services, free legal advice, health services, interest-free loans, subsidised catering and facilities and also services that help students stay at university and finish their degrees.

But student associations do have a very important role, more so today because universities have changed under this government. We see higher student-staff ratios, more online courses, tutorials with over 100 students in them and lecturers being required to take on greater course loads and administrative duties, while still desperately trying to maintain their research presence and outcomes. Those things have had a big impact on universities. Student associations now take on more dispute resolution, conflict resolution, students who have to appeal against grades, failure of the university to perhaps recognise students’ special needs, harassment cases and intimidation claims. Those are the sorts of things that student unions also provide. I am proud that one of my daughters was president of a student union. I know what hard work she did. I also know that the work was very challenging. For her to represent students to the university council and university senior staff was very difficult. But that work has to be done, and those are some of the important services that student associations provide.

I have heard this government say, ‘Why should poorer students have to pay compulsory student fees?’ I am really sick of the reverse classism that those opposite use. This paternal benevolence and patronisation of lower income families really gets my blood boiling. The Minister for Education, Science and Training says ‘Why should boilermakers pay for the sons and daughters of lawyers to go to university?’ It is because they want their sons and daughters to go to university too. Get real! Our country has been built on each generation aiming higher and improving its outcomes through knowledge and training. I find the minister’s comment offensive in every way.

At the University of Newcastle there are many students who are the first in their family to go to university. It remains a university where the majority of students still come from families that have not had that experience. They need these services more. They rely very much on support from student organisations. It provides the orientation and support that these students—and, as the member for Boothby pointed out, the increasing number of overseas students who now attend universities—need.

Let me say something about those overseas students: the University of Newcastle would love to have more international students, but the reality is that it is very hard for international students. Many of them are also working. Some at the University of Newcastle are spending half of their day driving to and from Sydney to work and then trying to fit in their studies. It is a reality that it is harder for students in regional universities: the labour markets are thinner. Remember that over 50 per cent of students at universities like the University of Newcastle now are part-timers. Many are part-timers because they are out trying to work for a living and to pay their HECS fees. It is just an appalling situation.

But student organisations do create the vibrant campus life that makes universities the interesting and exciting places they should be. Student organisations are also part of making a university degree a fulfilling experience and a more holistic one, which, I really believe, turns out better young Australians. So, sorry, Minister, your unrelenting attacks on student organisations do threaten to change so much more than ‘the price of a sausage roll’. But we are not surprised you continue to patronise the Australian people and trivialise universities. I have not seen any aromatherapy or belly dancing courses lately, but apparently the Minister for Education, Science and Training has. He gets around, that’s for sure.

That brings me to regional universities. Regional universities really do know that student unions are part of the whole fabric of our community. The services that they provide are important to strengthening our community. In particular, we have heard about sporting facilities. Newcastle University Sport, NUSport, for example, was recently awarded the Newcastle City Council’s commitment to participation award for their contribution to sport in the whole Hunter region. I have taken representation from them that the delivery of their services to the university and to the region will be seriously compromised if this legislation passes. I do not think this government has much idea of just how universities are woven into regional economies. One result of this legislation will be rather savage cuts to student sports organisations. Scholarships will be cut, subsidies to sporting clubs that promote fitness and participation certainly will be cut and some facilities will be closed forever. Let us be realistic: student facilities provided for universities do benefit the whole region, as regions do not then have to provide all of them. It is a shared responsibility, and it is one that has worked very well.

The University of Newcastle is facing some financial problems. We are doing it tough. We have had $120 million in funding ripped out of our university since this government came to office, and we have had a period of direct assault on our university. The outcome, no matter what, is that 450 jobs will have to be shed. It is proposed that they be shed over one year. Why not do it over three years? We just do not have the money. It is time that the government took seriously the problems at the University of Newcastle and supported its call for some financial assistance that would allow it to phase in that restructure over three years and not over one year, thereby alleviating considerable pain to a regional economy.

The University of Newcastle is not alone in its struggle to survive financially. RMIT and the University of Western Sydney are also posting deficits. Yes, it is hard to suddenly change the whole culture to respond to financial accounting standards. Deputy Speaker Baldwin knows that there are some rather major government departments struggling at the moment to reach acceptable financial accounting standards. But the root cause of our problems is definitely a fall in government funding. The federal government used to contribute 90 per cent of university revenues 25 years ago. Now it contributes only 40 per cent. Such savage cuts to funding and subsequent cuts to staff numbers have had an enormous impact on the University of Newcastle.

At a community meeting in Newcastle last Saturday, 7 May, organised by students, it was resolved to put the following demands to the federal government: one, that the government does not pass voluntary student unionism legislation; two, that the government funding to tertiary public education be reinstated to the 1996 level so that excessive job and course cuts need not occur at the University of Newcastle; and, three, that the university’s regional status be reinstated. We have got a problem with regional status. We are not allowed to have it; apparently we are not entitled to it. Wollongong is, and we are pleased for Wollongong, but we are also desperate in our region to make sure that those community based and regional programs that enable students to have a second chance and gain access to university will be funded. We actually have the highest number of second chance programs in the country. We provide more of those opportunity programs. We also provide courses from New England across to the coast, up to Port Macquarie and down to the Central Coast; but, no, we are not regional apparently.

We have a proud history at the University of Newcastle, and it is one the House deserves to be reminded of. We are No. 9 on the research table. We are a university that has one of the best medical faculties in the country. We have some extremely wonderful and successful relationships with the community—Hunter Medical Research Institute; Newcastle Legal Centre; ResTech, a research and development partnership with Ampcontrol; Family Action Centre’s Engaging Fathers program—and the university’s Professor Graeme Jameson has now been made a laureate professor. He is one of the top 10 researchers in the world. We are a high-achieving university and we are proud of our students and staff. We are proud of their achievements now and we want that to continue.

That is why we oppose this legislation. At the heart of this is the real agenda of this government. This legislation is not just an attack on students and an attack on unionism or associations; it compounds the onslaught by this government on higher education. It is an onslaught that will be felt in my region very sorely with the loss of 450 jobs, with a spin-off of another 150 jobs. Five hundred jobs in a year? The university is going to be hit hard. Mr Deputy Speaker Baldwin, those people come from your electorate as well as my electorate. I ask you, on the record, to make sure that you ask the Prime Minister and the Minister for Education, Science and Training to look favourably on our regional economy, on our knowledge infrastructure and certainly on our university. This legislation is anti freedom of thought. It is an attack on ideas and ideals. It attempts to erase the dissenting voices of students, those critical minds and critical voices that we need. When I say critical they are critical of us here; they are critical of everyone and everything to some extent. That is part of the role of learning. Learning is about improving, understanding, testing and finding new ways. That is how the solutions to the problems of now and the problems of the future are found. I oppose this legislation. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —What a very interesting speech we have just heard from the member for Newcastle. She has come up with an answer that I do not think any survey in the world’s or in Australia’s history has ever come up with: students are only studying part time because they have to work part time to pay off their HECS fees. For a start, they would not be earning enough working part time to pay off HECS fees, so it is an amazing claim to make in the first place. In actual fact, they are probably working part time to pay off their compulsory student union fees—not their HECS fees. What an amazing claim made by the member for Newcastle, who is not staying around to hear the object of ridicule. The member for Newcastle seems to think that this argument is about attacking unions, or even attacking student associations, when it is nothing of the sort. The whole basis of this legislation is freedom of speech, freedom of action and freedom of association. The member for Newcastle, in her feeble rebuttal of these core rights, seems to think that students have a responsibility to compulsorily support each other, even if they cannot afford it. We know that many of them cannot afford those few hundred dollars that they need to pay for those compulsory student fees.

speech.para: I rise today to give my support to the Higher Education Support Amendment (Abolition of Compulsory Up-front Student Union Fees) Bill 2005. In seeking to amend the Higher Education Support Act, the government is looking to afford university students the same rights that they enjoy outside the university environment inside the university environment. These amendments will ensure that from 2006 students in Australia are not forced to become members of a student association or to pay fees for non-academic student services. Compulsory student unionism has been an issue of concern for the Liberal Party for some 25 years. The Labor Party will claim that this is just another bone for Liberal students and their supporters and that we are opposed to compulsory student unionism purely because of the word ‘union’. As I said before, it is not about unions or student associations; it is about compulsion. Just as we, on this side, do not like to see compulsory unionism out there in the normal work force, we do not like to see it inside universities either.

History and commonsense show this is not the case. The Liberal Party has been continually fighting for VSU—that is, voluntary student unionism—and will not stop fighting for it until we can guarantee students the freedoms enjoyed by the rest of Australian society. VSU first emerged as a policy of the Liberal government during Malcolm Fraser’s time as Prime Minister. Although it was not put to the House, it planted the seed and we have seen Liberals, Liberal students and the general student population across the nation lobbying for VSU ever since. Early in the first term of the Howard government, the coalition floated VSU legislation. It was hotly contested by the National Union of Students and the Labor Party, who were unable to see the benefits VSU would deliver to the student population. It was subsequently rejected by the upper house, to the dismay of many students and Liberals nationwide.

We are back here in 2005 fighting for VSU because we believe students are capable of making decisions for themselves. We are not opposed to compulsory student unionism because of the word ‘union’; we are opposed to it because of the word ‘compulsory’. Compulsory unionism in the workplace is all but gone. With the workplace relations amendments before the House this week, the underhanded, devious compulsory unionism we have been witnessing through the charging of bargaining agents fees to non-union members will also be a thing of the past. I had the pleasure to speak on that in the House yesterday.

However, apparently our higher education facilities—those institutions that house our future professionals, academics, tradespeople and leaders—believe that they should have the right to force free-thinking individuals to join a union. These institutions are where young Australians develop their moral, ethical and personal values systems. I ask: just what are we teaching them through compulsory student unionism? Those on the other side of the House will argue that we are trying to rid universities of unions, that we are trying to prevent students from having a voice at university. This could not be further from the truth. We have no problem with university unions. What we have a problem with is students being forced to join university unions. We want to give students a choice on whether or not they join a union.

University unions as they presently operate do not represent the student body at large. Student elections generally have a dismal voting turnout, which means that the student council represents a very small percentage of the student population. Further to this, there is very little consultation with the students—any action is usually the decision of the student council alone. In my opinion the lack of support shown for student elections is the student body speaking up. They are saying: ‘We don’t care about the student union. We consider it irrelevant to our studies and we consider it irrelevant to our daily lives.’ If the majority of students feel like this—and we know they do; just look at how many vote in the student elections—why should they be forced to pay a fee for representation that they do not need, want or use?
