And in the past these countries have had governments equivalent to those of the Australian Labor Party in this place.

We are giving people the opportunity to participate in the work force of this country and, when the immediate requirements of their preschool aged children have passed, we will encourage sole parent beneficiaries to look for work and will put them on newstart allowance. We have been generous about newstart allowance not just for sole parents but for all recipients of newstart allowance where we have made the taper rate operate in a way that retains more of people’s income.

These are positive measures. You would hardly imagine, listening to the member for Sydney, that this is a $3.6 billion package of expenditure—this is not a savings measure—designed to increase the work force participation of those who unfortunately are presently locked out of the economic life of this country. On top of that, not only does the opposition oppose giving these people and their children a better chance, looking at their capacity to work and doing something about them achieving their aspirations—that is what they were telling the Minister for Workforce Participation, me and all others in the coalition—but the opposition is opposed to the tax cuts in this budget.

In the time that I have been in this parliament I do not recall an opposition that has been so inept in its response to a budget. Where are the Leader of the Opposition, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition and the shadow Treasurer? Not only are they missing in action—we might see something of the Leader of the Opposition tonight—but, essentially, they are seeking to deny Australians billions of dollars worth of tax cuts. On one hand, they complain about the minimum wage and, on the other hand, they say they are going to block the tax cuts. How absolutely ridiculous a position is this for an Australian opposition? It would deliver obvious advantages and benefits to the men and women of Australia and their families. Why is the Labor Party so opposed to giving Australian workers and their families more money in their pockets? Why is it saying, ‘While we control the Senate in this place, we will vote against’—presumably with the assistance of minor parties—‘a benefit which would flow otherwise from 1 July to the families and workers of Australia’? The Australian Labor Party was once the great party of the workers of Australia. All one can conclude from this debate is that the party which once represented the workers of Australia has abandoned them. The friends of the workers of Australia are on this side of the House.

talk.start.para: —This budget shows how woefully out of touch this government is with the challenges and struggles of making ends meet for millions of Australians. Everyone in this House thinks that work is better than welfare. Everyone in this House believes that if it is possible for someone to work then they are better off than being on welfare. But where the opposition and the government differ, and differ bitterly, are over the means of achieving that outcome. The government have just discovered welfare to work disincentives. They have only just found out about them. They have only just accepted that what Labor has been arguing for years is right—this government must do something about welfare to work incentives—but in their implementation of that program they have shown their callousness and their disregard for the needs of millions of Australians.

speech.para: In this budget we see three things: first, a clear indication that this government is out of touch with the needs and challenges of people on a disability pension and a parenting payment; second, a continuation of their ideological obsession with punishing instead of helping people get back into the work force—we have seen that since this government came into office in 1996; and, third, a continuation of this government’s favourite tactic. This government loves the fact that people on a disability pension are being portrayed in the community as shirkers. Their favourite tactic is the dog whistle.

We have heard that the Treasurer’s favourite headline, out of all the headlines that have been written about this budget, is that of the Daily Telegraph on Tuesday: ‘Workers 1, Shirkers 0’. We saw the picture of the Treasurer reading that headline with a huge smile on his face—not untypically, with a huge smile on his face. Well, somebody has got to say it: not everybody on a disability pension is a shirker. Not every single parent is a shirker. It would have been better if one of the members of the government could have come into this House and said, ‘Hang on a minute, that’s not right; not everybody’s a shirker,’ but not one of them has said it. Not one of them has had the guts to come into this chamber and say, ‘There are people on the disability support pension and there are single parents who are not shirkers.’ In fact, the vast majority are not shirkers. They are people who have been dealt a hard blow in life and deserve this government’s support, but the government are happy to see them portrayed as bludgers and shirkers. That is a national disgrace.

We saw this in 1996: this government came into office and abolished a range of programs which helped people from welfare to work—Jobstart, the national training wage, New Work Opportunities, Landcare and Environment Action Plan and job skills. They slashed all those and what did they create? What did they replace them with? It was Work for the Dole. What did Work for the Dole contribute? There was no training and a worse result in getting people from welfare back into work, but it was an excellent result in portraying unemployed people as shirkers. This government is at it again with welfare to work policies which do not produce results but which do portray poor and disadvantaged people in the community as shirkers.

Let me turn to some of the practical ramifications of this year’s budget in relation to welfare. As the honourable member for Sydney said, from 1 July 2006, people applying for the parenting payment will receive the current entitlements until their child turns six. From then, they will receive a so-called enhanced newstart allowance, which will involve an obligation to work at least 15 hours a week. The taper rate for this enhanced allowance will be 60c in the dollar instead of 70c.

But what is the biggest obstacle for single parents wishing to transfer to work? The answer, of course, is child care, particularly out of school hours care. This government has announced 84,300 new out of school hours places. At first glance that sounds impressive, but the devil is in the detail. Firstly, the majority of these places will not come on line until 2008. Half the funding for these places is not available until 2008-09, but of course the welfare changes come into effect in 2006. So there is a very significant lag. I am not sure what the single parents who are transferring from welfare to work are meant to do for two years while these places are coming on line. That is just the nub of the problem. We already have a shortage of out of school hours places as it is. As we speak, there is a shortage of over 30,000 places across the country, so of those 80,000 new places more than 30,000 are going to be taken up just fulfilling the shortfall that is currently there. That is not taking into account all the people whom this government is trying to move from welfare to work and is not creating anywhere near enough child-care places.

I have seen this in my electorate. We have seen after school hours care centres close. Just last year we saw the Smithfield West after school hours centre threatened with closure. It was only through a community campaign and cooperation from the local council and other child-care providers that we were able to keep that open. Talking to the mothers and the fathers who relied on that centre for their after school hours care brought home to me just how important it was for parents, both in family situations with two parents and in those with single parents, and how much they rely on after school hours care. There is a national crisis in after school hours care and the government have done nothing about it. Even now, the places they are creating will go nowhere near meeting the new demand that they will be creating.

In addition, the government have made some quiet changes to the JET scheme for sole parents which will reduce the incentives for sole parents to move from welfare to work. So not only have they done nothing; they are actually making it worse. They have quietly introduced changes in this budget—they have not gone out and talked about them. They have changed the JET scheme to say that sole parents with disabled children should not be able to go into long-term training to get them back into the work force—a callous budget-cutting measure which goes against the grain. It goes against everything the government are meant to be achieving, against all their rhetoric, and yet they stay quiet about it.

I talked before about the enhanced newstart allowance and the taper rate of 60 per cent. They call it the enhanced newstart allowance—I am not sure where it is enhanced from. It is true that the taper rate for the normal newstart allowance is 70c in the dollar. But what is the taper rate for the parenting allowance? The taper rate for the parenting allowance, up to $146 a fortnight, is 40c. So, by moving people from the parenting allowance onto the newstart allowance, they are again reducing the incentives from welfare to work, again going against the grain of all their rhetoric and their promises. Again we see the devil in the detail.

What support is the government providing to people on the disability pension to transfer from welfare to work? In fairness, as the member for Sydney has outlined, there are some vocational training places, but again they are sadly inadequate. There are not many—600,000 parents have to fight with 65,000 mature age unemployed for just 12,300 vocational training places.

This is not a proper plan to help people off the disability support pension. It is a way, however, to transfer people from one form of welfare to another. If a disabled person is classified as being able to work 15 hours a week then they will be moved to Newstart. This means that a disabled person will be $77 a fortnight worse off, even if they are doing everything they can to find a job—even if they are applying for every job they can think of, even if they are struggling in their wheelchairs with public transport to get to job interviews, even if they are doing whatever is possible to get a job.

talk.start.para: —Shame!

—‘Shame!’ is right. This is a very sad result indeed. We must do more to help people on the disability support pension back into work, not just punish them. The Prime Minister showed a sad lack of understanding in question time. More in pity than in anger I say: a sad lack of understanding of the needs of people on the disability support pension. The Brotherhood of St Laurence has said:

quote.para: The Treasurer said that welfare to work changes are meant to encourage unemployed people and part-time workers but they are only penalising people and acting as another disincentive to work.

speech.para: The Prime Minister said the other day that this government was an enlarging government. It is not; it is a punishing government. It is not interested in enlarging the lives of people on disability pensions and sole parents who are struggling and trying to get back into work. If it was, it would be doing something for the current disability pension recipients. It would be creating incentives for them. It would be giving them support to get back into the workplace. But those people, as the Prime Minister said, are grandfathered. There is no support for them, no encouragement for them and no training places for them. They are left out in the cold.

We have an obligation as a parliament, as a government and as a society to look after those who have been dealt a hard blow in life. We have to extend a hand to them and help them back into the work force—not punish or penalise them for the circumstances they find themselves in. This is a punishing budget from a punishing government. It should hang its head in shame for this outrageous budget. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —It is a pleasure to talk on this matter of public importance in the House today following the excellent budget delivered by the Treasurer on Tuesday night. I would like to quote Winston Churchill, who said, ‘We make a living by what we get, but we make a life by what we give.’ I think that statement underpins the philosophical differences that we are seeing come through this debate on both sides of the House. ‘We make a living by what we get, but we make a life by what we give.’ The opposition are concerned only with what people need, from their point of view, to get—what handouts, what entitlements, what benefits and what welfare. But on this side of the House we are asking people: ‘What can you contribute? How can you make a life by what you give and in so doing find happiness?’ That is an important philosophical difference that we have really seen come through clearly in this MPI.

speech.para: The first speaker wove the usual web of nonsense and inconsistencies—I am not allowed to call them lies. The second speaker continued with the same sort of rhetoric, putting words in our mouths—‘shirkers’, ‘bludgers’, ‘struggling in wheelchairs to get interviews’, ‘a punishing government’. These are not words that the government use. Do not put words in our mouths. How can this be a punishing government when we are spending $3.6 billion with these measures? And we are spending for the next eight years to encourage training and opportunities to move people into a real place in the real economy.

This centrepiece of the budget attacks the very real problem of intergenerational welfare. I want to explain where the need comes from, because obviously members opposite have not worked it out. The proportion of working age Australians receiving income support payments has risen from one in 20 in 1974 to one in five today. In June 2004 there were some 2.7 million income support recipients aged between 16 and 64—over 20 per cent of all working age Australians, most of whom rely on income support for the majority of their incomes. We are talking about a group of people affected by intergenerational welfare whose long-term life chances are being lost to them.

As the Prime Minister said in question time, it is in the interests of this government that we look after the interests of the working men and women in this country. As Minister Andrews, who spoke earlier, said: we must give people the opportunity to participate in the working life of this country. Welfare is a safety net, a very good safety net, but it is not a way of life and nor should anyone see it as that. It is better to be on work than on welfare, and we need to encourage the transition from welfare to work.

Again let me highlight where the need comes from with a couple of figures from the recent past. The number of Australian families with children under the age of 15 who had no parent in work increased from 280,000 in 1986 to 390,000 in 1997. About three-quarters of the parents in these families were not in the labour force. Among the quarter who were unemployed, perhaps 40 per cent had been unemployed for more than one year. But what we see now is that around 690,000 children live in households where no parent works. I think that is one in five or one in seven Australian kids growing up in a household where no parent works. There has been a substantial increase in the extent of income support dependence and worklessness in this country.

At an OECD conference in 1996 Professor Esping-Andersen said, ‘We face a crisis of polarisation if the losers of today are losers for life, and if they pass their underprivilege on to the next generation.’ I do not think this government wants to stand by and see underprivilege being passed on from one generation to the next. This is about finding opportunities for young people to have a ‘real place in the real economy’—I think I am quoting Noel Pearson when I say that.

If we look at the American experience we see that growing up poor increased the probability of long-term poverty in adulthood by three times for poor blacks and eight times for poor whites. The daughters of welfare recipients were more than twice as likely to receive welfare themselves than the daughters of nonrecipients. The member for Sydney should take note of that point. In Australia we have not yet completed similar longitudinal studies, but there is evidence that the experience is comparable. The lowest participation rates were found among young people from families with no parental employment, and that should come as no surprise. We must support parents who have the greatest responsibility of all—to care for, provide for and nurture their children.

I have got into the habit of checking from time to time the web site of the Australian Greens. Prior to the last election it was with great concern that I realised that people who held these views managed to put them on the national agenda in this country. It is with a sense of relief that I have now realised they will not be able to do that after 1 July. I want to touch on the Australian Greens, and I hope none of their ideas find their way into this debate. They have an idea that we should have a universal guaranteed adequate income scheme with the following characteristics: everyone gets a particular amount of money, no-one has to pass an activity test and no-one pays tax under a certain level. Everyone is somehow supposed to find an adequate wage in that scheme.

I am really pleased that after 1 July this year we will have an opportunity to do what has not been legislatively possible over the last nine years. I think what has come through today is that Labor is scaring the public with this nonsense about parents being forced to work. It is all very well to stand here and trot out the rhetoric, as the member for Sydney has done, about mums having to go back to work and not being able to be at home after school. I share that concern with her. My mum was not there when I got home from school either, but she certainly demonstrated to me a model in which you work hard, get where you want to in life and try your best. It is something that women in this place should all understand.

The member for Sydney gave the example of a constituent who sent her a fax in which she said she is going to be forced to go to work and will not be home when her children come home from school. What the member for Sydney should do is inform her constituent of the facts, which is that if she is currently receiving sole parent pension she will be asked when her youngest child turns six to look for 15 hours work a week, which is about three hours a day. I am confident that, should she be able to do that, she will be able to be at home at least some of the time when her children get home from school. It is the responsibility of the opposition to educate their constituents. This is a new and important measure and it matters a great deal to the future of this country. So, please, give them the facts. I say to those who are reading about this debate and trying to get to grips with it that they should contact members of the government and we will give you the facts so that you can understand how it will affect you.
I want to touch on some of the remarks that members opposite have made on this subject. This welfare to work measure hinges around mutual obligation. Senator Penny Wong said:

quote.para: Mutual obligation is the touchstone of Labor’s approach to increasing work force participation. … It is our view that government should be doing everything possible to help unemployed people who are reasonably able to work to find work. That is obviously a situation where everyone wins. It is good for the individuals concerned, it is good for the community …

speech.para: The subject matter of the MPI today is that we are not doing the real work. We have not heard from the opposition what their ideas on this are, but we do know that they support mutual obligation. The Leader of the Opposition has said:

quote.para: Labor supports mutual obligation where people are capable of working; and the government provides them with the opportunities they need to find and keep work.

speech.para: He has also said:

quote.para: To increase work force participation, our tax and welfare systems also need to provide greater incentive and reward for effort.

speech.para: The member for Lilley has said:

quote.para: What this country needs is … real reform which puts incentive into the system …

speech.para: So where is the real reform? I guess we will have to wait until tonight to hear what is said, but I hope what we hear in the opposition leader’s budget reply tonight centres on the facts and does not use this ridiculous rhetoric that we have heard today. On welfare to work in general, the member for Lilley has said:

quote.para: Labor recognises that encouraging people to move from welfare to work is a policy objective in its own right and one of the most important we can have. We want fewer people on welfare and more people in work.

speech.para: We could not have put it any better ourselves. The Minister for Family and Community Services, Kay Patterson, has responded to the further scaremongering about child-care places by the member for Sydney this morning. I encourage the member for Sydney to catch up on those few facts as well and, importantly, to understand that the number of long day care places is uncapped and is constantly increasing. Since 1996 the number of places has increased from 168,000 to over 229,000. The member for Sydney falsely assumes that no formal care is available for parents employed in shiftwork when in fact family day care very much has those options. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: (Hon. IR Causley)—Order! The discussion is now concluded.

debateinfo.title: HIGHER EDUCATION SUPPORT AMENDMENT (ABOLITION OF COMPULSORY UP-FRONT STUDENT UNION FEES) BILL 2005

talk.start.para: —I am pleased to be able to make a contribution to this debate on the Higher Education Support Amendment (Abolition of Compulsory Up-front Student Union Fees) Bill 2005. This bill is the last of those implementing the government’s Backing Australia’s Future package. It is quizzically named Backing Australia’s Future, because it is far from doing that. Instead, it is yet another attack by the Howard government on the ability of Australians to access education. The bill’s purpose is to prevent higher education providers from requiring students to join student associations. In other words, students will not have to pay fees to assist their student association when they enrol in their courses.

speech.para: The government claims that this is necessary to ensure freedom of association. However, it is clear to us that the real intent of this legislation is to knock out another voice that opposes government policies. Freedom of choice, speech or association is the last thing the Howard government wants in our higher education system. In effect, this bill not only attacks students but also attacks universities. It is not only students who say that they need student associations; the universities themselves have told the government that these institutions are needed on campus.

Under the preposterous guise of freedom of association, the government is using this bill to destroy students’ services, students’ rights and students’ support networks. The bill is the latest in a series of measures the government has put forward to damage the higher education system and distort it into one based on privilege over merit. The Backing Australia’s Future package has seen a rise in the HECS fees charged by universities of up to 25 per cent from 2005 and has paved the way for full fee-paying domestic students where privilege rather than merit will guarantee a university place. The government has made universities harder to get into and too expensive for many Australians to access. Now it will also seek to abolish the remaining vestiges of student support on campus.

All of this has been done in an attempt to silence student criticism of the terrible mismanagement of education policy we have experienced under this government. This is political payback of the cheapest and lowest kind. We already know that existing provisions allow students to opt out of associations, but this bill will prevent higher education providers from collecting fees for student associations. The Trade Practices Act 1974 contains provisions that ensure a student’s rights to freedom of association should they object to joining a student association. This right has already been tested by the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission. This bill is unnecessary in achieving the government’s supposed goal of freedom of association. That right already exists.

The real intention behind this bill is ideological. In 1997 we saw the Howard government rip into unions with masked guards, military recruits and dogs on the docks. We are going to get another round of that after 1 July. Now it is happening again through this witch-hunt against student representation. This is all a vain effort to silence any opposition and criticism of the Howard government’s changes to education policy. The government is punishing all those who dare to speak out. So one-eyed is the government’s dogged pursuit of unionism that it is willing to destroy student associations, which more closely resemble service and welfare support organisations than unions. To their credit, students have long been involved in the political process and political activity. They have been effective critics of governments for decades. The previous governments of which I was a member, the Hawke and Keating governments, were confronted by student opposition often—just as John Howard’s successive governments have been.

In the face of reforms pushed by the Minister for Education, Science and Training, reforms which strip the ability of ordinary Australians to access education on academic merit rather than on their financial position, students have to put up a fight. It is clear to me that this bill is political retribution and is a means of neutralising public comment on the government’s education policies. If this bill becomes law, students will have paid a heavy price for standing up for themselves and standing up for others. They will have lost important support that many rely on at one time or another in their studies.

So determined is the coalition to gag students while creating a privilege based education system that it has even managed to write a flaw into the bill—the catch-all prohibition of any fee that does not relate directly to the course. Let us consider the consequences of that. It will prevent universities from gathering student association fees. It will also prevent them from collecting parking fines, library fines or accommodation charges at halls of residence. Of course, none of these are directly related to university education courses. Surely even this government must recognise that this bill will result in a massive erosion of the facilities and capacities on university campuses. The government seems willing to let universities crumble and decay. That is the ultimate impact of this exercise.

A cost saving it will not be. It will be a penalty on all Australian students at all Australian universities, whether or not they are the sandstone universities or the newer regional universities like the Charles Darwin University in my own territory, the Northern Territory. Of course, that is a very young university and can ill afford the cuts in services which will automatically flow from the government’s decision to prevent the university from raising the student association fees.

The government may not see the value in student associations but, on this side of the House, their role in the universities is clear. It is worth while looking at some of the functions that are carried out by a small regional university like ours in the Northern Territory. University associations administer sports associations and sports facilities. I was a member of the student association here at ANU when I was a student and was on the sports council. We had the responsibility of administering and managing all the sports resources of the university. That included the gymnasium, the grounds and all of the things that the students were using as part of the union fees in the sports arena. All of these will now be threatened. The reduced capacity of student associations to provide comprehensive services as a result of this measure will mean that many of the clubs and societies which are currently run at universities and financed through the student associations will no longer continue.

Charles Darwin University has a gymnasium and various sporting clubs: athletics, soccer, the various football codes, badminton, basketball, netball, cricket, triathlon, hockey, ju-jitsu, karate, sailing, TaeKwonDo, Ultimate Frisbee, volleyball, water polo and capoeira. In the students union they have special interest groups: the Social Workers Club, the Indigenous Students Association, the Engineers Club, the Maths Club, the Psychology Students Association, the Law Students Association, the IT Club, the Labor Club and—dare I say it—the Liberal Club, the Baha’i Society, the Fellowship of Christian University Students and the Japanese Animation Club. There is a students’ rights advocate, who is funded through the students union. The function of this position includes advising of rights under the CDU student charter, helping students deal with issues with their faculty, failed grades, exclusion, disciplinary hearings and special consideration, helping international students with study visa and liaison with the department of immigration, support for mature age students, other advocacy and assistance with external bodies, including assistance with youth allowance, Austudy and Abstudy, accommodation assistance, employment assistance, participation in annual events such as Orientation Week for both VET and university students, Troppo Week at the commencement of second semester, Youth Week, Indigenous Day, International Day, Harmony Day, Darwin Pride Week, Charity Pancake Day, the National Campus Band Competition, the National Tertiary Art Prize, the Movie Club and Deck Chair Cinema, cocktail parties, ‘big barbies’ and even a pub crawl, and the Litchfield Day Trip.

It may sound trite, but these are all essential activities on the university campus. Yet the government seems to think that, somehow or other, these things will continue once it removes the right of universities to charge students association fees. Most of the sandstone universities will have built up significant reserves and their capital costs would have been sunk many years ago, but the smaller universities do not have those luxuries. Since 1996, when the Howard government first appeared here in the parliament, the government has removed $6 million a year in recurrent funding from Charles Darwin University alone—$60 million over 10 years. Last year, this government raised HECS charges by 25 per cent and opened the door for ‘buy your future’ $200,000 university degrees. Now students pay GST on books.

Universities like Charles Darwin cannot suffer long the penalties which have been imposed upon it by the Howard government. The successive charges which have been placed upon that university because of underfunding by the Commonwealth are causing that university distress in the way it is able to fund courses and provide student services. And now we have another shot. Under the process the government has put in place we will see the capacity of the university to provide for the student associations and the activities of the student union—which I have just outlined—severely undermined. The involvement of the university students in the community of Darwin will be handicapped. I do not believe this measure is something many Australians will support. It compounds, in my view, the cynical approach of the Howard government—attacking the rights of universities to raise these charges when it knows that the universities themselves oppose the measure. Professor Di Yerbury, President of the Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee, on 16 March stated:

quote.para: The Australian Vice-Chancellors’ Committee rejects the government’s underlying premise that students are forced to be members of student organisations. Students already have the option not to be members.

speech.para: I made this point clear just moments ago. She continues:

quote.para: It is a bit like council rates—not everybody uses all the services, but rates in a community are compulsory.

speech.para: I do not think that is a bad analogy—it is a very good analogy, in fact. That is how these charges should be seen. Professor Yerbury continues:

quote.para: We see this legislation as somewhat heavy-handed.

speech.para: John Mullarvey, the chief executive of the Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee, said on 17 March:

quote.para: International students view education in Australia as a holistic experience—an education combined with an invaluable life experience underpinned by the students services offered on campus, such as general support and pastoral care, as well as social and sporting activities ...

speech.para: I am certain that domestic students should share this view of their time at university. It demonstrates clearly that a comprehensive involvement at the level of higher education means that you should be able to access these services. But that will be threatened and undermined if the government has its way.

I mentioned earlier the role of student sports associations. We know that a number of prominent Australians placed advertisements in the major daily newspapers on 19 April this year expressing concern that the introduction of this anti-student organisation legislation would destroy sporting activities at universities, which have encouraged and developed many athletes at the elite level. Among the signatories were Ric Charlesworth, a former member of this place who was a Sheffield Shield cricketer, an Australian representative hockey player and the coach of the great gold medal winning Australian women’s hockey team; Shane Gould MBE; John Boultbee; Ric Charlton; David Clarke; John Coates; David Coe; Kim Beazley; Bruce Collins QC; Peter Crittle, a great rugby player; Phil Crowe; Roger Davis; Rob de Castella; Gary Flowers; David Gallop; Phil Harry; Richard Lee—and the list goes on. These are not people of want who just go out and pay for an advertisement of this type simply because they want the exercise or because they want to participate in this sort of activity. It shows their real concern about the impact of this legislation upon the ability of universities to provide the full range of services to their students. Importantly, these people understand, as I do from my own experience at university, the value of the sports services that are provided by university campuses and the fact that they are a very strong training ground for sportsmen and women who go on to earn higher honours as Australian representatives.

It seems to me that we are throwing out the baby with the bathwater here. This is such a short-sighted thing the government is doing. It is penalising good, young Australians for going to university. It has penalised them already by the enormous increase of 25 per cent in HECS charges. Now it is saying to them: ‘We don’t believe that these services are essential to your education.’ I say they are. And I say that it is in the national interest to ensure these services are provided at universities.

Of course the Commonwealth government will not tip into the till to cover the losses that will be incurred as a result of this legislation. There will be no additional finance coming from the government to help these university activities—no way. But it is all about ideology. It is all about the government’s abhorrence of students having a voice. I am reminded of Kent Rowe, President of the Charles Darwin University student union. In a statement he made on 16 March this year he said:

quote.para: The Howard government is irritated by informed organised criticism of his anti-student policies by student organisations, so now he wants us to shut up. The legislation his government introduced in parliament today is designed to do just that. What kind of government bans students from making organised political comment?

speech.para: He gives three examples:

quote.para: Soeharto, Indonesia 1978. Deng Xioping, China 1989—

speech.para: we all remember that—

quote.para: and John Howard, Australia 2005

speech.para: By contrast, universities in virtually every country in the OECD including the United States, Canada, the United Kingdom and New Zealand charge compulsory fees to support student services at universities. Australia will be the exception if this proposed legislation is passed. Some governments just hate informed, organised opposition, and John Howard’s government is one of those.

I do not believe that Australians will be able to hold their heads up with any great pride as a result of this legislation. They will, like me, be very concerned about its impact upon campuses across this nation. They will, like me, be concerned about the ability of students to provide services for themselves and their colleagues. They will, like me, be concerned about the ability of student associations to actively promote and advocate students rights. They will, like me, be concerned about the impact this will have on the ability of student associations, and student bodies generally, to be actively involved politically. I am most concerned about this and believe that it will be a day of great shame if and when this legislation becomes law. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I welcome the opportunity to speak on the Higher Education Support Amendment (Abolition of Compulsory Up-front Student Union Fees) Bill 2005. Like the bill debated yesterday on bargaining agents’ fees, it goes to the heart of values in Australian society: freedom of choice and freedom of association. Before I go on with what I had planned to say, I want to go back to something that the member for Lingiari alerted the House to—that is, his time at the ANU. He was a member of the student union. He remembered with fondness the services that were delivered by that student union body and where the money was going. I was at the same university. In fact, if I look at the age range of both of us, I think our time may have overlapped slightly towards the end of the member for Lingiari’s time and the start of mine. I remember the absolute outrage from the students on the campus about where that money was going. I remember the protests that took place when we found out that the money during those days was going to support terrorist organisations overseas. It could very well be that money was going to services within the university, but it was also going to questionable organisations overseas.

speech.para: If the member for Lingiari was part of the student body that made the decision to send money to those overseas terrorist organisations based in Libya, then he should hang his head in shame for the part that he played, because it certainly did not receive the support of the student organisation when I was there during the early to mid-seventies.

This bill is about freedom of choice. It is about freedom of association. What makes these fundamental freedoms all the more relevant in this case is the fact that they relate to the very people we are currently training as the future leaders of our society. At present, freedom of choice and freedom of association do not apply to membership of student organisations or the payment of compulsory general service fees at universities. This situation is simply unacceptable and it keeps the higher education sector out of line with the general community. As mentioned, the Howard government has breathed much needed life into the industrial relations sector by introducing freedom of choice and association through our workplace relations reforms.

This bill seeks to introduce these freedoms to students in the higher education sector. Why shouldn’t students enjoy the right to choose something that now exists in most workplaces across Australia? The union movement only represents 17 per cent of the Australian private sector work force, and membership is falling. Why is it falling? Because people do not understand and do not accept the value of what the union movement purports to give them. The same applies on campuses. Workers refrain from formally contributing their voice to a union; the situation is mirrored in Australia’s universities, where a pitifully low voter turnout to student elections reflects a high level of apathy amongst students towards their unions.

Before the pros and cons of voluntary student unionism can be effectively debated, one point needs to be made: student unions, guilds and associations are not industrial unions. I accept that. But, unlike in industry, students are not engaged in employment with the university and, hence, do not derive an income from their role at the institution. Student unions are formed to represent students at the various administrative bodies of the university and to provide student services. Additionally, student unions manage their associations and the windfall that they receive straight from the pockets of students.

Higher education funding reform has been a highly topical issue in this chamber over recent years. To our universities, the Backing Australia’s Future reforms are a sensible response by the government to the cause of greater financial liquidity for students. The reforms recognise that Australia’s universities need greater and quicker access to funds if they are to continually develop into world-class education centres. Prior to the reforms of December 2003, universities were limited to the terms and finances of the Higher Education Contribution Scheme. The same cannot be said of our student unions across Australia. Compulsory student union fees are up-front payments collected prior to the commencement of an academic semester. In most cases, the fees are collected by the university under the guise of a general service fee or student association fee. The majority is then directed straight into the coffers of the student union.

The most unfair aspects of these fees are the conditions that payment or, in some cases, nonpayment entails. The compulsory nature of the fees ties into student access to vital university services such as libraries, computer laboratories, the internet and other online services. There is no one standard model for student unions and associations in Australian universities. Essentially, a student organisation is in place to be representative of the student and reflective of their needs. In some cases, the representative role and the wider student union role are clearly divided. It needs to be made clear that this bill is not designed to belittle the need for student based organisations. In most cases, student unions and associations offer important student welfare services in areas such as careers and housing assistance, employment services, medical facilities, counselling and advocacy. Additionally, these associations control commercial student facilities on campus and coordinate clubs, societies and student media.

However—and this is where we differ—students can choose whether to utilise most of these services during their time at university. The same cannot be said about paying quite a large sum of money to access those services. To illustrate the point, I draw the attention of the House to Deakin University, located on Burwood Highway, just outside my electorate. It is a very good university with a growing reputation for its academic standards. During recent years, Deakin University has charged a general service fee in excess of $250 for full-time undergraduates. As with most institutions, the major beneficiary of these fees was the student association—in this case, Deakin University Student Association, or DUSA. Despite the obvious financial potency of DUSA, the organisation’s annual student elections generated a meagre voter turnout and a low level of interest from students for office-bearing positions. Of the 90 DUSA positions on offer across the university’s three campuses, a staggering 27 remained vacant after the 2005 campus elections.

This is hardly a healthy representative democracy at work. The problems evident in this are a lack of an accountable structure for the association’s funding and a clear lack of incentive to increase the level of student representation. Accurate voter turnout figures for student elections are hard to locate. However, I have heard informally that as few as 600 students out of the tens of thousands attending Deakin actually voted in the DUSA elections.

I am not using this opportunity to criticise DUSA’s services or Deakin University generally; many of my constituents, staff and, notably, community volunteers within my electorate received their education at Deakin. But it has been drawn to my attention that the compulsory up-front, no-questions-asked method of fee collection can really put a strain on students. In their wisdom, many academics at Deakin University recommend that full-time students work no more than 15 hours per week when supporting their studies. For the average full-time student working 15 hours or less per week, up-front fees totalling $240 can create a real problem—even more so when they perceive they are getting no value from that fee.

Abolishing the compulsory component of student union fees is one of the things that has been hotly debated in this parliament since 1999. This has had real relevance for tertiary students within my electorate as it complemented legislation passed by the Victorian Kennett government in June 1994. The Victorian legislation at that time had given the Victorian education minister power to specify which student services could require a mandatory fee. In this case state legislation created a window of accountability for student union fees. Sadly, however, this legislation was amended by the Bracks Labor government in 2000. The amendment removed the list of allowable student services, paving the way for student fees to be used for publications and often extremist political activities.

The Bracks government demonstrated the time-honoured Labor tradition of placing the concerns of the union movement, which controls its purse strings, ahead of the interests of the students. Premier Bracks, himself a former student union president in the early 1980s of what is now the University of Ballarat, is part of this attempt to wind back those needed improvements in union representation and fees introduced by the Kennett government. Interestingly, the total take-up in compulsory fees at the University of Ballarat in 2005 will be approximately $1.14 million. Like many of his Labor contemporaries, the Victorian Premier’s political upbringing was peppered no doubt by socialist undertones of obligatory economic distribution.

talk.start.para: Mr Burke interjecting—

—I am glad you are amused by that. Many of the members opposite may argue that the intention of this legislation to increase student fee transparencies is ideologically driven. I would like to argue that the Labor Party’s opposition to such moves is done in collaboration with the vested interests of the student union movement and against the interests of the students in general. Therefore, I ask the members opposite: how do you justify forcing students to pay up-front fees? This question was put before the parliament in 1999, when we debated the Higher Education Legislation Amendment Bill. That debate generated some memorable cynicism from the opposition. I recall at the time a cynical comment by the member for Wills, who stated:

quote.para: For the Liberal side of politics, voluntary student unionism is a combination of an ideological wet dream and political payback.

speech.para: Only the member for Wills can use that kind of expression. However, this argument is questionable when, while calling for an abandonment of the legislation, he acknowledged that a responsible government should ‘allow students to decide for themselves what they want from their student organisations’. That is exactly right. Surely it stands to reason that offering some choice in the payment to, and participation in, the student union is a key tenet in giving students such an opportunity. Abolishing student fees pulls the rug of complacency out from under student organisations—organisations that fail to effectively represent students; organisations that fail to target their efforts towards assisting students and instead promote political agendas that are out of touch with the overwhelming majority.

Voluntary student unionism has generated its own sense of history in this House in recent times. Throughout Australia the pros and cons of the issue have been largely debated. A key comparison is often drawn between the Victorian model, which I previously mentioned, and the Western Australian model of the same period. Under the Victorian model, the university could prescribe a list of conditions for which a general service fee could be used. However, the changes did not include voluntary payment of fees. When VSU was introduced into Western Australia, the changes were far more pertinent. The detractors claimed that the effects of VSU reduced student services.

What actually occurred was a shift towards a more targeted form of service delivery. I had an opportunity at the time to see that service delivery and the effect of the VSU legislation in Western Australia when I visited the Edith Cowan University campus in Perth. Sadly, the re-election of a Labor government in Western Australia denied the chance for the voluntary system to have a long-term effect. We have seen two attempts by state governments to introduce VSU and, on their losing office, the Labor governments reversed those attempts.

Yesterday, this House debated the merits of indirect fees for employees when enterprise bargaining agreements take place—and I participated in that debate. The key ethos of that debate was the immorality of charging an indirect fee to people who choose not to be a member of a student union. While we cannot directly associate workplace relations with students, the same principle of choice should apply to student associations.

Earlier in this debate, members on this side of the House highlighted the recent track record of the financial mismanagement within the University of Melbourne student union, or MUSU as it is often known. The liquidation of this once all-powerful organisation more than anything highlights the need for a greater level of accountability within these associations. It became evident towards the end of 2003 that the union had become embroiled in questionable property deals with a little-known development firm. Unbeknown to students at the time, MUSU had made arrangements to pay tens of millions of dollars to the firm to invest in apartments. A very significant fact in this alleged scandal is that many involved were heavily aligned with the right of the ALP.

One should not imply that the mismanagement resulted solely from political affiliation. It is very evident, however, that the alleged kingpin of this scandal is ALP figure Andrew Landeryou. He has now returned from hiding overseas to face trial. The courts have recently heard that Mr Landeryou was behind at least two controversial leasing deals struck between the union and private companies in the year before the union collapsed. He will face court and no doubt the processes of the judicial system will take place.

talk.start.para: (Hon. IR Causley)—Did the member for Deakin mention that the matter was before the courts? If you did, it is sub judice and you should withdraw it.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I am not sure but to be on the safe side I will withdraw it, just to make sure that we cover ourselves.
—I thank the member for Deakin.

—A truly democratic, voluntary system will continue to permit and encourage politically active students from across the spectrum to run for office. The added accountability of having to encourage students to join will add to the role. If a student association offers good value for money services, it will attract members. It is imperative that student union executives work to effectively manage their finances. Under the current system, the compulsory fees do not provide an additional incentive for the University of Melbourne student union to effectively manage their estimated total take from students of $10.6 million in 2005.

speech.para: It is important to highlight the need for this bill. Our universities are full of hard-working students. Many students turn up on campus to attend classes, use the academic facilities and focus on their studies. It is simply unfair that every student should be forced to pay for many services that they choose not to use. In Victoria this year over $51.54 million in compulsory fees will feed the coffers of the various student organisations. While this is not a bad thing in itself, provided that each student utilises the pool of services, we cannot be sure that this will be the case. More importantly, there is the compulsion side of it, rather than making it voluntary.

Let us run through some of the funding for the various universities in Victoria and what they will be receiving from compulsory student union fees: Deakin University—just on the outside of my electorate—$4.28 million; La Trobe University, $5.87 million; Monash University, $13.4 million; Royal Melbourne Institute of Technology, $11.2 million; the University of Melbourne, $10 million; the University of Ballarat, $1.14 million; the Victoria University of Technology, $3.16 million. These are large sums of money.

At the end of the day, this bill is about making sure that we protect students from the practices of student union bodies who have had their skill level and experience to manage the money effectively questioned. It is also about the fundamental freedoms that all of us in this place often talk about and this time have an opportunity to uphold: freedom of association and freedom of choice. That is what this bill is about. I commend the bill to the House.

talk.start.para: —I rise this afternoon to speak against the Higher Education Support Amendment (Abolition of Compulsory Up-front Student Union Fees) Bill 2005. The Howard government and the Liberal Party have always been opposed to student unionism and student activism. In fact, given the changes this government have brought in recently to higher education, we on this side of the House say the government are plainly against students. The bill arises from a determination by this government to thwart anything associated with the concept of unionism. They hate unionism. They hate solidarity and all that it stands for. In the case of voluntary student unionism, the Tories cannot see past the word ‘union’. We have heard many contributions today from members of the government, including the member for Deakin, that have referred to and made comparisons with workplace relations legislation. That emphasises this ideological bent.

speech.para: This is not the first attempt by the Liberal Party to introduce voluntary student unionism. It has been trying desperately to do so for years. The first real attempt was in Western Australia in the 1970s. Other models have been introduced but have failed to silence students. Student organisations have repeatedly voiced their opposition to Liberal Party attacks on students and universities. The Prime Minister is attempting to silence student organisations because they successfully bring to public attention the antistudent policies of the government. Students have campaigned strongly against the cutting back of billions of dollars of federal funding for universities and the doubling of HECS fees, plus the latest increases of up to 25 per cent that just about every university across this country has accepted, increases in class sizes and university fees for the dumb and the rich.

There is a lot of history here. The Liberal Party has been out to quash student organisations for more than 25 years. I wonder how much of this stems from current members of the government who were so unpopular as students because they were Liberals that they could not garner any support from their fellow students in elections. When considering the background to this legislation, we should consider that some past and present members of this parliament and major party organisers came up through the ranks of student organisations, including Kim Beazley, Peter Costello, Chris Ellison, Bob Hawke, Michael Kroger, Tony Nutt, Michael Yabsley and Julia Gillard, to name just a few.

Conservative politicians have identified politically orientated student organisations as ripe ground for the propagation of successful and career politicians. Despite the fact that some key and very influential people in the Liberal Party were largely introduced into politics and completed their apprenticeships in these political student bodies, more and more from the progressive side of politics emerge. This attempt and those previously to introduce voluntary student unionism have been designed with the motivation to stunt the growth and learning opportunities of non-conservative activists.

The government argues that this legislation is designed to protect the right of people to choose not to belong to an organisation if they choose not to for whatever reason, be it political or otherwise. However, Mr Deputy Speaker, I think you will find that most student organisations will allow any student, on the basis of conscientious objection, to refuse to be a member of their organisation. I know that is the case with organisations at the University of Newcastle. The basis of the student’s decision cannot be made on the grounds that they object to the payment of their membership fee. However, they can choose not to have that fee passed on to the student organisation. The compulsory nature of the fee structure upon enrolment does not permit a student to opt out of payment. Instead they are required to pay the fee, and in many cases organisations will allow the equivalent cost of membership to be contributed to a recognised charity of their choice. I think that if we conducted a poll of Australians as to whether they wanted the taxes that they pay to be contributing to the salary of the Minister for Education, Science and Training, many of them would choose to opt out.

At this point I think it is important to discuss the precise role of student organisations in student life. Members would be aware that the vast majority of students attending university are there to get an education and do not bother with the political side of student life. However, student organisations still play a vital role in their studies. Being a student without strong financial support from parents and family is pretty tough. This government has made it harder and harder. One of the fees that is paid by students, certainly at the University of Newcastle, goes towards providing subsidised services and facilities on campus. In its attempts to close dissent among students, the Howard government is putting at risk vital services and facilities for students, making things harder yet.

I would like to spend a little time on the provision of services in universities. I draw my examples from the work of the University of Newcastle Union. This is not a politically active organisation. It is an organisation that provides excellent services and facilities for the students of Newcastle university and charges a fee each year to provide essential services and an environment to make life as a student enjoyable. The union’s web site details the benefits of membership:

item.para: 15% discount on food within UNU
10% discount at all UNU Shops
12.5% discount at all UNU Bars
Internet Access
Clubs and Societies subsidies
Highly subsidised and FREE entertainment

speech.para: The union is not an organisation driven by profit motive. It receives concessions under the taxation laws in recognition of this fact. The organisation exists for the benefit of its members. The provision of services and activities that students want and need is a clear objective of the unions and should never be put into a position of compromise. The discounts offered to members, the clubs and societies, the activities and the support of other aspects of university life are all examples of ways in which the union successfully contributes to the personal, social and cultural development of the students of the University of Newcastle.

It is worth noting that, in the event of the withdrawal of a large level of membership fee income through the provisions of this legislation, many of these aspects of the organisation’s activities would be jeopardised and would be likely to be severely limited. The reason for this is clear. Students are hard up for funds most of the time. The Howard government has added to these burdens and if there were an opportunity to opt out of a membership fee then most students would take advantage of that. Under voluntary student unionism, many student organisations will become unviable. Many services and activities will dry up because they are not commercially viable, and a great aspect of student life will disappear.

However, those services will still need to be provided. We will see businesses come in and replace existing services and charge market prices, which will be a major disadvantage to students. At many TAFE campuses around the country, private firms operate and provide the catering services required by students. There are large firms operating on numerous campuses. These firms are obviously profit driven. There is nothing wrong with that—they are operating a business that requires a return on their investment. However, choice is limited in order to keep costs down. Items are generally expensive and the length of time one can expect to wait to be served can be considerable. There is a captive market at many university campuses and private service providers are only too keen to take advantage of this.

This draws an important distinction between the approach of student unions and that of a private provider. While many student organisations have outsourced particular catering functions, it cannot be expected that a private business which is set up to provide a return for an investment is going to consider the needs of students ahead of profits. On the face of it, the commercial operations of a student organisation may appear to be an attractive proposition for a private interest. Closer examination shows the captive market largely only exists for six months of the year and the need to establish necessary infrastructure would diminish the viability of any expected return. Only an organisation like a student union can properly maintain the services, facilities and activities that it provides for all its members.

Proponents of voluntary student unionism will have you believe that the fundamental need for fees and the subsidies they provide to services and facilities that do not necessarily turn a profit cannot be justified because there are unsubsidised, off-campus alternatives to virtually all services and because there are ordinary shops within walking distance of every Australian campus. We recently heard the Minister for Education, Science and Training, Brendan Nelson, talking in this place about how much cheaper the sausage rolls are off-campus. Minister Nelson should take himself up to Newcastle university and explain to the students there where the shops are that sell these cut-price sausage rolls. The University of Newcastle—like other non-metropolitan campuses, I would think—is isolated from any shops. It is not within walking distance. The entire case of regional universities must be considered separately from metropolitan based campuses, which have different situations and concerns.

Then there is the argument of competition. Proponents of voluntary student unionism will say that a student organisation having a monopoly over the provision of services is detrimental to the needs of its consumers or students, as it offers little in the way of choice. For those metropolitan based campuses, where students are able to walk from the union building to off-campus services, this must surely allow for that competitive edge that is considered so necessary. This cannot be applied to most regional campuses though.

This legislation is misguided. The government may want to nip in the bud aspiring progressive student political activists, but the collateral damage is the enormous added disadvantage such a move will place on the vast majority of non-politically active students. This is a disgraceful piece of legislation. It should be opposed, and the government should be condemned for it.

talk.start.para: —Freedom of association is one of the most fundamental freedoms enjoyed by Australians, and I am sure that there are very few within this House today that would disagree with that sentiment. It is therefore somewhat surprising, although I must admit not entirely surprising, that the Labor Party should oppose the Higher Education Support Amendment (Abolition of Compulsory Up-front Student Union Fees) Bill 2005.

speech.para: It was certainly interesting to listen to the comments of the member for Charlton in her speech to the House just now regarding the Liberal Party’s view of student activism and student unions. She used the emotive word ‘hate’ extensively in her opening remarks, but I think it is those who sit on the opposition benches, the members of the Labor Party, who are the real haters in this House and in this parliament. Labor hates that individuals might have the freedom to choose what organisation or association they might belong to—if such individuals choose to belong to any such associations. In fact, in our communities today workers are deserting unions in droves—they are certainly voting with their feet—and I think it is the same with students: they have no great desire to belong to student unions.

It is an absolute nonsense to say that the Liberal Party or the government is opposed to students. Indeed, many students are fully supportive of the initiatives of this government because they, too, stand for freedom—freedom of association and freedom of choice. This bill does not limit freedom of association. It does not seek to abolish the student union movement; nor does it in any way impact on students’ rights to join and contribute to their student unions. It requires that this membership should be a conscious choice of the individual student. This is hardly an outrageous expectation.

The key word here is ‘choice’. Essential to, and at the heart of, the concept of freedom of association is the right to choose to belong—or, indeed, not to belong—to a union. The government is not anti student unions. Students should be, and indeed are, free to organise and develop representative structures. Nothing in that regard will be changed by this legislation. What will change is that students will be entitled to choose to do so rather than be compelled to do so. Compulsion, by its very nature, removes choice, and the idea that students should be forced to join a student union that might have little relevance to their individual beliefs, interests or needs is therefore objectionable to many people, including many students that I have spoken to over the years. It is more objectionable when those students are required to hand over anything from $100 to $600 for the privilege, without having a say on how the money is spent and without taking into account the individual’s ability to pay. Nor does that requirement take into consideration whether the student is in full-time or part-time education or whether they have a need for the student union services that are provided.

In Western Australia many students are disaffected by the political nature of their student unions. Indeed, they are disaffected with the student union office holders that are meant to represent them. An article entitled ‘Shades of racism in campus race’ that appeared on 3 November 2004 in the Inside Cover column of the West Australian newspaper helps illustrate this point. It describes the election of an African student to the office of union president and the attempt of the incumbent office holder to prevent him from taking up the role. Despite his being democratically elected, it seems that the idea that a foreigner could be the president of the student guild dismayed the acting president sufficiently for him to involve the Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs in an effort to prevent the elected student taking office. Such practices bring that student union into disrepute and it is no wonder that in many cases students would prefer not to support or be associated with its activities.

The government is absolutely committed to the principles of freedom of association—and to doing something about it. In that context, it is my belief that students have the right to unhindered freedom of association, as well as to choose the services they want and the causes or organisations they wish to support. It is absolute anathema to us that students who disagree with the current compulsory nature of student unionism should be in a position whereby they face the very real prospect of expulsion from a university or even the withholding of their examination results. The Higher Education Support Amendment (Abolition of Compulsory Up-front Student Union Fees) Bill 2005 seeks to address this issue and remove what is, in my view and the view of many in my electorate, an inequity long overdue for change. It will mean that from next year, 2006, voluntary student unionism will exist throughout Australia, and I for one warmly welcome that development.

Essentially, at the core of this bill are two very important provisions. Firstly, the bill requires that higher education providers should not make it compulsory for students to become members of student organisations or to pay fees for services and amenities that are not of an academic nature. Secondly, the bill provides that this prohibition on non-academic fees should not apply to goods and services that are considered essential to the student’s course of study provided the student also has the choice—there is that word again—of purchasing those goods or services from an alternative supplier.

This legislation will ensure that students, as a condition of enrolment, are no longer forced to pay for goods and services that they have absolutely no use for and, at the end of the day, often can ill afford. Membership of student unions will be optional and universities will no longer be able to charge students for services they do not use or want. Optional membership of student unions would be meaningless if students were still compelled to financially support student organisations through the levying of a general services fee. If that were the case, the question would have to be asked: where would the pressure come from for student guilds to adapt and become more relevant to the people they are meant to serve? In this context, general services fees can be regarded as a form of compulsory association by another name and I therefore welcome the fact that this bill addresses this important issue.

In a West Australian newspaper article entitled ‘Student groups condemn move to cut guild funding’ which appeared on 17 March 2005, the Vice-Chancellor of the University of Western Australia, Mr Alan Robson, made an assertion that amenity fees should not be abolished because students that were required to pay them did not have to join the student guild. Mr Robson’s assertion misses the point entirely, which is that students should not be made to pay for campus facilities they do not need. Services funded through the general services fee should be run efficiently and competitively. They should meet the actual needs of students and, this being the case, they would, in my opinion, best be provided for on a user-pays, cost-recovery basis, much as happens for services provided by commercial and voluntary organisations throughout the wider community.

To ensure compliance and adherence to the two requirements imposed upon them, the bill provides for mandatory penalties for higher education providers breaching the voluntary student unionism policy. Those penalties include a reduction of the basic grant to be paid to the higher education establishment that equates to $100 for every Commonwealth supported place allocated to the provider. It is, therefore, a bill with teeth and one that higher education providers will ignore at their peril and with an eye only to the impact on their bottom line.

The effect of the Higher Education Support Amendment (Abolition of Compulsory Up-front Student Union Fees) Bill 2005 will be to achieve a number of important outcomes. It was the 17th century European philosopher and Oxford academic, John Locke, who said that the great purpose of law is not to abolish or restrain but to help preserve and enlarge freedom. This bill achieves that high ideal by establishing and enshrining a student’s right to freedom of association. It embodies choice and introduces competition to an environment where none existed before. This means that student unions will have to ensure that they remain relevant to their membership and provide services that students need, want and value. Surely such a desirable outcome has to be welcomed by all parties. In essence, students will, of their own volition, join organisations that demonstrate they do a good job of representing the interests of their membership. And, of course, student unions will be able to recruit new members by offering relevant, value for money services to students that are prized by them and can be sustained in the long run.

In essence, the bill encourages student unions to enter the real world, rather than continue to be closeted in a world where they exist as a fait accompli, irrespective of their performance and relevance and without any need to be seen to provide value for money. So under the bill a student body has the potential not only to survive but to thrive by being free to recruit members and offering services to students that are valued by them.

Of course, those with a vested interest will oppose the idea. After all, you do not have to work particularly hard to ensure you meet the needs of your membership, if membership of the student union is compulsory. Student guilds and others will argue that valuable community facilities, particularly in regional Australia, will be lost. They will argue that the services lost as a result of voluntary student unionism will put an extra financial burden on universities and that the quality of their educational experience will be diminished as a result. They will argue that student unions are an essential part of university life. In my considered view, these arguments really do not stack up when examined in the cold light of day.

I ask the House: is it really reasonable to force students—who most of us would agree are hardly swimming in surplus cash—to subsidise recreational and other facilities for the broader community? In my experience, few students, certainly in the electorate of Hasluck, have the resources to pay for services unconnected to their academic pursuits which, at the end of the day, are not relevant to their personal interests or to the activities they wish to pursue. As the situation stands today, many students are not even aware how their money is being used.

I also contend that those regional universities in a position to share campus facilities with their local communities are well placed to spread the cost in a way that is not always available to metropolitan campuses. If facilities are valued by students and local communities, with each contributing to their operating costs, I do not believe that it will automatically follow that voluntary student unionism will have a detrimental impact on those facilities. Nor do I accept the assertions made in the media that voluntary student unionism will damage Australia’s ability to win medals at the Olympics and other major sporting events. There is no basis for suggesting that services that are relevant and of interest to students will not continue to enjoy their support and to thrive.

Voluntary student unionism does not mean the death knell of student unions or their contribution to university life. Far from it; as I have said, services that are valued by students will continue to receive student support. Many sporting clubs and voluntary organisations exist throughout Australia because they offer mutually beneficial services to their membership. There is no compulsion involved and really there is no reason to suppose that university campuses should operate any differently. Individuals on campuses will band together in pursuit of common objectives just as they do everywhere else in this country.

I accept that during the period from 1995 to 2002, when Western Australia embraced voluntary student unionism, as a result of the introduction by the state government of the Voluntary Membership of Student Guilds and Associations Act, some services ceased to be provided. However, the reality is that this situation reflected the change and new requirements placed upon student guilds to focus on the services most likely to be valued by their members. Students had a choice to join or not to join and many services that were initially impacted upon recovered over time as they changed and were adjusted to more closely fit with the needs of the students.

I and many students in Western Australia regard it as extremely unfortunate that in 2002 the Labor controlled state government saw fit to overturn the legislation on voluntary student unionism through the introduction of a so-called amenities fee. An opinion piece in the West Australian newspaper described this practice as an egregious denial of the right of choice and association, as well as an inevitable infringement of students’ rights. Quite rightly, in my view, the writer points out that the vast majority of students attend universities primarily to undertake academic courses and further their career prospects. So there can be no justification for hindering them from doing so by demanding payment of fees that have nothing to do with their courses.

The article goes on to assert that any university that makes the payment of such amenity fees a condition of enrolment contributes to the diminishing of tertiary education. There can be no excuse for holding the future of our young people to ransom in such an unnecessary, unwarranted and unwelcome way. If student guilds are providing essential services for students, they should be able to attract members without any need for compulsion. If they cannot do so, it means that today’s student union movement has, in essence, little relevance to its membership and therefore you have to ask the question: does it deserve a place on university campuses?
