I do not believe that this is the case and I therefore suggest to this House that there really is no need to enshrine student guilds as enclaves of unwarranted compulsion.

Make no mistake about it: the move to re-introduce compulsion in Western Australia, which means that every student has no choice but to pay around $100 or more to fund the student guild, was a very definite and unwelcome step backwards for the rights of students who are once again forced to pay an up-front fee for something that is totally unrelated to their academic studies. Interestingly, though, it seems that the WA student guilds may have learnt a valuable lesson during Western Australia’s period of voluntary student unionism. In an article entitled ‘Student guilds in survival bid’ that appeared in the West Australian on 3 November 2004, the then University of Western Australia guild president was quoted as saying that strategies were being discussed to make sure better provisions were made for the onset of a return to voluntary student unionism. From my point of view such pragmatism is certainly very welcome.

It is unfortunate, but fairly predictable, that the Labor Party does not seem to share that pragmatism. It seems to me that at both a state and federal level Labor is determined to oppose the right of students to exercise choice and also deny them their fundamental right to freedom of association. Opponents of this bill must surely recognise that students should not be made to pay for services they do not want.

I have heard the argument put forward that by legislating for voluntary student unionism the government is in effect making an assault on academic freedom. In my view and the view of most reasonable people, the student’s right to freedom of association by far overrides the right of a university or higher education provider to ride roughshod over it. The concept of academic freedom does not give the university the right or indeed the justification to interfere in the lives of their students in a way that is outside their mandate. This government is committed to the principle of freedom of association, and this bill will finally give students that right, which is already enjoyed by the wider community. On that basis I support this bill and I commend it to the House.

talk.start.para: —The Higher Education Support Amendment (Abolition of Compulsory Up-front Student Union Fees) Bill 2005 is designed to prohibit compulsory student unionism. Firstly, it will prevent higher education providers, mainly universities, from making membership of a student organisation a condition of enrolment. Secondly, the bill will prevent higher education providers from making a condition of enrolment the payment of any fee that is not directly related to a course of study.

speech.para: The government has a longstanding commitment to prohibit compulsory student unionism in universities. One cannot help but wonder if the term ‘union’ is the thing that is the real problem here. The use of the name ‘union’ in association with students at university has been described as a historical accident. The earliest student organisations evolved out of the Oxford and Cambridge debating unions that were founded around 1815. These organisations grew and developed wider roles, but the name stuck and has since been adopted by other universities.

Student organisations can be better likened to local councils—everyone pays for the provision of services and the services are available for everyone to use. On campus services provided by student fees go towards such things as student study spaces, free computers, free room hire, advocacy, representation, legal advice, student development opportunities, email addresses and access to sport and recreation facilities.

The argument put in favour of this legislation is that current arrangements impinge on a student’s right to freedom of association. That argument has been put to rest by many authorities including the full court of the Supreme Court of Victoria in Clark v the University of Melbourne and by the full court of the Supreme Court of South Australia in Harradine v the University of Adelaide. The full court of the Supreme Court of Victoria held:

quote.para: The essence of the University’s powers is that they are powers of self-government affecting only those who choose to become members by enrolment ... they cannot touch anyone who does not voluntarily bring himself within their reach.

speech.para: The full court of the Supreme Court of South Australia said:

quote.para: The suggestion that the Universal Declaration of Human Rights is at all relevant to the issue here is not sound.

speech.para: In the Adelaide case it was also said that Adelaide University Union is a body providing services to members of the university. The learned trial judge noted that a student union is ‘not a union of the kind well known in the industrial and commercial world’. He went on to note that a student union is a ‘club providing facilities for eating, sport and other activities’. It is clear that a student union is not a union in the industrial relations sense at all.

There is also the argument that students are forced to pay fees for services that they will not use and that their fees will be used in activities, particularly political activities, that the student disapproves of. The current Treasurer of Australia has put paid to that argument. He commented on the issue of compulsory student union fees way back in his Monash University days. He said:

quote.para: The funding and therefore provision of ... services would be impossible unless there was some requirement to pay a contribution ...

speech.para: He also said:

quote.para: The facilities of student unions are only practical on the basis of compulsory contributions.

speech.para: Those are the Treasurer’s own words! In fact, the Treasurer went on to qualify his statement and illustrate it with an example. He said:

quote.para: The fact that some people object to the way in which some public funds are spent does not mean that they are therefore exempted from paying taxes.

speech.para: Treasurer, you are absolutely right. In our society we all pay taxes and share the costs of the use of services and resources, and a university is no different.

The Minister for Education, Science and Training is mistaken when he says that students should enjoy the same consumer rights enjoyed by other Australians. Citizens of a democratic country generally do not have a choice about where their particular tax dollar goes. This so-called freedom of choice is an illusion. If such logic were applied to taxes, people could refuse to pay for roads they do not use and so on. The way to direct where our taxes go is through the appropriate ballot box. Simply making the tax or fee voluntary is a nonsense. We do not do it for government taxes. We do not allow doctors to opt out of paying their medical registration fees on the grounds of freedom of association. We do not allow teachers to opt out of paying registration fees.

Last year many vice-chancellors were in Canberra, and MPs and senators were invited to meet with them informally. I took this opportunity to ask a number of vice-chancellors about this bill. The response was unanimous and slightly bemused: the bill is nonsense, it should never have been introduced and it certainly should not be supported.
Swinburne University of Technology, my old stamping ground, has written asking me not to support this bill. I will read some of their letter:

quote.para: One of the main outcomes of this Bill will be to significantly reduce the range and quality of services (including academic, cultural, sporting and social services) offered to university students within Australia. It will also diminish the facilities and environments in which they are studying. This will further threaten the Higher Education export market (currently worth $8 billion), as Australia becomes less attractive to overseas students, leaving room for competitors from other countries to take market share.

There are, however, further issues connected to the Bill which need to be addressed. The first is that the Bill confuses two separate issues—that of the general service fee (GSF) which is levied on students at all universities to pay for a range of amenities and services, and that of compulsory student unionism. These two matters are separate and need to be managed appropriately.

speech.para: Swinburne goes on:

quote.para: The next is that the name of the Bill is somewhat misleading. In Victoria, in accordance with the Tertiary Education Act 1993, there are no Compulsory Up-Front Student Union Fees to abolish. Victoria does not have compulsory student unionism and certainly at Swinburne, Student Union membership is an individual choice, and not linked to enrolment.

Under the Bill, the general service fee (GSF) is swept away and Swinburne will effectively lose $4 million in resources per year and risks not being able to provide critical services to our students. Activities such as student advocacy, orientation, transition and mentoring programs, on-line support services and infrastructure and facility support are currently provided by GSF funds, which complement and enhance our students’ studies.

speech.para: If this bill passes, the result will be a reduction in services offered by student organisations across our university campuses—services such as student employment services, child care, welfare services, orientation and transition to university, student loans, accommodation services, subsidised meals and access to sport and leisure activities. All these services are important to the wellbeing of our students. It is obvious that not all students will use all the services all the time, but that is not the point. The services are there for students to use if the need arises or if they choose to do so.

Student associations have traditionally nurtured the future leaders of this country. Many members from both sides of this House were involved in their student union or association. Beyond fostering leadership, student associations hold activities and functions that allow diverse groups of people to meet and socialise. People who attend university come from regional areas, interstate and overseas. The transition from high school to university leaves many students feeling vulnerable and isolated. The university or post high school years are very important to a young person’s future. It is where they begin to shed their adolescent skin and shape and mould themselves into well-balanced, knowledgeable adults prepared and able to contribute to our society. Student associations allow individuality to develop, and foster an appreciation of differences. They cultivate an atmosphere of tolerance and allow students a chance to excel in their academic and social lives.
I will read a letter I received from a constituent who is determined to see this bill fail:

quote.para: I am writing to you to voice my opposition to the Federal Governments proposal to prohibit universities from collecting a compulsory general service fee (GSF) from universities for services supporting students. As a former student of La Trobe University (Bundoora campus) I have been through the tertiary education process where GSFs are compulsory. I believe I speak on behalf of the majority of students when I say that I would not have experienced many of the benefits I did without the subsidies the university has provided through the GSF system.

I continued my sporting career throughout university as it was made affordable to me. In fact I still play soccer for La Trobe University (now unsubsidised of course) despite not being a student for the past nine years. The life time friends which are made by being part of a social club plus the social and business skills learnt along the way are invaluable. None of this would have happened had GSF been voluntary as I strongly believe that the funds would not have been available to continue to run these clubs and activities.
Please ensure the general service fees remain compulsory so that the quality and diversity of the tertiary experience continues.

speech.para: This bill is all about silencing student organisations. It is about retribution, plain and simple, because student associations dare to speak out against funding cuts to universities—funding cuts which have led to increased class sizes and to 20,000 qualified students per year being turned away from our universities. Turning away qualified students is a waste of our most precious resource—our own abilities and talents. This bill is about retribution because student associations do not want students paying an extra 25 per cent for HECS and they say so. This bill is about retribution because student associations do not want to pay full fees for undergraduate courses and they say so. Student associations understand the importance of access to education for all those who are interested and qualified, not just for those with deep pockets.

The government knows all too well that university students can see straight through the recent changes in university financial arrangements and can understand very clearly the destructive nature of them. Students know that this government is intent on wrecking the future of many of our young people by denying them access to a university education. In destroying the future of many young people the government is also putting at risk the future of our society. We need all the skills and resources we can muster to thrive into the future. To deny a tertiary education to those students with the capacity and the desire for further education is to waste our resources both on an individual basis and on a community basis.

The Minister for Education, Science and Training has said that if this legislation is passed students will be better able to manage their own financial affairs. That is an absolutely outrageous claim to make, given that he and the federal government are not really concerned about the welfare of our students, considering the havoc they have wreaked upon our higher education system.

This bill does not enjoy the support of those at the coalface. Every university and peak university body in the country has given this bill the thumbs down. This bill is all about the government annoyed at a body speaking out against government actions. The government cannot control the voices of our students so it is intent on silencing them. It is trying to do this by removing student unions. It is worth noting in passing that the government is so afraid of collective student action that it has produced a very second-rate piece of legislation. A consequence of this bill—and it is probably unintended—will be that universities will no longer be able to issue fees for things such as parking and library services.

To summarise: supporters of this bill are trying to get rid of student unions for ideological reasons. I make the point that student unions are not the same as industrial unions and that the government’s obsession with unions is blinding it to the reality of what student unions really do. The government argues that compulsory student fees force some students to pay for services they do not use. Once again, I cannot do any better than to quote the current Treasurer when he was wearing another hat and explained that provision of services would be impossible without a requirement on all students to contribute. Every part of this bill is awful—not merely from an ideological perspective but from a functional and practical one. I will not be supporting this legislation.

talk.start.para: —It is turning into a long day of debate on the Higher Education Support Amendment (Abolition of Compulsory Up-front Student Union Fees) Bill 2005. Many speakers have preceded me and, looking at the speakers list, I see there are many yet to come. I do not want to sound snobby about this but there is a lot of interest in this bill from both sides of the chamber. I rise to strongly support this bill. I am proud to support this bill. I believe in freedom of association; anyone in this place who opposes the bill clearly does not.

speech.para: For all the rhetoric we have heard, this bill is not based on a narrow political ideology; it is not wedge politics; it is not returning favours to any sections of the community. This government does not do that—unlike our opponents when they have had the opportunity to be in government. This legislation is based on a simple mainstream belief that is held by the peoples of every free nation around the globe, and that is that everybody should have the freedom to associate with people or organisations of their own choice and nobody should be forced to associate with people or organisations against their will. So this issue is really about quite a simple principle, and one which I am somewhat surprised we are contesting and debating here today. I cannot see how people can stand up and proudly oppose a bill that contains a measure that simply seeks to enact this belief.

My party, the Liberal Party, is guided by firm principles. Some 60 years ago the organisation’s founders set down ideals which today would cause us to stop higher education providers—that is, universities—from forcing their students to become members of student organisations or at least from forcing them to pay fees for services and amenities that are not of an academic nature. We are talking about paying for things that do not necessarily relate to the purpose of attending a university. We are talking about fees and charges for services that are not essential to obtaining a higher education. Today I have been respectfully listening to some of the comments from members of the opposition who strongly oppose this bill. Some of the arguments being used—I think, to defend the indefensible—are very difficult to accept for anybody around Australia who is able to listen to the broadcast of this debate or read it later in Hansard.

How can you describe child care as an essential service? Child care is an important service for a lot of people. It has been important in the past for my family. But, in the context of a university education, you simply cannot say with very much credibility that it is essential. Of course it is important for many; but, like the sporting examples we have heard of, such as the rugby club at Sydney University, it is not an essential service. It is important for those who need and want to enjoy campus life in that way but there is no defensible reason for the entire body of students to be forced against their will to subsidise and pay for those services for other people.

I think the previous speaker is one of the Labor Party’s better advocates, because she argues in such a respectful and dignified way. But I still think it is difficult to defend her opposition to the bill. She said that this bill is retribution against students who have protested against this government in the past. It is true that student organisations around Australia have very loudly protested against many of the important reform measures that this government has introduced over nine years, including the GST, industrial relations and issues that have nothing to do with campus life. However, the Howard government, and I as an individual, have no problem with people protesting and expressing their opinion on any issue. In fact, this legislation will do nothing to water down students’ ability to collectively organise, if that is their wish, and protest on any issue they like, providing that it is done in a law-abiding way.

Forcing people to pay is a breach of basic human rights. The previous speaker compared university fees to taxes. Federal and state taxes are applied to everybody in the Australian community. We all pay taxes in accordance with the same rules and we may often think to ourselves that we are paying for services and government spending that we do not use or want. The argument being applied by the previous speaker was that university fees that would go to student organisations could be viewed in the same way and therefore there is a good reason why they should be compulsory. With respect, this argument is totally unsustainable. You are comparing an educational institution with a sovereign, elected government—so there the comparison ends. No university should be ascribed the status and the ability to make decisions on behalf of other people that belong to a government.

Every person should have the right to choose the goods and services they want and the causes they are prepared to support. I would like to make it clear again that I am not opposed to student organisations. They can be an exciting form of democracy in which students are able to represent their members, the students, and to undertake advocacy—and even, if they are able to do so using the resources they do have, to provide services which will benefit their members.

The passing of this bill will not stop or impede that sort of voluntary activity. In fact, I would argue today that this bill actually reinforces it and encourages a form of student engagement which is far more dynamic and meaningful—voluntary and loyal membership. If I were the head of an organisation and I had the choice between having a membership of people who were paying toward the costs of that organisation and a membership of people who perhaps had no choice as to whether or not they contributed to the running costs of the organisation, I would feel very much as though I were leading an organisation that had a very reluctant membership in the latter case. There is not a lot of status in that; there is certainly not much pride; and there is zero dignity in it. I would rather lead an organisation that had a membership of people who were committed to the central causes that made that organisation exist in the first place. I would rather have a membership of people who believed in the need and the legitimacy of that organisation. It is almost like an arranged marriage as things are—two reluctant partners stuck with each other and forced to make it work out as best they can. As we should all know as mature adults, a good, healthy marriage—a healthy relationship—is where there is mutual affection and mutual loyalty.

Student organisations will always be free to recruit members and offer services to students. If the students want them, they will buy them. If they want those services but perhaps can find a better deal elsewhere, they should be able to choose them and buy those without being told where to purchase. Conversely, if they do not want those services, if they do not need them, if they are not a part of their academic program at the university or higher education provider, they should be excused from paying for them.

I say here today that the National Union of Students is totally out of touch with this nation’s student population. I represented the University of Tasmania’s Launceston campus as a delegate to the NUS in the early 1990s. I was in a distinct minority by choosing to be an independent. Most others were disturbingly close to—or active members of—the Australian Labor Party and some others were close to that ragtag group of Democrats and, when that disintegrated, really became followers of the Greens. While the odd protest against the government of the day was quite normal, to be expected, it was really an annual event. The union tried to rally its members to always put the Liberals last at elections. It was in reality a Trojan horse for the Labor Party. The arrangement between the Labor Party, unions like the NUS and campus guilds, unions and associations is one of the best examples we have today of mutual obligation—even before the advent of the Howard government and our social compact.

Labor needed the union—and, let us face it, the union needed Labor. Both consequently totally lost touch with the real world. They have lost touch with real students and they have totally lost touch with the real needs of students. I can see again today evidence of how true that still is today. I again say to my Labor colleagues that you are defending the indefensible so long as you stand in the way of freedom of association, whether it be in schools, clubs, churches, businesses, trade unions or university campuses. To stop a student or an individual person from having that innate right to choose whom they will associate with is indefensible and to be condemned.

I would also say that the National Union of Students is far too closely aligned to the ALP and the Greens—parties that say they fight for the people’s best interests. I do not believe that this is the case. They want to force people to pay student union fees—with or without their support, permission, involvement or loyalty. As most tertiary education students in this country will tell you, money is very tight and every purchase is a very considered and careful decision. Cash-strapped students need to have the flexibility to spend their money on what they want to spend it on.

Let us face it: if students really believe that services that university unions, guilds and associations have on offer to their members are worth while, they should be free to purchase them, not forced to do so. If students actually believe that university union services are worth while, they will willingly pay for them. Equally, if they are worth while, the student unions should have the courage to market them and to take the same business decisions that every other commercial entity around Australia has to take: to market their product, to run a proper business plan, to not run and offer services and spending that are wasteful and to try to meet their market—in the case of universities, to try to meet the needs of the students in relation to whom they have an excellent marketing opportunity, a captive audience, to whom they can advertise their various wares and services.

Student union presidents who claim that they will be shut down with legislation obviously have no confidence in the services they provide. Without naming the person, I want to mention that quite recently I received an email from an advocate for stopping voluntary student unionism. I had to be quite honest and blunt and say:

quote.para: If services provided by student unions such as yours are valuable services for students, then students will naturally be willing to choose them and they will pay whatever chargeable fees are set by your union.

speech.para: I then asked:

quote.para: Are you firm in your opinion that providing this choice to students will cause you to shut down? If so, perhaps you may agree that it is unreasonable to force students to pay for a service or organisation that is, in your own words, unsustainable.

speech.para: Good on him for writing to me. At least he had the courage to make his claim. That email was the only opinion that I received in my office—by email, post or fax—that actually came from a student who resides in my electorate. And I have two higher education institutions, with some thousands of students, in my electorate.

So I am not opposed to student organisations. I have been in one. I just want to see value for money. Figures compiled in 2003 looking at compulsory student union fees around the country showed the national average for 39 institutions was $280, which are substantial funds for a young person or a mature age student to have to find at the beginning of the university year when there are also various other expenses such as accommodation, textbooks and levies payable for the courses they have chosen.

I am very amused also with some of the claims that we heard from the member for Melbourne Ports earlier today, which somehow said that the Howard government, in wanting to introduce this bill and see it carried forward, was attacking freedom of speech. So we see that member doing something which I think is unreasonable in an argument—that is, playing off these two important principles of freedom speech and freedom of association. But the two can validly be upheld: we are not choosing freedom of association over freedom of speech, because this government believes that we can have both and that we should have both and that a student, irrespective of what their political or life views might be, ought to have the right to join a union if they want to and the right to not join a union if they do not want to. Also, whether or not they are a member of a union or an organisation that represents students, they should have the right to freedom of speech. Nothing I do in this chamber will diminish that freedom that I believe in.

I want to draw the House’s attention to some material from the National Union of Students. Again, that is an organisation that I used to be a member of. On 22 April a posting on their web site claimed:

quote.para: As with all regressive changes to the Higher Education sector, the impact of Voluntary Student Unionism legislation will not fall equally on all students.

speech.para: The person who wrote the article concerned has not put their name to it, but it is an official document from NUS. It further states:

quote.para: Student organisations are of specific and direct benefit to women students in a myriad of ways, therefore attempts to destroy them hit women particularly hard.

speech.para: Viva la revolution! This will liberate women on campus and give women more choices because they will be able to choose to pay for union membership if that is their wont, and if that is in their best interests they can do that. This government will be doing something for those women students by providing them with a choice that they do not have today, but which they will have as soon as this bill, which we have presented so often in this parliament, gets passed in the Senate.

The NUS web site also said that around 350 students attended the activities held on the University of New England National Day of Action and found out more about the implications of the VSU legislation currently before federal parliament. The NUS web site has a picture of a poster which advertised the event and told everybody to come. In two photographs associated with this story you can perhaps see the number of people who were there, which looks like a couple of dozen, not 350. This is further evidence of that union’s inability to engage in this debate in a cognisant and sensible manner.

The NUS also supplied protesters with suggested chants that they could use on the National Day of Action on 28 April: ‘VSU no way, we are going to fight it all the way.’ That is a good one. ‘VSU is not a choice. It destroys the student voice.’ ‘VSU is not a choice. Give the students back their voice.’ And the ripper, which I think really goes to explain the purpose of the National Day of Action and, indeed, the purpose of this union: ‘Unions yes, Liberals no. VSU has got to go.’ My time is about to expire, so I thank the House. I commend this bill to the House and I call on Labor and members opposite to withdraw their fanatical opposition to this bill and to support the rights of the people they were put here to represent.

talk.start.para: —The government’s official spin on the Higher Education Support Amendment (Abolition of Compulsory Up-front Student Union Fees) Bill 2005 is that it is somehow related to civil liberties, human rights and freedom of choice. In fact, the bill has little to do with any of those things. Every now and then government members let slip what is indeed the real motivation behind this bill when they launch into their typical tirade about student guilds, student unions, student councils—however they are named—on university campuses daring to be involved in public debate and public comment, usually taking a position contrary to that of the Liberal Party of Australia. For that they have been condemned and for that they are being punished now.

speech.para: I want to refer to a very interesting letter I received which outlined some concerns about this bill. I challenge members opposite to listen to me read the letter and to identify where it came from. The letter said that the:

quote.para: ... proposal to reduce already inadequate Commonwealth support for the University is an unwarranted interference in the affairs of the University. If promulgated in its present form, the legislation could do irreparable damage to the University and particularly to its international competitiveness.

speech.para: That was a letter from the Chancellor and the Vice-Chancellor of the University of Queensland. Who is the Chancellor of the University of Queensland? It is Sir Llewellyn Edwards, former leader of the Liberal Party in the state of Queensland, former Deputy Premier to former Premier Bjelke-Petersen. It was also signed by the Vice-Chancellor, Professor John Hay, a well respected academic. Llew Edwards, one of the high priests of the Liberal Party in Queensland, understands clearly the implications of the madness of this government’s legislation if it is enacted. He understands the impact on the university and on the services available for the staff and the wider community at the university and he thinks that is more important than the blind Liberal dogma that we have witnessed here in this debate and seen evidenced in the contribution of a number of members. The letter from the University of Queensland’s Senate is illustrative in a number of respects and I want to refer to a couple of other passages in it:

quote.para: The Senate of the University of Queensland is very strongly opposed to the Commonwealth Government’s alarming proposals in relation to voluntary student unionism and compulsory student service charges.

speech.para: That is the first sentence. Let there be no mistake where Llew Edwards and the Senate of the University of Queensland stand. They are strongly opposed to these proposals. Later on the letter sets out some of the important services and functions that the various student bodies perform. Many of those things have been covered during the debate today. The letter also refers to the important role that those student bodies play in the educational development of the students as part of their university life. If time permits, I may return to quote some of that letter. They also note quite correctly that student clubs and societies are a part of the great tradition of Western universities.

I have seen in other material the comment that, if this legislation goes through, Australia will be the only country in the Western world to have outlawed these compulsory student fee payments. I have endeavoured to get that checked on a number of occasions. I have not been able to determine absolutely that it is accurate, but it does appear to be the case. Certainly, as Llew Edwards and Professor John Hay point out, it is the tradition in Western universities for there to be compulsory student organisations that the students participate in, not just for the delivery of important services but as part of the development of those people at universities, not all but many of whom are transiting through life from youth to adulthood and will be leaders of our community in years to come. That is important. If Llew Edwards, one of the high priests of the Liberal Party in Queensland, can understand that, it beggars belief that few on the government side either cannot comprehend it or, if they do comprehend it, fail to have the intestinal fortitude to stand up and do something about it.

The letter that I received from Llew Edwards that I was quoting from has in fact been sent to every member of the federal parliament from Queensland and to the minister. The parliamentary secretary at the table, the member for Petrie, no doubt has a copy. I am sure she has read it and I look forward to her contribution to this debate, answering the letter from Llew Edwards and explaining why he, as one of the senior, respected political figures in Queensland—and a senior Liberal figure to boot—has got it wrong. I suspect the parliamentary secretary is not about to give up her job and cross the floor to vote with us on this, so she may like to enter the debate and explain to us why the people of Petrie should find themselves lost in this debate.

It is not just the Liberal Party in Queensland that is led by people who understand the importance of student services on campus. Not that long ago, on 29 April, I was interested to note a statement from the leader of the opposition in the Queensland parliament, the leader of the Queensland National Party, Lawrence Springborg. The Courier Mail reported on that day:

quote.para: Queensland Nationals leader Lawrence Springborg has broken from conservative ranks to call for major changes to the Federal Government’s voluntary student unionism legislation.

speech.para: The article quoted him saying:

quote.para: I think there is a strong case for a compulsory levy otherwise genuine student services will suffer, particularly in regional areas ...

speech.para: That is Lawrence Springborg, the leader of the National Party in the Queensland parliament and the leader of the opposition in the Queensland parliament.

So we have here two prominent Queenslanders, leaders in their own right of conservative parties, the Liberal Party in the case of Llew Edwards and the National Party in the case of Lawrence Springborg, both coming out publicly and saying that this government’s approach with respect to compulsory fees at university is wrong and, worse than that, is damaging to the life of the university. Indeed, the University of Queensland, in the letter from Llew Edwards, went on to point out that it is going to create problems for them as they endeavour to market themselves to students overseas because the services provided by these student guilds and bodies are often regarded as essential by overseas students and those who pay for the overseas students to come here. They are concerned that the University of Queensland will be placed at a disadvantage when those students look around the world because, unlike the rest of the universities in the Western world, they will find that these services are not available to students here in Australia if this legislation goes through.

Why is that the case? We need look no further than the comments of some opposite when they were in a different life. Treasurer Peter Costello no less, when he was at university, was not only an activist in his student association but also the president of it. He was the president of the Monash Association of Students. He wrote an article about the threat to universities should compulsory charges be removed. This is what Peter Costello wrote in that article:

quote.para: The funding and therefore provision of the various student services would be impossible unless there was some requirements to pay a contribution towards them.
... the facilities of the student unions are only practical on the basis of compulsory contributions ...

speech.para: That was no less a person than Peter Costello, the Treasurer of Australia today, when he was president of the Monash association—when he was actually at university, involved in an association and understanding on a day-to-day basis the services they provide and the way those services are funded and operate. That is the view he had then. He is quite silent about it these days. He has his mind set on other activities at the moment—he is trying to topple the Prime Minister and have a bit of generational change within the Liberal cabinet room. But when he was the president of the student guild at Monash University, he made no bones about this issue. He made it clear that, without the compulsory payment, these services would not exist.

That reinforces the concern that people like Llew Edwards and Lawrence Springborg have raised. These are not people whom government members can characterise as left wing radicals or unionists trying to bring down the world as we know it. If you listen to some of the nonsense from people on the other side, they would have us believe that university student guilds were hotbeds of anarchy. It is a fairly amusing thing for those of us who were involved in student politics, and I have to confess that I was very active in student politics as well. There are people on both sides of this chamber who were. Unlike Peter Costello, I hold the views about the importance of those organisations that I held then. Like Llew Edwards and Lawrence Springborg, I appreciate the importance that they provide on campus for a whole range of reasons.

This is not the first time John Howard and his government have sought to introduce legislation such as this. A similar—probably identical, in fact—piece of legislation was introduced into this parliament in 1999 which evoked the same negative response from all of those involved with universities, and by that I do not mean the student guilds and unions that those opposite want to lambast. One university union went bankrupt—yes, that happened. We can talk about companies that go bankrupt. Does that mean we should close down the operations of boards of directors around the country? We can talk about company directors that are behind bars because of their improper behaviour. Does that mean we should be taking drastic action to close down corporate Australia? The simple fact is that there are going to be some people who want to bend rules and cut corners. That happens everywhere, but please do not pretend in this debate that they are representative of the student guilds and unions around Australia. That is such a fallacious argument—it does no credit to those in the Liberal and National parties who have raised it.

Let me go back to when this issue was raised in 1999. Who came out then to oppose the legislation? There were people like Sir Gerard Brennan, the former Chief Justice of the High Court, and Steve Monaghetti, the well-known Australian Olympian and marathon runner. The Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee opposed it, and I believe they are opposed to it on this occasion. Not only were people outside the parliament on the record as opposing it; in 1999, at least, there were a few Tories in this parliament who were willing to stand up and publicly criticise it—people who today are silent.

talk.start.para: —Name them.

—I am invited by my friend the member for Lowe to name them, and I think I should. In 1999 those people on the government benches for the Liberal and National parties who thought that this was a bad thing and said so publicly were: Ian Macfarlane, the member for Groom, now a minister; Kay Hull, the member for Riverina; Joanna Gash, the member for Gilmore; and a member who is now an Independent, Bob Katter, the member for Kennedy. So members of the Liberal and National parties were saying publicly that this was the wrong tack to take, it would damage the role of universities, it would damage the services available and it would diminish the experience of students as they progressed through tertiary education.

speech.para: I wonder what has happened to people like Ian Macfarlane, Kay Hull and Joanna Gash these days—not a peep out of them. At least people like Llew Edwards have the intestinal fortitude and integrity to stand up and publicly say this is the wrong thing to do. There is even Lawrence Springborg from the National Party. You do not hear me saying too many positive things about the Queensland National Party, but at least the Queensland National Party are led by someone who understands that his constituents are going to be hurt by this.

A couple of weeks ago I spoke at a rally against this proposition on the campus of the Queensland University of Technology. I made the point then that it is really bewildering to see the National Party jumping off the cliff like lemmings on this issue. They have done it on other things; there is no reason why they should not do it on this. It is not for passing amusement that they are referred to these days as ‘Liberals in gumboots’, but their constituents are actually seriously affected. One of the critical services most student guilds and unions provide is accommodation and other support for people who are moving into the area of the university. They might be moving from, say, the outskirts of Brisbane into the city and need assistance with accommodation or job placement. They might need to know where there are doctors who bulk-bill, because most university students do not have a lot of cash. They may need other counselling support and services. Because they are away from their home base, they may need some advice on the operation of their university and, from time to time, advocacy support if things go wrong.

One of the groups that use those services more than others are, in fact, the people from the bush who come to the city for their tertiary education. Lawrence Springborg is smart enough to understand that. You would hope that cocky corner on the other side of the House could wake up before the vote occurs and realise that their constituents are going to be adversely affected if they mutely sit on their hands. But I would have to say that, given their performance on a number of issues—not least of all the sale of Telstra—we will see the National Party trot along with the Liberal Party and support this bill.

During this debate, members on this side of the House have referred to the idea of mutual obligation and the fact that it is not uncommon in our society for people to be obliged to make a contribution if, indeed, they receive a benefit from an organisation. We would not be here as a parliament and a government if we did not subscribe to that principle, because it is on that basis that we tax people whether they like it or not. It is on that basis that state and local governments tax people whether they like it or not. I have listened to comments from government members who are critical of that. There are a few lawyers on the other side of this parliament. I just wonder what they say about the compulsory fees they have to pay to their law societies. Should that be the next bill we introduce? If this is about freedom of choice, civil liberties and human rights, why is it that we tolerate a situation where lawyers have to make a contribution to an organisation whether they want to or not? Because there is a good reason for that: it ensures a standard; there is a collective benefit. As a society we accept the view that, if you get the benefit, you should make a contribution.

There was another very good comparison made, I think by one of the student union activists in an article recently, which perhaps was better than those already made in this debate. It is the situation that applies in Queensland, and perhaps elsewhere, of the ambulance levy. I think people would agree that the ambulance service is an essential service. Our society could not really function in a civilised manner without it. In Queensland, until quite recently ambulance contributions were voluntary. As a consequence, the ambulance service was dramatically underfunded. So you would go to your shopping centre on Saturday and there would be a chook ruffle or a chocolate wheel, and the ambulance guys would be out there trying to raise a few bob to make sure they had equipment for their ambulances that, frankly, are an essential service.

The Beattie government, quite properly, put an end to voluntary contributions. They said: ‘This is an essential service and we are going to place a levy on people to cover it. Everyone will make a contribution, which will guarantee an appropriate level of resourcing for the ambulance service.’ We heard some of the same arguments then from people in the community. Frankly, I supported that decision by the Queensland government. Everybody should be making a contribution to the operation of the ambulance service. None of us particularly want to be in a situation where we need it, but it is proper that we all make a contribution to it. Today I do not hear anyone in Queensland arguing the reverse of that. I do not hear anybody hopping up to say, ‘We should abolish that because really it is a question of freedom of choice, human rights and civil liberty.’

The argument before the parliament today is about something far broader. It is not about the things that the government have put forward in the debate. It is in fact this: John Howard and this government will not tolerate dissent; they will not tolerate alternative voices in our community. We have seen it in the rhetoric of those opposite when the emotions start to run high The student unions happen to be the latest group in the firing line for that; they are not the first people to encounter it. It has happened to the environmental groups. It has happened to social groups who have had their funding cut or threatened. It has happened to church groups who dare to complain that the welfare system in this country has got worse. It has happened to the ABC—they were being bludgeoned to death by this government. Now the government are directing their weaponry at the student unions, because they will not tolerate voices of dissent and alternative thought. That is fundamentally wrong and is one of the most insidious things this government have done since they came to office.

I oppose this bill wholeheartedly. It may well be that the bill will go through after 1 July, but it will be at great cost to universities throughout Australia. If people opposite do not want to listen to Labor members, they should listen to the wise heads in their own Liberal and National parties on this issue.
Debate (on motion by Mr Keenan) adjourned.

interrupt.para: Sitting suspended from 5.54 pm to 7.30 pm

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 10 May, on motion by Mr Costello:

motion.para: That the bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —Our great country is about to enter the second decade of conservative rule. History will mark 1996 to 2006 as the Liberal-National government’s decade of deception: year after year of lowering the ‘truth’ bar, then deliberately crawling under it, with one common theme—the government deceive and Australians pay. But this year we have learned why the government have been so deceitful. We uncover their motive with each new economic indicator—with one of the highest foreign debt levels in the world, with a record current account deficit, with household debt rising and rising—and with the tragedy of a government that turns away tens of thousands of Australians from TAFE colleges whilst the Treasurer makes a virtue in his budget speech of importing skills from overseas to make up for the difference.

speech.para: Sadly, we are learning the truth. They have squandered this chance to make Australia secure for our children and grandchildren. They have surfed a wave of prosperity but left the tough decisions to future generations. When we hoped they would get better, they got worse. Tuesday’s budget centrepiece is an injustice of the highest order. Instead of leading Australia through reforms the OECD and Reserve Bank, among others, tell us we ought to have, instead of preparing Australia for the next phase of growth by investing in training Australians and in infrastructure like roads, rail, water and ports—and in tax reform which encourages people into the Australian work force—the budget savaged the weakest in our society and contemptuously dismissed those nurses, teachers, tradesmen, labourers—the people raising our families, 80 per cent of our taxpayers, seven million Australians, the engine room of Australia. They received no tax cuts last year or this year and in the next three they get a derisory $6 a week—nothing to encourage those out of the work force into it but for a minority a tax cut which, for the first time in my memory, takes those of us in this parliament out of the top tax bracket with 10 times the reward of our fellow Australians. If you think anyone here of Labor principle would vote ourselves a $65 weekly tax cut when the people who put us here get $6, you have got another think coming.

It is not leadership to cheer this through. What leadership means is that when you are confronted with something like this you stand up and fight. That is what we will do. I will do so in the context of a budget of lost opportunity. It comes at a time when Australia is enjoying its highest export prices since Don Bradman retired from captaining Australia half a century ago. The minerals boom that underpins our economy has nothing to do with the policies of this government. Good fortune has added $40 billion per year to our national income. That is the equivalent of a $7,000 bonus for every Australian family, every year. But a responsible leader looks out to the horizon, sizes up the future threats to the nation and prepares it for risks. Before the budget, the question for Australia was: what would we do with this singular opportunity? Would we invest it in something that lasts? Would we take this extraordinary opportunity to repair what is broken in our nation? This is a question of our values: what and who would come first in our Australia? This budget has failed the Australian people because it fails to act upon urgent challenges facing the nation. It does nothing new to ease our chronic skill shortage. It does nothing new to fix our ports and roads. It does nothing new to support research and development. It does nothing new to support our universities. It does nothing new to solve the water crisis. It does nothing new to lift our exports.

But before I get on to those matters, I want to deal with the first order of business: taxation. Tonight I am drawing a line in the sand with John Howard on Australian values and the sort of country we want to be, a line between us and this government, which says someone earning $500,000 a year deserves 10 times the tax cut of an Australian earning $50,000 a year. A lot of Australians think that John Howard’s tax plan is terribly unfair. I will expose it for what it is and oppose it for what it is. I will not accept criticism from a greedy government for standing up for the seven million Australian taxpayers who were tossed the tax cut scraps from the tax cut feast enjoyed by so few Australians. The Labor Party will be the last line of defence between John Howard and his desire to divide the Australian community—reward some and punish the many.

The Treasurer got a big cheer from the Liberal Party backbench on Tuesday night when he announced a whopping big tax cut on their super, and he got a huge cheer when he announced that these same politicians would be exempt from the top income tax rate. He was offering them a massive tax cut. Here was the Treasurer, using the nation’s public finances to gain the support of his colleagues for a tilt at the leadership. It makes no sense to skew tax cuts towards those who have already enjoyed the greatest gains from our recent prosperity.

Tonight I am going to set out a tax plan that takes the government’s proposed tax changes and turns them into a genuine reform of the tax system that delivers benefits across the income tax scales with fairness. The government should raise the threshold where the 30c rate cuts in from $21,600 to $26,400. It should implement a welfare to work bonus that would provide an effective $10,000 tax-free threshold for people earning up to $20,000 per year. This is what encourages people who are on welfare into the work force—when you are not trying to punish them.

The tax plan should avoid delivering any fiscal stimulus while the economy stays in the red zone of a potential interest rate rise in the second half of 2005. There is simply no benefit in giving families a $6 a week tax cut if that tips the Reserve Bank over the edge into raising interest rates. After all, one interest rate increase will raise monthly mortgage repayments for a $300,000 mortgage by $48—almost twice the size of that $6 weekly cut.

These changes should take effect from 1 January 2006. In addition, from 1 July 2006 the government should raise the threshold where the 42c rate cuts in from $63,000 to $67,000 and raise the threshold where the 47c rate cuts in from $80,000 to $100,000. This package would deliver a tax cut of up to $9 a week for those earning up to $25,000—double what the government is offering. It would deliver a $12 tax cut for those earning from $25,000 to $70,000—double what the government is offering. It would preserve the government’s tax cut for people earning from $70,000 up to $100,000. We recognise that people on around $80,000 are not rich, but politicians on $105,000 and over are doing all right. This package would deliver $40 to people who earn $105,000 and above—one-third less than what the government is offering; a much fairer outcome.

A worker or single-income family on average weekly earnings will over the next four years gain $1,248 in tax cuts from the government. How much from Labor’s plan? $2,184 in tax cuts—about $936 more under Labor for middle Australia. A dual-income family on $85,000 will over the next four years gain $2,496 from the government. How much under Labor’s plan? $4,368 in tax cuts—about $1,872 more under Labor for middle Australian families. I say to those in government: you have a choice. Make yourselves richer or make seven million Australians who put you in here richer. The whole proposal could be delivered for around the same cost as the $24.1 billion cost of the government’s changes over the budget period.
Welfare reform

This budget’s welfare changes were touted as a significant reform that would raise work force participation rates and assist people to transfer from welfare to work. But the government’s approach to welfare reform does little to increase welfare recipients’ capacity to work and nothing to encourage employers to take them on. Instead of seizing the opportunity to bring these Australians into the productive economy, it shifts them from one welfare payment to another. Let us put this in perspective. We are actually talking about people who typically live with poor vision or hearing, possibly suffer from episodic mental illness or endure chronic physical pain. These are some of the most disadvantaged Australians. They are not a breed apart; they are not a separate species. They are our neighbours, our siblings, our parents and our friends. A genuine effort to help get them into paid work involves taking practical steps to make it easier for employers to hire people with disabilities.

Welfare recipients often require training and are not job ready. The lack of affordable child care is also a major barrier to them working. The government is offering only small child-care and training measures in this budget that do not do enough to address the real challenges of getting these Australians into lasting work. In practical terms, the main impact of the package is to shift disability support pensioners and sole parents onto the dole, where the government will save up to $77 per fortnight. Once again, the government has taken the low road, the easy path.
The 2005 budget: a squandered opportunity

I have dealt with disincentive to work in our tax and welfare systems by proposing a genuine tax reform plan. But to secure our prosperity we need to lift Australia’s capacity for the next phase of growth. Commentators agree this budget fails to do that work. The ANZ Bank has said ‘it could not be said that this is a great reforming budget’. It also said that the budget is ‘light on spending to relieve infrastructure constraints’ and ‘There is now an increased risk that rates will be lifted again’.

The budget should have seized an historic opportunity to invest in Australia’s future and confront the long-term threats to the economy. What Australia’s economic commentators are urging from this government is national leadership on infrastructure. That means investing in our economy’s growth capacity—building a highly skilled work force and an advanced, competitive economy. Australia’s greatest asset is not its mines, its stock markets or its buildings. It is our people: hardworking Australians. And nothing gives us better prospects for long-term productivity and prosperity than investing in working Australians.

We also need to keep the nation’s infrastructure in good repair. Our transport and communications networks must be up to scratch so that Australian businesses can seize opportunities for growth and investment. We must also address enormous challenges in other parts of the national infrastructure: the crisis in our inland rivers, rising salinity problems in our soil and gaps in our energy infrastructure. And we need a modern industry agenda that embraces the potential for innovation, business investment and growth from ratifying the Kyoto protocol, encouraging clean energy and cutting greenhouse emissions.

We also need a broad program of reform to rebuild our national competitiveness. We need to strengthen our national competition laws. We need, once and for all, to resolve the bickering between Commonwealth and state governments, to improve efficiency and reduce duplication. We need to relieve the burden of regulation on small business and we need to simplify the mind-numbing complexity of our tax system. Before it introduced its tax reforms, the government inherited a tax act of about 4,000 pages. It is now 7,000. You do not paginate the tax act anymore; you weigh it.

Australia needs a government that is up to the reform challenge, that can lift the hood on the economy and get stuck in and fix things up, just as the reformist Hawke and Keating governments did in the eighties and nineties after inheriting a weak, uncompetitive economy from the Fraser-Howard government in 1983.
The Howard government: tinkering, not delivering

The Howard government has talked for nine long years about reform, and it has held scores of inquiries and published dozens of reports about reform. But its record of action has never matched the rhetoric. It is a government that tinkers on the edges. It walks around and kicks the tyres, but it does not lift the hood and get its hands dirty with real reform.

Look at the record. Who remembers now the great savings debate of the 1997 budget? Mr Costello said that it would increase savings, reduce our reliance on foreign debt and raise the speed limits to growth. Six weeks after it commenced they scrapped it! And since then the household savings ratio has plummeted to below zero and foreign debt is astronomical. This week’s budget quietly announced a permanent downgrade to Australia’s future growth prospects.

Who remembers the great crackdown on top end tax avoidance that was promised alongside the GST in 1999? Mr Costello claimed that it would clean out the rorts. Labor supported the cuts in corporate tax and capital gains tax, on the basis of Mr Costello’s undertakings to deliver those reforms in full. Mr Costello even signed a piece of paper saying he would deliver them in full but his signature on that paper was worth nothing.

Who remembers Mr Howard’s flamboyant promise in 1996 to ‘cut red tape for small businesses by 50 per cent’? There was a review, a report, a big launch and a blaze of publicity. But instead of getting relief from compliance burdens, small businesses found they had to become tax collectors for the government when the GST and the business activity statement were introduced. And this year small businesses are burdened with another heavy load: the red-tape nightmare of superannuation choice. Once again, the government decided that all the paperwork would land on the desk of the small business owner. Worse still, the government’s legislation actually imposes a jail term of up to two years on small business owners who answer an employee’s question about the super funds they might choose.

This Treasurer has form. He brings in the brass band to trumpet his big solutions but when you look back on his legacy you realise he is little more than a clanging cymbal, a hollow drum, a loud percussive nothing.
The government is not up to the reform challenge

The problem for Liberal Party politicians is that the actions most needed to address our economic challenges do not fit their ideological prejudices. Instead of questioning their own prejudices and putting them to one side they deny the problems. They cannot accept that there are substantive economic reforms that require real leadership from the public sector.

But the big wave of economic reforms that shifted Australia from an overregulated, insulated economy to an open market economy are already in place. We do not have to relive the 1980s and 1990s. The next wave of productivity growth is not going to come from the kinds of one-off reforms made in the eighties and nineties. The next wave of productivity growth will come from our long-term investments in our work force and in our infrastructure. Today’s challenges therefore call for active public sector involvement.

Just as Labor abandoned its prejudices in pursuit of reforms such as tax and labour market reforms in the eighties, now the Liberal Party needs to break out of its ideological straitjacket and start putting Australia first. In those days, the nation’s economy required a historic shift to integrate Australia with the world economy, phase out protectionism, overhaul the tax system, create a modern productivity based system of workplace agreements, and scale back regulation.

We put those reforms in place. They were not popular, and the Liberal Party opposed many of them. They opposed intergenerational reforms like introducing an assets test on pensions. They opposed compulsory national superannuation, the greatest single step in building retirement income security for all Australians. They opposed tax reforms that restored fairness and equity—even our efforts to end those long boozy business lunches that executives enjoyed at taxpayers’ expense. They were lazy on reform then and they are lazy on reform now.

In place of dispassionate reform that develops far-sighted solutions to our economic problems we get silly ideological indulgences like Brendan Nelson’s voluntary student unionism. In the long term, Australia will not be able to escape the effects of the government’s wilful neglect. We need a government that gives priority to the long term over the short term. It means the government putting the nation’s interest ahead of its own political interest. I believe that government has a responsibility to invest in the wealth-generating machinery of the economy. We need specific, immediate action to address the long-term erosion of work force skills and infrastructure.
Skills

Rebuilding the nation’s skills is an immediate and urgent need for our economy. The government’s only initiative on skills this year is an increase in skilled migration—an extra 20,000 skilled migrants in this budget. Meanwhile, the government is turning away almost 40,000 Australians from TAFE each year. Since 1997, the government has turned 270,000 people away from TAFE colleges, while bringing in 180,000 skilled workers. Labor’s priority is different: train Australians first and train Australians now.
Trade completion bonus

The government should move immediately to address the national skills crisis. I would start with the appalling drop-out rate in apprenticeships. Currently, 40 per cent of people in new apprenticeships drop out before completing their training. We need more tradesmen and women and fewer apprentice drop-outs. The government should move immediately to introduce a $2,000 trade completion bonus for traditional apprentices who complete their training. The first $1,000 would be paid halfway through their apprenticeship and the second at its end. This would immediately encourage more Australians to complete their training in areas of critical skill shortages, instead of forcing businesses to wait until 2010 for the first qualified apprentice to emerge from the Howard government’s technical colleges.
Trade Apprenticeship School Incentive Scheme

The second step the government should take immediately is to dramatically increase the number of school based apprenticeships in traditional trades. Last year, just 11,400 school students commenced apprenticeships—70 per cent of these were not even in areas of skill shortage. We could make a real dent in the skills crisis by allocating an additional 4,000 training places in our schools for years 11 and 12 students—that is 2,000 at each level. We also need to give schools extra support to participate in this scheme.

I would provide a 50 per cent ‘skill shortage loading’ for school based trade apprenticeships. This additional funding of $1,750 per student apprentice would help schools build their capacity to offer the school based apprenticeships, such as by creating links with local employers. This approach reflects a difference in values between the Prime Minister and me.

I think it is irresponsible for the Prime Minister to tell young Australians to drop out of school. Unlike the Prime Minister, I understand the difference between low-paid, casual and part-time work and a real skill and a real career. To be an electrician, to be a carpenter, to be a tiler, to be a person with a substantial career means you can marry and you can have a family. You do not go on the treadmill of life but have a real career. Young people who leave school early, as urged by the Prime Minister, are twice as likely to become unemployed as people who finish year 12. Employers want their apprentices to finish school so they have broad based skills to make them better equipped for working life.
Infrastructure

The third major reform challenge that requires immediate action is the repair of our nation’s infrastructure. Organisations like the OECD and the Reserve Bank have called for national leadership and have identified this as the missing factor in the development of Australia’s public and private infrastructure—national leadership, not blaming the states. If I were Prime Minister tonight, I would provide clear national leadership on infrastructure planning. I would marshal the expert advice on the extent of infrastructure problems, how to fix them, and how we plan for the roads, railways, ports and communications networks of the future.

Mr Howard behaves as though we do not need action, just talk. In the past year alone, the government has commissioned eight separate, sporadic and ad hoc infrastructure inquiries. That is why Labor would set up a national infrastructure council to be known as Infrastructure Australia. With input and representation from the private and public sectors, Infrastructure Australia would provide ongoing advice to all Australian governments—Commonwealth, state and territory—on the adequacy of what infrastructure we have and to develop a blueprint for the future.

Infrastructure Australia would be a standing item on the agenda of the Council of Australian Governments, and would provide regular reports to that body. I cannot understand why the government remains deaf to the calls from business for such a body. If we get the policy settings right—through the establishment of Infrastructure Australia—we can unlock investment in roads, rail, ports, communications and energy networks. This will lift the speed limit of the economy and be a strong foundation for Australia’s future prosperity.
Future fund

I believe the private sector has a major role to play in the financing and building of infrastructure, but some parts of our infrastructure cannot operate commercially and must be provided by the public sector. The Treasurer has indicated that the proceeds of asset sales and budget surpluses will be moved into a future fund. I support this measure, but I have a different set of priorities as to the use of its dividends. The Treasurer asserts that the assets will be in a locked box for 15 years. But let us see how long it will be before John Anderson’s Nationals crowbar that box open and boast about it as they fritter away the assets around the countryside—they have form.

The Treasurer says the Future Fund will offset the pressure on the budget from the costs associated with population ageing. He is actually talking about a couple of Commonwealth Public Service superannuation schemes which have been abolished and which were reasonably well handled anyway. When talking about the ageing population, he is really talking about paying superannuation to retired Canberra public servants, who are, as I said, covered well enough as we stand. But the best safeguard against the intergenerational risks to the economy is to put the economy on a path of higher productivity and faster growth.

Labor has a different and better plan for a fund for the future, a fund to help rebuild Australia. Instead of the government’s future fund, Labor would establish its Building Australia Fund, and allow the income streams from that fund to be applied for infrastructure purposes. This would lay our foundation for higher growth rates. Higher productivity and higher growth are the best and only ways to lay a strong foundation for the future. That is the right way to use the budget surpluses that would go into that fund. It is the right way to ensure that impediments to growth in the Australian economy are properly removed. Anyone who thinks for one minute that the National Party would not get their hands into that locked box is a victim of the triumph of hope over experience. To be heckled by this bunch with the record they have developed on regional rorts is pretty rich.
Conclusion

A budget exposes a government’s priorities. It determines the way ahead for the nation. It is an open window on a government’s soul. So, with this budget, who comes first in John Howard’s Australia? The members of parliament in this place who get a windfall gain of $65 per week, or the men and women who clean their offices and get just $6 per week? Of course, the Prime Minister will instantly dismiss Labor’s stand for the seven million forgotten Australian taxpayers and say that it is populist, opportunistic and Labor Party class warfare. But I say it is just that we have different priorities and different values.

If this were the budget speech and not the reply, the rebuilding of the Australian economy would commence tonight. The engines of reform would hum again. We would begin again to lay the foundations for a better Australian future, one that depends not on the good luck of a mining boom but on the skills of working Australians and the strength of the nation’s infrastructure.
Labor stands for a better deal for working Australian men and women and tonight one thing is clear: if ever this country needed a Labor government, it is now.
