debate.para: The following notices were given:
Mr Georganas to move:
That this House:
(1) notes that:
(a) since the abolition of the Commonwealth Dental Program waiting lists for dental services have increased by over 30 per cent;
(b) an increasing number of Australians are unable to afford private dental treatment and are waiting up to 5 years for dental care;

(c) older Australians, in particular, are at risk of poor health and a diminished quality of life as a result of long waiting lists and the lack of affordability of private dental services and private health insurance;

(d) the working poor, ineligible for health care cards and unable to afford private health insurance, are either postponing essential dental care, or risking high interest health credit products to access essential dental care to avoid further work absence;
(e) poor dental health can contribute to deterioration in overall health and can lead to premature admission to nursing homes or even death;

(f) oral health issues are often divorced from mainstream health issues even though there is a strong link between poor dental health and health problems such as diabetes, stroke, heart disease, endocarditis, and nutritional deficiencies;

(g) the postponement of dental treatment has led to an increase in the demand for emergency dental care, exacerbating ongoing preventative treatments which provides greatest long term benefits to both the community and the Commonwealth budget; and
(h) early intervention is important for maintaining a healthy and quality lifestyle and reducing future burdens on the health system; and
(2) calls on the Government to:
(a) recognise Ben Chifley’s vision when he amended the Constitution in 1946 to recognise dental treatment as a legitimate medical treatment;

b) acknowledge that existing policies, as highlighted by the House of Representatives Inquiry into Long Term Strategies for Ageing Over the Next 40 years, “fall short of providing access to preventative dental care”;
(c) reinstate a Commonwealth dental program, and adopt Labor’s Australian Dental Care plan; and
(d) work cooperatively with the States and Territories to ensure that services are delivered to the most vulnerable in our community, including the elderly and the working poor.

Ms
Burke to move:
That this house:

(1) notes that there has been an increased global trend for companies to relocate various parts of their operations to locations outside of the country where the service is being delivered - a practice often referred to as off-shoring;

(2) notes that the practice of off-shoring has seen jobs and skills lost from the IT and finance sector in Australia and that Deloitte Research predicts that 15% of all financial sector jobs will be moved off-shore by 2008;
(3) recognises that participating in the global economy may deliver lower costs for local consumers and companies, however it must be done in a transparent and equitable manner; and
(4) calls on the Government to act now, before the flood of jobs off-shore sees Australia losing out, by:
(a) ensuring privacy protection for consumers;
(b) providing consumers with a “right to know” so that service providers disclose the country of origin which provides their services, equivalent to country of origin product labelling;
(c) developing a national skills base that is suited to the changing needs of the economy;
(d) providing assistance in reskilling displaced workers; and
(e) ensuring employees of the country where the jobs are relocated are also protected by ILO Labour Standards.
Ms King to move:
That this House:
(1) recognises that:
(a) symphysis pubis dysfunction (SPD) or pelvic instability in pregnant women can affect 1 in 36 pregnant women; and

(b) the condition can be debilitating with symptoms ranging from pain in the front and back of the pelvis, to difficulty walking, bending or straddling and an inability to carry out many daily activities;
(2) congratulates the newly formed Pelvic Instability Association for its work to raise awareness of this condition; and
(3) urges the Government to:
(a) further promote awareness of pelvic instability in pregnant women;
(b) fund Australian-based research into its incidence and guidelines for treatment and rehabilitation; and
(c) provide assistance to the Pelvic Instability Association in supporting women with this condition.

Mr Kerr to present a Bill for an Act to amend the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 to deny election funding to political candidates accepting gifts derived from tobacco smoking, and for related purposes. (Commonwealth Electoral Amendment (Preventing Smoking Related Deaths) Bill 2005)

business.start.para: The DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. IR Causley) took the chair at 9.40 am.

talk.start.para: —Last week one of my constituents wrote to me expressing his concern about the increased cost of petrol, diesel and kerosene—a concern that is widely shared in the electorate. He argued quite forcefully that the multinationals were holding Australia to ransom. I have some sympathy for this position, having got nowhere with the ACCC when I pursued what I believed was possible collusion in the regular price peaks of petrol on Thursdays in my electorate—the Thursdays that just happened to coincide with pension paydays. The price of petrol is an important issue in my electorate. It is a non-discretionary expenditure for most households that are so reliant on private car transport. When oil prices peaked at nearly $US60 a barrel in April this year, families were paying $1.10 or more per litre. With some commentators predicting that the price of oil could hit $US100 within the next two years, it would be a foolish government that ignored the potential impact on household budgets.

speech.para: It is in this context that I believe we should be appraising alternate fuel technologies. As we know, hybrid cars like the Toyota Prius are already in high demand in Australia. Even the Bush administration is now talking about hydrogen cars. In fact, not so long ago I witnessed a trial of hydrogen buses in Perth.

Biofuels are being widely used throughout the world in countries like Sweden, Canada and the United States, while in Brazil, as we know, nearly all vehicles now run on ethanol blends or even pure ethanol. Isn’t it time we had a thorough look at biofuels like ethanol-blended petrol and the degree of appropriate government assistance that should be provided to support this fledgling industry? Most studies now seem to concur that 10 per cent ethanol is an acceptable blend requiring no vehicle modification. That being the case, it should settle the recent controversy, with the proviso that the principle of the consumers’ ‘right to know’ is safeguarded. I note that BP began marketing 10 per cent ethanol-blended petrol in south-east Queensland in 2002.

Fuel ethanol has a number of important benefits. It is an environmentally friendly, renewable energy resource; it can supplement our dependence on increasingly expensive oil supplies and improve our nation’s energy security; and ethanol production from a range of agricultural crops, including wheat and sugarcane, would help diversify regional economies like my own in the Illawarra, help secure regional investment and create reasonable jobs.

In response to the argument that biofuels are too expensive, let me just say that as a nation we cannot afford to continue to ignore their substantial non-market benefits as we look to a sustainable future. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Between 1999 and 2004 the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority undertook an enormous and complex planning and consultative program to improve the zoning of the marine park. As an example of the scale of this interaction, over 31,000 submissions were received, which is approximately 33 times the number ever received for any other Great Barrier Reef Marine Park rezoning process. The effort, of course, was commensurate with the importance of the reef, and the eventual success of the whole program illustrates the maturity of community and environmental planning in Australia. It was a great outcome.

speech.para: There have been a small number of reactionaries who have been bitterly opposed to what GBRMPA has done in the interests of our World Heritage area and in the interests of our nation. It is disappointing to see that some of them are even suggesting that GBRMPA should be disbanded and taken back into the department. That would be a terrible outcome for the reef and for environmental protection in Australia.

I say to those reactionaries that I have here today two national awards which were presented this year to GBRMPA in recognition of the success of the project in connecting with a local, state, national and international community—the planning minister’s award presented to the authority for planning for the future of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park and the community based planning award. The planning minister’s award is a significant national recognition by planning peers, not influenced by government, of the tremendous effort that was put into the consultation and planning process of the representative area’s program. The leadership and the staff of GBRMPA are to be congratulated for winning these national awards. It shows that their process was proper, appropriate, timely and in the interests of our country. Congratulations GBRMPA.

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak on South Australia’s state defence sector plan. South Australia stands ready to help the nation meet its defence and security challenges into the future. The Premier, Mike Rann, has launched four groundbreaking plans covering the land force, aerospace, naval and defence electronic sectors, announcing a comprehensive commitment to lift capabilities and skills and to make the investments for the future. The centrepiece of the plan is its key commitments in South Australia’s bid to play the lead role in construction and through-life maintenance of the air warfare destroyers.

speech.para: The state government has made a commitment worth more than $100 million to invest in infrastructure and high technology skills that would allow the air warfare destroyers to be constructed to the highest standards. This commitment includes a 160-metre long shiplift, a state-of-the-art transfer system, a new 200-metre long wharf, and dredging around the shiplift and wharf to allow large ships to manoeuvre. This is a commitment to common user infrastructure. It would not be the property of one company. It is infrastructure that would be available to many companies and operations on a 90-hectare site that has massive potential for expansion. This is a modern solution to Australia’s shipbuilding challenges for the next 50 years.

But South Australia does not only have the best infrastructure; it has the strongest commitment to skills development. This commitment includes a maritime skills centre at Osborne to train up to 200 students and apprentices a year and a centre for excellence in defence industry systems capability to research new systems integration technologies and to help small and medium enterprises do more in systems and software. The case for South Australia also includes the lowest rate of industrial disputation on the Australian mainland, a just-agreed and pacesetting enterprise bargaining agreement and the independent conclusion of the Australian Industry Group that Adelaide is the most competitive manufacturing location in Australia.

This South Australian plan has been an exercise in bipartisanship. South Australia’s Defence Industry Advisory Board includes not just Premier Mike Rann and Deputy Premier Kevin Foley but the head of the state’s Economic Development Board, Robert Champion de Crespigny; former Liberal Defence minister Ian McLachlan; Malcolm Kinnaird; and retired senior naval officers David Shackleton and Kevin Scarce. Regardless of political persuasion, they have come together through a common conviction that South Australia represents a comprehensive and competitive solution to Australia’s defence challenges.

The Adelaide Advertiser recently ran a campaign highlighting that South Australia is the best option for the contract. This campaign has included the opportunity for readers to send in text messages in support of the bid. The response from the public has been extremely positive. The experts say that South Australia is the best place, and so do the people. We now all hope that the federal government will say the same. South Australia is indeed defence ready for Australia.

talker.name: Hunt, Gregory, MP
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Heritage
talker.name: Mr HUNT

talk.start.para: —It is time to end the dumping of raw and partially treated sewage off Sydney’s coastline. I say this with a view to the national environment and to the fact that what occurs in Sydney with the dumping of raw and partially treated sewage is a national disgrace. Sydney Water is Australia’s greatest polluter—and that is a factual statement. There is no other organisation which puts out two billion litres of raw sewage—not even primary sewage but raw sewage—directly off the coastline each year. There is no other organisation which puts out 400 billion litres of primary or partially treated sewage off the coastline of Australia every year. This is the 21st century, and a 19th century approach to wastewater is being used. It is an environmental disaster, it is a significant health risk and it is a monumental waste of water resources at a time when this country, in particular New South Wales, is desperately short of usable water.

speech.para: Firstly, we have the problem of the straight volume. Secondly, this chart, produced by the Water Services Association of Australia in 2003, shows that Sydney Water produces eight times the percentage of primary treated sewage of any other water organisation in Australia. Every other water organisation has dramatically higher levels of tertiary or secondary treatment. Only Sydney Water has 73 per cent of primary treatment or very partially treated sewage. The next worst, the Power and Water Corporation of the Northern Territory, has nine per cent. So Sydney Water is eight times worse than the next worst offender in Australia.

The solution is simple: Premier Bob Carr and the Minister for Energy and Utilities, Mr Sartor, must stop the practice of Sydney Water. They must allow for upgrading, for recycling and for that water to be used critically for industry and agriculture—for industry and agriculture but not for potable purposes. They cannot let Sydney Water stand in the way of private solutions. So the solution is simple: the Premier and Mr Sartor must compel Sydney Water to clean up its act or they must let others who are willing to do it do it. In the 21st century, there is no excuse for 19th century rampant environmental vandalism. The message is simple: clean up the coastline, end the dumping and reuse the water for industrial and agricultural purposes. Nothing else would make more of a difference to Sydney’s water supply. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I rise to share with the House the crisis of identity currently being experienced in my electorate of Newcastle. Under the Howard government, we are finding it hard to work out if we are regional, metropolitan or just lost in space. This week, the government announced that all regional offices of the Australian Securities and Investments Commission will close. Apparently, it is just too presumptuous for a regional city like Newcastle to want local financial services infrastructure. So five jobs will go, and the dozens of outraged businesses who contacted me will have to join the ‘virtual’ community online and be lost in space.

speech.para: It is perplexing for them, because in the budget this week the Treasurer announced a very welcome upgrade to broadband services in Newcastle under the metropolitan Blackspot program. I am not surprised that the Treasurer is confused. After all, anything outside the boardrooms of Melbourne or Sydney or the back benches of his leadership fantasy just does not compute at the moment. But the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts does a little better. After all, she is trying to convince regional Australia and her National Party colleagues to vote for the sale of Telstra. So back in April, she awarded a well-deserved grant to an IT consortium, led by the University of Newcastle, for a broadband backbone, smack through the middle of the city, under a scheme to improve access and services to rural, regional and remote Australia.

In April, the minister for rock solid, ironclad safety nets opened a new multidisciplinary resource centre at the University of Newcastle’s Department of Rural Health, located in Tamworth, operating from funding specifically reserved for improving regional health outcomes. So he thinks we are regional. And so does Minister Anderson, because he has let us access the Regional Assistance Program, the Dairy Regional Assistance Program, the Regional Solutions scheme and now the Regional Partnerships scheme. But it is ‘Lord’ Nelson that we have problems with: the Minister for Education, Science and Training says there is no way that we are regional. Our university is definitely metro to him. You see, we just do not follow orders very well in Newcastle. The University of Newcastle stubbornly ranks ninth on the national research tables. It includes three of the top 10 international researchers in its staff and it persists in trying to service its diverse region—from New England to Port Macquarie to Ourimbah. It persists in trying to provide those regional services well, but that has been very hard, with $120 million of funding having been ripped out and regional status denied to our university.

We are struggling financially and we are facing a cut of 450 jobs. I think Minister Nelson needs some advice. The people of Newcastle know who we are. We are a very proud and independent region. We are competing on the world stage with very little help from the Howard government. I suggest to ‘Lord’ Nelson that he stop playing his war games, restore regional funding to the University of Newcastle and save 450 jobs—or at least save the pain from such intensity by helping us to spread it out over three years. That is the least he could do.

talk.start.para: —The onset of cooler weather in Queensland signals one certainty: the start of our annual show circuit. In recent weeks I have travelled many kilometres visiting shows throughout the Hinkler Electorate, each and every one of them a colourful reflection of the character and talents present in regional towns. To date I have had the pleasure of attending Gayndah, Mount Perry, Monto, Eidsvold and Mundubbera shows, with more to come in the months ahead.

speech.para: Those of us from regional areas appreciate the sense of community fostered by local shows. They are a real showcase for the achievements of towns and districts, offering an insight into the best agricultural, handicraft and cultural capacity of a community, to say nothing of the superb livestock which benchmark local breeding standards and husbandry. Rural shows are a time for celebration. Town and country come together to celebrate, to compete and to enjoy such things as equestrian events, woodchopping, vintage parades, rodeos and open-air concerts against a backdrop of pavilions, sideshow alley and vehicle and equipment displays.

People who work throughout the year to coordinate entries, catalogues, judging, presentations, ring events and all those things that go together to make a good show and who work selflessly behind the scenes are really the unsung heroes. Over the year they put their hearts and souls into the logistics of maintenance, ring upkeep, catering facilities and—the bane of all show committees—insurance. They work unselfishly for the benefit of the wider community. On that note, in 2002 the coalition government invested $2 million in training show volunteers in areas such as show administration, finance, marketing, management and occupational health and safety. I know that support was very much appreciated.

The country show movement is one of Australia’s largest volunteer based organisations and has more than 400,000 financial members. I commend the work of these hardworking people and their committees and, in particular, the commitment of presidents and secretaries who run these shows. A big thank you goes to Monto Show president, Pat Bowles, and her secretary, Frank Goody; Eidsvold president, Stuart Hamilton, and secretary, Mary Nelson; Gayndah president, Gary Taylor, and secretary, Jeni Faulkner; Mundubbera president, Wally Benham, and secretary, Leanne Harvey; and Mount Perry president, Clive Wallace, and secretary, Margaret Clark. I salute them as an integral part of the fabric of country life.

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 11 May, on motion by Mr Truss:

motion.para: That the bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —The Civil Aviation Amendment Bill 2005 is very technical in nature. In the first part of my speech I will deal specifically with the technical aspects of the bill and I will then take the opportunity to look more broadly at safety within the civil aviation administration. In particular, I will deal with some aspects that relate—
—I remind the member for Blaxland that I gave a statement to the member for Batman yesterday that this is a very specific bill and I expect members to speak to the bill.

—That is what I just said I want to do, Mr Deputy Speaker, but I also indicated that I wish to speak a bit more broadly about changes to Bankstown which are affected by this bill. I also want to note the fact that a major development plan in relation to Bankstown has just been promulgated by the government and allowed to go through. Turning to the purpose of this bill, the fundamentals are that it will allow the making of regulations under the Civil Aviation Act that are inconsistent with antidiscrimination laws and it will retrospectively validate existing regulations that may be inconsistent with antidiscrimination laws where the inconsistency is necessary for the safety of air navigation.

speech.para: Across a range of portfolios it becomes necessary from time to time to consolidate the government’s approach, where there may be inconsistency. We have an antidiscrimination act and the courts may interpret the act—indeed, the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission may interpret the act that it is under and other acts that the government makes. This leads us to the point we are at with this legislation: if within civil aviation in terms of this bill you have a certain set of features which in other circumstances may be quite discriminatory, then it is necessary to take the action that is being taken with this bill, to ensure it is brought to book and regularised, so that what would otherwise be seen as antidiscriminatory activity has a context and cannot be knocked out.

The best example of this relates to the regulations about who can be air traffic controllers. Air traffic controllers come directly under the provisions of this bill. In the normal course of events, people would not think it very safe to have colourblind people operating as air traffic controllers, because there might be a significant safety dimension. People’s lives might be put at risk, because an air traffic controller would need to be able to distinguish, on the basis of discrimination between colours, between different aircrafts and code signals and so on. This is a very practical example of what this bill tries to fix. At the moment if someone says, ‘I want to be an air traffic controller but I’m colourblind. I think it’s discriminatory of the government and its agencies to use provisions to try to stop me from becoming an air traffic controller’—and they think there is a great deal of remuneration to be gained and they wish to get into that field—they can go to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission. This has recently been done within this context—and there is a separate provision for air traffic controllers in relation to pregnant women as well—so it is possible for an action to be brought. Without the safeguards in this bill, it would be possible for the department and the government to find themselves before the commission and possible for them to be forced to employ someone who is manifestly an inappropriate employee, given that the safety of the public could be prejudiced.

This bill should have been dealt with prior to the last election, but the prorogation of the parliament meant that it could not be. Because of the antidiscrimination matters involved, there was a consideration that the bill should be sent to the Senate for a deeper investigation, to make sure that the inconsistencies were not such that people were just being thrown out for no reason at all. An amendment has been incorporated within this current bill, after consideration, and the purpose now is not just to regularise the current situation in relation to civil aviation but to ensure that everyone using regional or major airports can depend upon air traffic controllers being able to keep them safe, without people challenging that very foundation.

Labor has argued—indeed it was argued before the Senate—that the regulations made under an act are generally constitutionally invalid if they are inconsistent with another act of parliament. We will find case after case where that is necessarily so. Generally there is a broad area where there is no meeting of two acts; there is no problem with the vast majority of acts. But specific types of legislation—racial discrimination legislation and the general antidiscrimination provisions of our acts—are a bit harder to deal with. This is because their compass is so great, dealing with all human beings in contact with all government departments. They need to be taken into account. If they are not taken into account properly, we can find ourselves in particular difficulty.

Regulations made under the Civil Aviation Act to ensure air safety may allow discrimination in the interest of air safety. As a general rule we would say that that should not be the case, and we have the global provisions of the antidiscrimination act to cover it. The regulations currently allow discrimination on the basis of colour blindness in relation to air traffic controllers. Other regulations require pregnant women to undergo medical tests in order to continue work as air traffic controllers. The base argument for putting in these directly discriminatory regulations is that—as all air traffic controllers with a great deal of experience would know—the stresses of the job of an air traffic controller are extreme. In order not only to ensure the proper work environment for controllers but also to ensure that people who fly from Sydney to Canberra or anywhere else around the joint are safe and secure, the legislators say: ‘Okay, we’re going to break the normal antidiscrimination provisions here, but there is a specific set of reasons for doing so.’

If it were just left at that, without this bill, that would be challengeable. Someone might go to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission and say, ‘I’m colourblind, it’s my right’—or ‘I’m a pregnant woman, it’s my right’—‘to try to become an air traffic controller,’ and they might well succeed. Here the government and the opposition are conjoined in trying to fix this problem.

A counterargument has been put in this debate that under any of the Commonwealth’s antidiscrimination acts such regulations would be valid if they related to the inherent requirements of a job or if there were a specific exemption given by the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission. So, according to that argument, the fail-safe mechanism would be either that there had already been a ruling by the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission on the specific provision or that people knew and could accept that the provision in relation to colour blindness, for instance, should be a sine qua non. You just cannot have people who are blind, for instance—not just colourblind—doing the job of an air traffic controller. If you had a blind air traffic controller, you might be in a lot of trouble. Almost everyone, you would think, would be able to accept that. So that argument says that either a specific provision or the general rule of what a reasonable man or woman would see in these purposes would mean that such regulations would be valid.

If that had been the case and that had been operative in this situation, we would not have needed the bill. But the argument behind this bill is that, where there is uncertainty, the Commonwealth should act to ensure the safety of the travelling public and to give certainty to those people who are operating in professions in the civil aviation area so that they know where they are going and they can get on with it sensibly.

In 2002 the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission granted a limited exemption with regard to this. That gave rise to the necessity to bring this bill into place. The concern is that current restrictions on air traffic controllers go beyond what are called the ‘inherent requirements’ of the job and therefore beyond the existing exemption granted by the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission. Concerns have also been voiced about the situation that lies behind this piece of legislation. Those concerns are that regulations restricting various licences to individuals on the basis of disabilities such as colour blindness or to women on the basis of pregnancy are not related to employment and therefore fall outside the general exemption, when the discriminating act is necessary to the inherent requirements of the job. So the worry here is that, where regulations have tried to specify colour blindness or pregnancy—blindness might be accepted—people may say: ‘This is just going too far. This is really trying to put in bars to employment. It’s about the people who are already in work, who are able to ensure that they stay there because they keep other people out and effectively have bars to entry.’

So, in order to be safe and secure, in order not only to come within the previous judgments of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission but also to be just plain safe, given those concerns, it was deemed necessary to pass this legislation, to ensure that regulations to ensure air safety were not struck down due to inconsistency with either the Sex Discrimination Act or the Disability Discrimination Act. I think the regulations are sound and sensible, and the Labor opposition in the Senate were in fact part of the majority of the Senate committee that recommended support for this bill, with the amendment that there should be consultation with the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission. I think that is sound, fair and reasonable.

The impact that this bill has in relation to my electorate is pretty clear and pretty direct. There are a number of air traffic controllers operating out of Bankstown Airport. Bankstown Airport is the biggest general aviation airport in the whole of the Southern Hemisphere. It has had more than 420,000 take-offs and landings per year, although over the last few years the amount of activity has decreased. One of the reasons for that decrease is that more people are choosing to go to cheaper places. There has also been a contraction in general aviation, and there has also been a great deal of argument about civil aviation safety because of the broader changes the government has made to the civil aviation regime. Mr Deputy Speaker Causley, you and other members would know that, for smaller aircraft flying out of country electorates into Bankstown or Kingsford Smith and coming under the control of the air traffic controllers this bill deals with in one of its aspects, there are new airspace regulations and a new approach to air safety. Bankstown, as the most significant civil aviation and general aviation airport within the Sydney region, has had a particular set of problems while there has been pressure to do away with air traffic controllers altogether. There are some people in general aviation who do not want to see them there. So, in terms of the provisions of this bill, the problem for them would not be colour blindness—

talk.start.para: (Hon. IR Causley)—Could the member for Blaxland indicate to me what clause that refers to in the bill? I do not want to restrict debate, but the standing orders are specific that you must speak to the bill and I do not think there is anything in the bill that refers to those regulations. Can you indicate the clause in the bill you are referring to?
—There is nothing in the bill that refers to specific regulations for air traffic controllers at Bankstown Airport, but inherently they will be affected by the provisions of this bill.
—I cannot accept that. This is a very simple bill and you must speak to the bill.
—Inherently those air traffic controllers will be affected by this, unless the situation is regularised.
—It is not a matter for debate, Member for Blaxland; it is a matter of the standing orders and speaking to the bill.

—I have spoken for 10 solid minutes—in fact, for 12½ minutes. When you look throughout the entire specifications of this bill and its explanatory memorandum, you could not argue that during all of that time I stepped one jot outside the provisions of the bill.
—Not until now. I did not interrupt the member for Blaxland until now.
—There was no reason to, I would think.
—If we are going to have a debate, I will call on the minister.

—I do not think there is any reason to. I come back to those people who work at Bankstown Airport as tower operators, who have been under a significant amount of pressure. The situation involved in this bill since 2002 has put those people under a further set of pressures. The determination in relation to their work as tower operators has been—

—Member for Blaxland, the bill is specific: it is about antidiscrimination. It is a specific bill. It is not to do with the tower operators at Bankstown Airport. If the member cannot come back to the bill, I will ask him to resume his seat and I will call the minister.
—I am coming back to the bill. Those people who work in the towers at Bankstown Airport are affected directly by this.
—The member for Blaxland will resume his seat. I call the Minister for Local Government, Territories and Roads.
—I rise on a point of order. What I was going to say in relation to those people is that they are affected by the specific provisions of the bill. If there is a question of colour blindness—
—That is not a point of order. The member for Blaxland will resume his seat.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. It is my understanding that the member for Blaxland is coming back to the point of the legislation and I request that you—
—The member for Shortland will resume her seat. The member for Blaxland was not making a point of order. In fact, he was continuing the debate.
Ms Hall interjecting—
—The member for Shortland will resume her seat! If the member for Blaxland wants to come to the leave of the bill, he can continue, but if he does not I will sit him down.

—I will come to it. The provisions of this bill relate, in one example, to colour blindness and, in another example, to a bar being placed on pregnant women from working as air traffic controllers at Kingsford Smith airport, Bankstown Airport or any other airport in Australia. The bill now before us and the provisions it contains are only there because uncertainty had arisen and because in 2002 the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission made a specific ruling on this matter. Air traffic controllers at Bankstown Airport and elsewhere have indicated that there is a significant problem for them because this issue is not resolved.

speech.para: If it were not the case that specific antidiscrimination provisions had been incorporated covering the way in which these people work and attempting to ensure the safety of the public, we would not be dealing with this bill. A Senate committee comprising government, opposition and Democrat senators would not have looked at the specific provisions of this bill. The minister would have determined that there was no reason to deal with tower operators at Bankstown, Dubbo, Orange, Kingsford Smith or any other airports. He would have determined that it was good enough to take a chance, to simply leave open the possibility that someone may or may not choose to take action against the Commonwealth. Even with the Sex Discrimination Act and the Disability Discrimination Act in operation, under the normal rules with regard to this bill it could be argued that the inherent requirements of the job in question should discriminate against people who are blind or deaf or colourblind or pregnant, that the normal provisions that are operating should in fact be put into place.

But anyone is capable of saying that these matters are discriminatory. These matters can be taken either to the courts or, at a cheaper rate, to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission and they can seek to enforce them. If these provisions were in place, they would affect the people working in the towers at Bankstown Airport and Kingsford Smith airport. It would lead to a situation where the government would not only be embroiled in attempting to deal with this legislatively; there would be a lot of money and time and effort wasted in terms of regularising this.

Every member of this parliament and every minister knows that, in the normal course of events, you do not have problems with one set of parliamentary acts coming over the top of others. Likewise, every person with experience in this area knows that, in relation to these two particular acts, the normal operations of business and activities can be foreshortened. I therefore commend the bill. It has the support of the opposition. (Time expired)

talker.name: Lloyd, Jim, MP
talker.role: Minister for Local Government, Territories and Roads
talker.name: Mr LLOYD

talk.start.para: —I would like to firstly thank the members for Oxley, Wakefield, Batman, Tangney and Shortland and the member for Blaxland, who, through your generous interpretation of relevance, Mr Deputy Speaker Causley, was able to complete his speech. I thank him for his support on the Civil Aviation Amendment Bill 2005.

speech.para: I am pleased that the opposition have supported this bill. It is an important bill and it will empower the Governor-General to make regulations that are inconsistent with the Disability Discrimination Act 1984 and the Sex Discrimination Act 1992 in relation to medical standards, where necessary, for the safety of air navigation. It will allow past actions and decisions taken under the existing regulations to stand, validate future actions and decisions taken under existing regulations, create a requirement in the act that the holders of an air operators certificate—an AOC—must continue to satisfy CASA that they meet the conditions in their AOC, and standardise references in the act to aircraft which are registered in countries other than Australia.

The bill also inserts a reference note into the DDA and the SDA to inform members of the public of the operations of the amendments to the Governor-General’s regulation-making powers that this bill is introducing. These amendments will address the current uncertainty in the Civil Aviation Act about whether certain aviation safety regulations or actions carried out in accordance with these regulations are inconsistent with either the sex discrimination or the disability discrimination legislation. The amendments proposed under the bill are required as the exemptions granted by the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission are for a limited period of five years and are not wide enough to ensure that aviation safety requirements are not unreasonably constrained by sex discrimination and disability discrimination legislation.

The existing regulations affected by this bill, largely medical standards for flight crew and provisions relating to the seating of a disabled passenger in an aircraft, have been in place for many years. I must emphasise that any new regulations that will be inconsistent with the sex discrimination or the disability discrimination legislation will be subject to clearance by the Human Rights Branch of the Attorney-General’s Department. As with all the regulations developed by the Civil Aviation Safety Authority, CASA, such regulations would undergo some of the most comprehensive consultation procedures used by any Commonwealth agency and naturally are subject to parliamentary scrutiny. The effect of the retrospective provisions in the bill is to validate past actions taken or rulings made by CASA that are potentially inconsistent with the sex discrimination and disability discrimination acts.

No-one will find themselves in a worse position than they were in under the laws as previously administered and understood. The parliament and the public need have no fear that this amendment will enable the making of unreasonable discriminatory regulations. The bill limits the extent of the inconsistency to situations where it is necessary for the safety of air navigation. This will provide a safeguard to protect individuals from conditions that are unnecessarily restrictive. By clarifying the Governor-General’s regulation-making powers, the bill will make Australia’s civil aviation regulatory framework simpler and easier to understand and use. This bill is necessary to maintain the high standards of aviation safety that Australia enjoys. I commend the bill to the House.
Question agreed to.
Bill read a second time.
Ordered that the bill be reported to the House without amendment.

debate.para: Debate resumed from 10 May, on motion by Mr Abbott:

motion.para: That the House take note of the document.

talk.start.para: —Both the Prime Minister and the Leader of the Opposition have spoken effectively about reasons why Australia should remember this crucial anniversary of the end of World War II in Europe and why we should honour the approximately one million Australian women and men who served in our armed forces during the war, especially the 27,000 Australians who died defeating fascism in Europe and the Pacific. The generation which lived through World War II is now growing elderly. The last veterans of the war to serve in this House, Tom Uren and Clarrie Millar, retired 15 years ago. But the war, and the crimes committed by the Nazis and the Japanese fascists during the war, continue to cast a long shadow over our lives. Our victory in World War II was not only a paradigm of a victory in a just war; it still casts a long personal shadow. For instance, in my own case, thanks to two thoughtful young Germans who run an institution called the Max Samuel House in Rostock in the German state Mecklenburg, I now know—as I have told the House previously—that both my paternal grandparents died in Auschwitz in 1943. This is a heritage unfortunately shared by many thousands of Australians.

speech.para: Last Sunday I attended a very moving ceremony at the great new Visitors Centre at the Shrine of Remembrance in Melbourne, where more than 70 elderly survivors of the war, migrants to Australia from the former Soviet Union, were honoured by the Russian government with 60th anniversary medals. The Acting Governor of Victoria, Lady Southey AM, and the Victorian Minister for Finance, the Hon. John Lenders, were the guests of honour. Many of those who were honoured were survivors of labour camps, had fought with partisans and had lost members of their families at the front in Hitler’s pitiless war against Soviet citizens. Men and women accepted these decorations in memory of their murdered families, often with very emotional short speeches, many including the word ‘pamyat’—memory. I know there are many more Australians of many backgrounds who have suffered through similar circumstances and this anniversary was an opportunity—in many places, the last opportunity—to honour and thank them for their sacrifices.

This function was one of the series of events in Melbourne to mark the 60th anniversary of victory, many of which I had the honour of helping to organise. On 1 May the Russian Ambassador, His Excellency Leonid Moiseev, and I welcomed 2½ thousand people to Hamer Hall at the Victorian Arts Centre. We were treated to an elegant concert in honour of the veterans of World War II from the ex-Soviet Union and also of Australian servicemen who served on the Arctic convoys to Murmansk resupplying the Soviet Union. Emma Lippa, a former artistic director of the Bolshoi Ballet, was the artistic director of the event. All the artists, including the dancers from the Australian Ballet and singers from the Australian Opera, donated their time and created a sparkling evening which was greatly enjoyed by everyone who was there and which properly honoured the many veterans who were present.

Also last week the Russian veterans in Melbourne held two other functions, a public meeting at the Caulfield Town Hall and a banquet at the St Kilda Town Hall, and I had the opportunity to speak to both events. More than 500 people attended each of these occasions. Roman Mirkus of the Shalom Association and Meer Khanazov, President of the Victorian Association of World War II Veterans of the ex-Soviet Union, must be congratulated for their heroic efforts in organising these events. I would also like to thank the City of Glen Eira and the City of Port Phillip for their assistance in providing the town halls free and my own office staff, who spent an incredible amount of time organising. I would also like to thank parliamentary colleagues, including the honourable member for Goldstein, Andrew Robb; the member for Throsby, Jennie George; Senator Mark Bishop; and Mr Tony Lupton, the member for Prahran, all of whom attended these functions and spoke to the veterans and other guests. The honourable member for Throsby, Jennie George, is the only member of this House who speaks Russian and her speech and presence were extremely well received.

talk.start.para: Mr Hunt interjecting—

—Maybe there is another one too—but I am talking about speaking Russian as a native speaker! Mention of the Soviet Union reminds us of the broader political questions raised by this anniversary. The Soviet Union was our ally in World War II and the 25 million Soviet citizens who died in that war were part of the enormous price paid by the people of that country to destroy Hitler’s armies on the Eastern Front. Without the contribution of the Soviets it is hard to see how the Allies could have won the war. Indeed, at the concluding ceremony in the St Kilda Town Hall I said that the Hitler regime was in fact crushed under the heels of the armies of Rokossovsky, Koniev and Zhukov.

speech.para: Stalin’s regime was every bit as oppressive as Hitler’s, and Stalin’s collectivisation and deliberate famine in the twenties and his purges of the thirties probably killed as many people as died in the Shoah. Stalin’s victory allowed him to reoccupy the Baltic States and impose communist regimes on Poland and other states and eastern and central Europe as well as parts of eastern Germany. Thus our alliance with Stalin had dire consequences for millions of people, consequences which were not reversed until the fall of the Soviet Union in 1991.

This serves to remind us that the people of the 1930s and 1940s did not have any of the luxuries of easy choices. They had a choice between evils. Many millions of people were faced with a stark choice between Hitler and Stalin. I know a number of people in my electorate who served in the Red Army or in the communist controlled Polish Army based in the Soviet Union even though they hated Stalin and communism. In fact practically all of them did. But they knew that while Stalin was an oppressive dictator he was not bent on genocide, as Hitler was. They knew that a rational choice between relative evils required a decision to support the Soviet war effort as the only means of destroying the Hitler regime and saving what could be saved of all the peoples Hitler was bent on exterminating.

Similar choices faced the leaders of Western democracies. Britain and Australia went to war in September 1939 in the defence of the independence of Poland. We did so in the context of the Molotov-Ribbentrop Pact, a disgraceful alliance between German Nazism and Soviet communism, which prolonged the war as Winston Churchill and many other world leaders like Franklin Roosevelt protested at the time.

By the end of the war Poland was under Soviet occupation. While it was technically independent, it was ruled for the next 40 years by a hated communist regime controlled from Moscow. This was an inevitable consequence of the victory of the Red Army on the eastern front. The Allies could not have it both ways: they could not gain the benefits of a vast commitment of lives made by the Soviets, which destroyed the cream of the German army—indeed, 75 per cent of all of the Germans killed and all of the equipment destroyed, 600 divisions, were on the eastern front—without accepting the consequences of the Soviet occupation of eastern and central Europe.

Churchill and Roosevelt have both been criticised for their acquiescence at Yalta to Stalin’s domination of Poland, but it is difficult to understand what they could have done with him in full physical control of that country. The only way the Russians could have been moved or evicted was by a new and even more terrible war between the Western powers and the Soviet Union. Such an idea was unthinkable in 1945. There was no way that the peoples of Britain, the United States or Australia would have supported a confrontation over Poland with Uncle Joe, as he was thought of at the time, our glorious ally against Hitler.

Churchill always had a clear understanding of the importance of the Soviet alliance for the Allied war effort. When Hitler invaded the Soviet Union in June 1941, in a great speech, which I urge all members to read, Churchill at once committed Britain to supporting the Soviets, even though he himself had led attempts to strangle the Soviet regime at birth. He said:

quote.para: Noone has been a more consistent opponent of communism than I have ... I will unsay no words that I’ve spoken about it.
We have one aim and one single irrevocable purpose. We are resolved to destroy Hitler and every vestige of the Nazi regime.
Any man or State who fights against Nazism will have our aid.
It follows, therefore, we shall give whatever help we can to Russia and to the Russian people.

speech.para: There is no doubt that this was a sound judgment. It was part of Churchill’s genius that he was able to soar above his own ideological sympathies and make and articulate such a clear-headed strategic decision so quickly.

Australia played a crucial role in seeing the defeat of Nazism. It was present at one of the great turning points of the Second World War. As the opposition leader, Kim Beazley, pointed out on Tuesday: when the Ninth Division was present at the Battle of El Alamein—the crucial turning point of the Second World War in the Western Desert—it was, despite the vast superiority of Montgomery over Rommel, absolutely crucial in finally clearing through the minefields and allowing the British armed forces to pass through. Without their presence, it is quite possible that that battle would not have been won. It says a lot about the Labor leadership of the time that they accepted their internationalist responsibilities, as well as having regional concerns by bringing the Sixth and Seventh Divisions back to Australia. You can do both at the same time—walk and chew gum.

I note in passing that Churchill’s generational successor as British Prime Minister, Tony Blair, has shown a similar grasp of strategic realities. An Atlanticist and a convinced European, he has not hesitated to align himself with the United States and place Britain in the frontline of the war against terrorism. He saw at once after the September 11 attacks that this was an attack on the whole democratic world and the kind of open and secular societies that the West has built in the wake of World War II—in fact, an attack on the idea of social democracy that both the British Labour Party and the Australian Labor Party stand for. Although his decision to align himself with President Bush was unpopular with parts of his own party, he carried the day and has won a third term as Prime Minister, something even Churchill could not manage.

At the recent election, the Conservatives, advised by Mr Lynton Crosby from the Liberal Party of Australia, ran a disgraceful campaign against Tony Blair, aligning themselves with the extreme Left, accusing Blair of being a liar while at the same time seeking to exploit racist sentiments with their attacks on gipsies, travellers and immigrants. This campaign was particularly disgusting coming from the Conservative Party leader, Michael Howard, whose own father, Bernat Hecht, arrived in Britain as a Jewish refugee from fascist Romania in 1939. The British people saw through this tawdry scare campaign and re-elected Tony Blair. Michael Howard has quite rightly resigned. Tony Blair is a colossus amongst world leaders. He combines a humane social democratic philosophy with a firm determination to defend democratic and liberal values against theocratic terrorism. I take this opportunity to congratulate him on his election. His victory is a victory for the kind of society we fought to preserve in the great victory of World War II.

talker.name: Hunt, Gregory, MP
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Heritage
talker.name: Mr HUNT

talk.start.para: —In commemorating the anniversary of the end of the European war, within the great Second World War, we remember the story of three things. We remember the story of the Holocaust and the extermination of civilians and free peoples throughout Europe; we remember the sacrifice of all of those who stood against the attempt to bring an entire continent and the entire Western Hemisphere under subjugation, particularly those brave Australian soldiers who fought in the conflict, and their families and the legacy that flows from them; and we remember the lessons about standing firm against tyranny, about the way in which we have to help turn our enemies into allies—remembering the postwar reconstruction effort—and our own responsibilities within our own society.

speech.para: Turning to the first of those, when I was 18 I lived in Israel for a year. During the course of that period, I visited the Holocaust museum, Yad Vashem, in Jerusalem. I also visited Dachau, the former Nazi concentration camp, just north of Munich, which has been turned into a memorial. I also knew many people on the kibbutz on which I lived who still carried with them tattoos on their forearms from the concentration camps. These were the survivors.

All these three things taught me about the six million souls that were lost in the concentration camps of Europe. They taught me about the way in which a particular people survived that experience and passed through it, how they learned to reconstruct their lives and also how they put together an absolutely unshakeable desire never, ever to forget the memory of their parents and grandparents and the lessons they had learnt about standing firm against those who would exterminate, those who would base decisions on race and those who would typecast people by nationality or religion or any other generalised combination.

So there were six million souls lost from the civilian population of the Jewish community, but there were many others. According to the work of Alan Bullock—in Hitler and Stalin—a total of 40 million people were lost during the course of the Second World War. So firstly I wish to remember those who were lost during the Holocaust, not just the Jewish people but also the many others, whether they were Roma or people from different minority groups, who were selected and specifically targeted by the most brutal form of genocide.

Beyond the genocide there was a strategic conflict for total control of the Western and Eastern Hemispheres. What we see is that there was a plan, calculated in cold thought and executed in cold blood. It involved the Russian steppes on the one hand, central Europe and western Europe on the other. That battle was not won without enormous sacrifice; it was not won without the resolution of the leaders and the communities who fought against it. The Australian contribution, which involved almost a million men and women, was an integral part of that. Australian soldiers played a critical role not just within the Pacific but in parts of Europe and in particular, most famously, in the Middle East. El Alamein, Tobruk—all of these are names which live on within Australia.

Twenty-seven thousand Australian lives were lost during the course of World War II, and eleven thousand of those were lost within the European theatre. It was a brutal loss and their legacy is something we remember today. We see it in our RSLs, we see it with the families and we see it with the recovery and emergence of a national recollection of the sacrifice made not just by the diggers of World War I but by the soldiers of World War II and those who have since followed them.

What we saw with World War II was the defining conflict of the 20th century—not the only conflict, but the defining conflict. It was a singular attempt to control the entire Western Hemisphere as well as the resources of the Eastern Hemisphere. Without the leadership of Churchill, Roosevelt and so many others, without the contributions of Australia and other members of the Commonwealth, and without the sacrifice of the soldiers themselves and their families, the world that we face today would have been a very different world. There were many hardships to follow, not least the entire subjugation of Eastern Europe under Stalin and his successors. But that battle was won primarily through cold conflict, through a resolution which continued from the sacrifices of the Second World War and which indicated that there were people willing to meet those sacrifices to protect freedoms.

That brings me to the third element of history which we must remember at this point in time, and that is the moral and strategic lessons of the war in Europe. To my mind, there are three lessons. The first is that we can never allow rampant tyranny to be unchecked. There are many who will disagree with the conflict in Iraq, for example, but that was a case of rampant tyranny unchecked—it involved one of the great dictators and exterminators of the latter part of the 20th century. There was a moral equivalence there of what was occurring in the midperiod of the century. So I respect those who disagree, but I respectfully put to them that this was a case of a society which was ruled by utter tyranny, utter brutality and an unflinching willingness to exterminate anybody who stood for freedom, basic dignity or humanity.

The second of the moral and strategic lessons is that we must play a critical role in reconstruction. The work of the Western powers after the Second World War in bringing together the Marshall Plan, which assisted in the reconstruction of Western Europe, and in the assistance that we gave in Japan helped reconstruct those societies that were implacable foes during the Second World War but which today are integral parts of the Western Hemisphere. They are tremendously strong and functioning democracies, and they are friends and allies. They stand against everything which was perpetrated and which was sought during the Second World War. So reconstruction is critical and it tells us about our role as we begin the 21st century.

The third thing is a cautionary tale to ourselves. Now we face, primarily, a non-state based form of threat. It is not the classic ideology linked with state control; it is a non-state based form of threat in terror. The other lesson which we have to bring to ourselves is to note that we cannot clamp down on all our freedoms. We cannot let ourselves be drawn into exactly the sort of outcome these terrorists wish to bring. The other great lesson is that we must protect the freedoms within our own society. In ensuring that we are able to confront the terrorists, we should not lay waste to those freedoms which are integral to who we are and which are the very things we seek to protect. So, in seeking to ensure the security of our society, we must be ever vigilant not to undermine the key tenets and freedoms which are fundamental to it.

In summary, I wish to record my recollection for all those families and people who lost souls in the Holocaust. I wish to record my debt of thanks, that of members of my family and members of the electorate of Flinders to all those who served Australia and to all those who lost friends and family in serving Australia during the Second World War. There are key moral and strategic lessons from the Second World War which we cannot forget. If we forget them, we dishonour those who served in that time.

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak on the 60th anniversary of VE Day, the copy of the motion of thanks by the Prime Minister and the motion that the House take note of this document. I do so acknowledging that the motion notes the 60th anniversary of VE Day and I pay tribute to all that that encompasses. I take the opportunity to endorse the words of the Leader of the Opposition in the House earlier this week, when he spoke in great detail and with great passion on this motion. I associate myself entirely with those comments.

speech.para: Today, however, I want to spend the time that I have speaking about the tragic death of nine Australian service personnel on 2 April, when a Navy Sea King helicopter crashed in the remote west coast region of Nias in Indonesia. I had in fact expected that a stand-alone condolence motion would have afforded me and other members an opportunity to refer to this tragedy. However, the government determined that this was not to be the case, and I have been advised that this is the appropriate place for me to say these words. I do that sadly because I think it would have been appropriate to seriously consider a stand-alone condolence motion. Be that as it may, I take this opportunity.

The Sea King helicopter had been working off the HMAS Kanimbla, carrying an emergency medical team to the village of Amandraya when this accident occurred. This work was part of a humanitarian effort following a devastating earthquake that had hit the region days before. The Kanimbla had only just reached this area, having been diverted from Singapore where the crew had been enjoying some shore leave following three months of what can only be described as wonderful, dedicated emergency aid work in the tsunami affected region of Aceh. I know that all of us in the House applaud very much the response and the work done in that area by everybody associated with the Kanimbla at that time.

When this accident occurred, sadly and tragically nine members of the ADF were killed, while two survived. Those who lost their lives were Flight Lieutenant Lyn Rowbottom and Sergeant Wendy Jones, both of Queensland, and seven male members: Squadron Leader Paul McCarthy of Western Australia; Lieutenant Matthew Goodall of New South Wales; Lieutenant Jonathan King of Queensland; Petty Officer Stephen Slattery and Leading Seaman Scott Bennet, both of New South Wales; and—sadly, from the point of view of my community—Lieutenant Paul Kimlin and Lieutenant Mathew Davey, both from the ACT.

I want to mention in particular the two Canberrans who lost their lives in this tragic accident, Lieutenant Mathew Davey and Lieutenant Paul Kimlin. In doing so, I refer to comments that were made in a variety of reports that appeared in the Canberra Times at the time of the accident. Navy doctor Lieutenant Mathew Davey who died in this accident received a United Nations Force Commander’s Commendation for his work as part of a resuscitation team in East Timor. Lieutenant Kimlin, who was 29, joined the Navy as a pilot in March 1996. He received his wings in 1998 after graduating from pilot school and was posted to HMAS Albatross base in Nowra before going to Indonesia with the HMAS Kanimbla, where he was one of the five Sea King pilots. He also served in East Timor, Christmas Island and Iraq and he flew in support of many national rescue missions.

We may remember also—and I know I do, because I watched it with great interest at the time—that Lieutenant Kimlin appeared in the Anzac Day special on the ABC TV program Enough Rope last year. He told the Canberra Times about two months ago that he and other service men and women aboard Kanimbla had been working long, hard hours as part of the relief effort but had been enjoying it. ‘People are happy to be up here lending a hand and doing what we can,’ he was reported as saying.

Navy doctor Lieutenant Mathew Davey was a 31-year-old intensive care registrar who was also one of the nine killed. He was attached to the hospital community here in Canberra, and the hospital community and members of the military gathered at a memorial service at the Canberra Hospital to pay tribute to Dr Davey and to share their grief over his sudden death. His partner of 10 years, Rachel Henson, also works at the Canberra Hospital as a nurse.

Hospital deputy general manager, Mark Bassett, said the community had been hit extremely hard by Dr Davey’s death. Defence Health Services Director General, Air Commodore Tony Austin, said Lieutenant Davey had helped write history as part of the team caring for survivors of the Boxing Day tsunami in Aceh. Co-workers of his believed that his towering intelligence, his photographic memory and analytical mind had made him a great scientist and that his compassion and empathy made him a great doctor. Director of emergency medicine, Professor Drew Richardson, said that he was a brilliant young man who would be sadly missed and that the community had lost one of its most promising doctors.

A number of communities around Australia have been affected by this tragedy. They have felt the deaths of these service personnel in a direct and personal way. My community of Canberra has deeply felt the deaths, in particular, of Lieutenant Davey and Lieutenant Kimlin. While a tragedy like this makes national and world headlines, it is also to be remembered that ordinary people—family members, colleagues, work mates and loved ones—suffer an enormous and life-changing impact as well.

I have also noted some debate in the media during the period of reporting on this incident about the issue of compensation and other related issues that come to the fore at times like this. I believe this debate has been with us for some years, and our side of politics will continue to monitor these issues while media comment continues. I urge the government to be in a situation where that debate is no longer a part of a tragedy such as this. It would be nice to think that we did not have to have those debates.

I also want to draw to the attention of the Main Committee a publication put out regularly by the Navy called Navy News. It has put out an eight-page special edition on this particular tragedy. I am happy to make that available to any members of the chamber who would like to look at it and read some of the testimony and comments made not only by work mates but also by the broader naval community as we consider this awful tragedy. Can I say to the crew of HMAS Kanimbla, to the work mates and the colleagues of those who died, and to the families and loved ones of those who died that we all send our sincere condolences. Particularly, as the member for Canberra, I want to say to the families, the loved ones and the friends of Lieutenant Kimlin and Lieutenant Davey that, on behalf of the community of the electorate of Canberra, we send our heartfelt sympathy to them.

It is interesting to be talking about this tragedy in a debate on a motion regarding the 60th anniversary of VE Day. Obviously it is always of note and always of importance to us when commemorating anniversaries involving VE Day, Anzac Day, the Vietnam War and so on to remember those who have served this country in times of conflict and who have, as the saying goes, paid that ultimate price with their life. However, this is different, because these people were, at the request of the government and the people of Australia, performing a different service where they were providing wonderful humanitarian aid at a time when people in the affected area in Indonesia desperately needed to get that aid. As I have said, Lieutenant Kimlin himself was quoted as saying that they would rather be nowhere else than to be there doing the job they had to do. What a tragedy to think that they lost their lives in the way that they did. I am sure all members of the chamber would join me in sending our condolences to all of the families concerned. On my own behalf and on behalf of the electorate that I represent, I send our very warm, heartfelt sympathy to the families of the two Canberrans affected.

talk.start.para: —It is an honour to speak to this motion to commemorate VE Day and the end of war in Europe 60 years ago. As previous speakers have pointed out—and the Prime Minister and the Leader of the Opposition both made eloquent contributions—the end of that conflict 60 years ago this week meant so much on so many levels. Most obviously it was the end of 5½ years of horrific war in Europe, the scale of which had never been seen before. Many have spoken of the monumental loss of life right across the globe and the sacrifice made by Australia. On another level, the joy at the end of that war was very much tempered by the fact that we were still at war on our doorstep, in the Pacific, and that there were still more sacrifices to be made in the coming months before Australia would finally see a conclusion to the hostilities.

speech.para: On another level, those who went to war 50 and 60 years ago were in so many ways like the Anzacs of the First World War. We have heard much of that in the days since Anzac Day, and they went to war in that great tradition: to defend the principles and freedoms that the Anzacs had defended. They displayed the same mateship and those great Australian characteristics, but they were different in many ways too. Unlike the original Anzacs, they went with no illusions. We have heard from previous speakers about the tragedy of the Second World War coming 20 years after the Great War. The difference between those going to the Second World War and those who went to the First World War was that those who fought in the Second World War knew exactly what they were getting into. They had grown up in the aftermath of the First World War—their fathers, uncles and family members having been killed or maimed in the First World War. They did not leave our shores with the romanticism that the first Anzacs had. They did not leave with that innocent curiosity; they left knowing that war was a bloody, costly business. They did not think it was an adventure at all. It was a war that was horrific in scale.

While Europe rightly celebrated VE Day and the surrender of Germany, we were just beginning to understand the true horror of the Holocaust. The member for Melbourne Ports spoke eloquently on that subject, and on that issue he spoke for us all. The Holocaust was unimaginable and will never be forgotten. The Jewish community and survivors of the Holocaust who came to Australia make a wonderful contribution to our nation’s culture and help us to ensure that the memory never dies.

The war still raged in the Pacific. It was clear that, with the defeat of Germany and the great advances in the Pacific, Australia was reaching the beginning of the end as far as the war was concerned, but there were still great sacrifices to be made. It is on important anniversaries like Anzac Day, VE Day and Remembrance Day that we remember the sacrifices that were made. It is great to see more and more Australians recognising Anzac Day not just at Gallipoli, which is very welcome, but at Anzac Day services in local communities. We all see that in, for example, Kooyong, Melbourne Ports and Parramatta, and we see it in local schools. That is vital, and it is something that those who made the sacrifice would be very proud of: that the cost of war and the principles for which they fought are never forgotten.

That is something that was very much on the minds of members of this House 60 years ago. On Tuesday, in between meetings, I had the luck to be accidentally listening to the Parliamentary and News Network when they replayed the very first motion, close to midnight, when Ben Chifley announced that Germany had surrendered. If I heard correctly, it was the very first continuous public broadcast from our parliament. There are a number of things about that debate, which I have taken the time to look at, that really stand out. One was the true bipartisan warmth for John Curtin, who could not speak, because he was gravely ill. The other—while there was certainly joy at the end of hostilities in Europe—was the real recognition that there was still a great Australian sacrifice to be made against Japan.

When you look at that debate and the speeches from Chifley, Menzies and Fadden, you see that warmth for Curtin and that understanding that he had made a great sacrifice as Prime Minister. It is a very moving debate to read because—Menzies, of course, was Prime Minister at the start of the war and Fadden was Prime Minister for a short time—they had each been touched by the conflict and they were all there, with the exception of Curtin, on the day that Germany surrendered. Fadden really summed up the sacrifice. At the very conclusion of his speech he said:

quote.para: Never again must our women be subjected to the sorrows, our sons to the perils of the last five years. We as the United Nations, and we as Australians, as one of the United Nations, must subordinate everything in the future to ensuring that peace is always maintained, by the goodwill of free peoples—

speech.para: A division having been called in the House of Representatives—

interrupt.para: Sitting suspended from 11.02 am to 11.15 am

talk.start.para: —As I was saying, the debate in 1945—60 years ago—in the House of Representatives sums up the feelings and emotions of those former Prime Ministers and members of parliament. I have quoted Mr Fadden on the sacrifice caused by the war. Mr Chifley—who, as I said earlier, was moving the motion because the then Prime Minister, John Curtin, was ill—summed up in great language the challenge that lay ahead and what VE Day meant from an Australian perspective. It meant that we had achieved a great deal, the sacrifice having been great, but there was still a lot more to do, including with the war in the Pacific, which was much closer to home and much more immediate to Australia.

speech.para: On that night 60 years ago, Mr Chifley said:

quote.para: For us, thanksgiving and rejoicing are tempered by the stern reminder that that other enemy—that assassin that struck at Pearl Harbour and Manila and Malaya—still remains. The Japanese still occupy territory that is Australia’s responsibility.

speech.para: He went on to say:

quote.para: In countless prison camps are Australians who fought their way down Malaya to Singapore. They must and shall be freed.

speech.para: Following him, the former Prime Minister and then Leader of the Opposition, Bob Menzies, said in the same light that thanksgiving and rejoicing were tempered by that stern reminder. In a similar way, he congratulated Mr Chifley. Bob Menzies said:

quote.para: In the months that remain for Japan, we have heavy tasks—to destroy the power and tyranny of the Prussians of the Far East, to release thousands of our people from bitter captivity, and to build a better world upon the ashes of the greatest war in history.

speech.para: That debate at that time meant so much to Australia, but there were still many more months to go and a great sacrifice for Australia to make before the end of the war in the Pacific, which occurred later in that September.

As we reflect on the sacrifice that is made in war—and we do so in this motion; so far, all speakers on the motion have done that—we tend to focus on the awful totality of the statistics: the millions of people killed in a particular year and the thousands killed in battles. That tells us much about the sacrifice, but it does not tell us everything. In conclusion, I just want to reflect on the cost of war to individual communities—and that is something that, as members of parliament, we all get a chance to reflect on. I do not think the scale of things can be properly interpreted and comprehended until we look at communities and people individually as well. World War II scoured so many nations, including Australia, but it also scoured many communities.

Just before Anzac Day I was honoured to attend a ceremony and give an address at the Monbulk Primary School. They were remembering every former student of that school who had served in the conflicts in Australia’s history. It gave me cause to reflect on the sacrifice in Monbulk and the sacrifice of those former students of Monbulk Primary School. It was a small school at the turn of the century, but 21 locals from Monbulk fought at Gallipoli and 13 of them had been students of the school.

You can look at the history of the First World War in that light—and it is abundant in the writings of CEW Bean, Australia’s foremost historian of the First World War. He wrote of the 10th Light Horse Regiment, which comprised the sons of Western Australian farmers who had volunteered with their own horses and saddles. Half of that entire regiment was wiped out in just a couple of seconds in Gallipoli. That meant, of course, that in a few seconds that Western Australian community had lost both their young and their future—and that story was repeated in many towns and communities right across Australia in the First World War and the Second World War. I mention that because in the Second World War the story was often repeated in the same families. Fathers had died or been injured and their sons went on to fight and die in the Second World War for the very same principles.

It is those people that we remember on this 60th anniversary of VE Day. We remember the sacrifice those people made and the principles for which they fought. For all of those Australians who lost their lives in the Second World War, I think we can safely say that they would be relieved to know that the Australia they grew up in and defended, a free and democratic nation, is still very much that and is truly the envy of the world.

talk.start.para: —Nothing in life is certain, whether for individuals, countries, nation-states or empires. There are no fundamental, underlying certainties that guarantee definite outcomes. On Anzac Day and other days of remembrance, our concentration is on the First World War, the lessons learnt from the First World War and the suffering of Australian troops and others—the 60,000 Australian dead from that conflict.
