But in the popular mind and in popular storytelling in Australia there is a fixation on the things that emerged from the First World War and on the notion that it was the war to end all wars.

speech.para: Time and time again, I have heard people make the comment on Anzac Day that that was what the First World War was about—it was the war to end all wars. That is a catchphrase that attempted to grab the essence of people’s hope about that dreadful conflict—a conflict which saw so many people’s lives entirely destroyed. Empires that had proudly stood crumbled before people’s eyes and new forces emerged. For example, the Russian Revolution occurred in October 1917, cracking open the Russian empire. Communities and peoples that were relatively whole at the start were shattered unbelievably. That catchphrase—the war to end all wars—allowed people to grab for the hope that maybe everything that happened there might not happen again.

Often people then say, ‘The Second World War was inevitable. It arose’—and there is a good historical argument for this—‘out of the conditions of the making of the Treaty of Versailles and out of the conditions in which the losers lost in the First World War.’ That has a great deal more validity than some of the other theories.

I am grateful for the fact that in this national parliament we are, shortly after the 60th anniversary of Victory in Europe Day, debating and taking note of the victory in Europe, because there are few opportunities really, even in this talking shop of our national parliament, to think about, muse about, talk about or relate our understanding of what our history is composed of and the sufferings that Australians and others went through in the great conflicts of the 20th century. Because of the capacity of new technologies developed in that industrial century, the level of damage, destruction, death, bloodshed and sheer suffering encountered by people was incomparable. There was the associated level of suffering through the Russian Revolution, fascism in Germany and Italy, and communism in China. Tens of millions of people had their lives destroyed in those instances. We see in the Second World War—the signal outpost at the end of that period—something that for many is its fundamental message: the six million people who were consigned to oblivion simply because they were Jewish. There had been pogroms before, particularly in France, against the Jewish people. There had been pogroms in Russia. But this pogrom was unequalled in its extent, in the method with which the Nazi regime pursued it and in its underlying basis.

If you just think in catchphrases, you particularly get stuck on the First World War. In our public speaking we tend to glide over World War II and glide over Korea, Vietnam and the depth of the conflict that the Australian soldiers and people were involved in. You cannot capture the immensity of what happened in the Second World War. The fact is that, for all that World War I was noted as the First World War, it involved most of the nations around the world simply because the extent of empires was so great. The Second World War was the first truly world war that we have seen, encompassing not just the entire planet but also individual nation-states—who were forced to put not only the lives of their individual soldiers at hazard with bullets, machine gun mortars, artillery shells and bombardment but also the lives of the totality of their populations. This is the first war known to humankind where the totality of the populations of the combatants were involved in that war. This is indeed the first total war that mankind has been involved in. That was brilliantly covered in all of its elements in a book entitled Total War by Peter Calvocoressi. He attempts to encompass just how great the scale of this conflict was.

In terms of Australia fitting into this, we have to ask a couple of different questions and seek to look at things in a different way to the way that we normally do. I am happy to follow the previous members who have spoken in this debate, in particular the member for Casey. He concentrated many of his remarks on the manner in which Australia conducted itself and the manner in which Prime Minister Curtin undertook the leadership of Australia during that period. There have been debates in this chamber around VE Day and its significance for Australia. We all know that this was really the making of a new country. The tendency in the mythology of Australia is to associate the growth in nationhood purely with the Gallipoli campaign, forgetting Australia’s part in the Boer War and the fighting in the Sudan. Yet the people who fought in those other conflicts had the same temper, the same character and the same desire to be part of their empire’s struggles—as Australia was still part of the British Empire at that time—and they hazarded their lives. Nevertheless, the crucible of nationhood has always been taken to be the Gallipoli campaign.

Australia’s nationhood should not be measured by that. Nationhood is a much broader thing. It is not just confined to warfare but to social conditions and the way in which a society develops. It is also a question of the context in which things develop. The colony of New South Wales and other colonies developed into a modern federated Australian nation on 1 January 1901. That nation was forced by dint of circumstance into the First World War and then by dint of circumstance into the Second World War, because Australians did not think enough about their own independence to sign up to the Statute of Westminster in 1931. They did not think about being their own individual country and having their own separate place in the world. They were part of the British Empire, thank you very much. They were not concerned about the Washington Naval Conference of 1922 and the contest between Japan, the United States and Britain over naval power across the continents. They were not concerned about striking out on their own, despite their experiences in the First World War, when very rarely did they have Australian commanders to lead them—when they did, Australians particularly marked themselves out as superior soldiers.

It was not until the Second World War—and this is the great stepping-off point, I think—that Australia as a nation, with its Prime Minister at its head in this federal parliament making determinations about the very survival and future of the nation, had to face fundamental decisions about which way Australia would go. The great cleavage point came after the fall of Singapore. The question was: which way would Australia go? Would it continue to take its orders as an imperial colony and continue to simply have its troops taken to Europe, the Middle East and North Africa to fight or would Australia stand firm and say, ‘The defence of this nation comes first and foremost,’ and seek help, as we did in the Battle of the Coral Sea, from the United States of America, the growing superpower on the planet, before they realised there were superpowers around the place? It was a major change and a major cleft in the road. That fundamental decision saved Australia, because it meant that it was not occupied by the Japanese, despite the depredations on northern Australia and around the coast by Japanese forces. As we now know, it was not just in the destruction of Darwin but in a number of incursions that Australians lost their lives on this very continent.

It is also the case that, because this was a total war, there was not a single individual in Australia who was alive between 1 September 1939 and Victory in Europe Day and what we will celebrate in August this year, VJ Day—Victory over Japan—who was not touched and affected by this conflict even more intimately than those who were affected by the First World War. This debate allows us to say that. It allows me to say that of all those people who were in the land army who worked to substitute for soldiers who were sent overseas and who worked backbreaking hours in the countryside to provide food for Australia or those people who worked in the munitions factories in Villawood and Chullora in my electorate. Bankstown was basically in the country, despite the fact that it is now in the middle of Sydney, until the munitions factory at Villawood and the other armaments factories were built. Bankstown airport was established as a World War II base. MacArthur and his officers at the top of Black Charlie’s Hill overlooking the whole of Bankstown had an operation where they directed the Pacific War from Bankstown itself. Everyone in Bankstown was affected but none more so than those people who hazarded their lives in Papua New Guinea, in the Pacific, in North Africa and indeed, eventually, on D-Day in Europe and the battles after that.

This immense conflagration could not have been imagined by people walking the streets of Sydney, or indeed Bankstown, in 1901. They could not have imagined the scale and scope of the war, nor its technological ferocity—not just, as we will get to, at the end of the war with VJ Day and the atomic bomb but the innovations that destroyed entire cities: the firebombing of Dresden and, prior to the massive attacks on Germany, the attacks on civilians in Britain which had caused so much devastation and so much terror and brought the war home to every individual in Britain.

But the fact was that Britain was able to hang on, whilst the great new democracy and new power that had built its industrial power and strength by mostly staying out of the First World War also stayed out of the Second World War for most of that period. The United States was not locked into truth, freedom and openness and fighting for everyone else. In the United States, the psyche was that they did not want to be part of old Europe and old wars. They did not want to be dragged into the First World War, and they did not want to be dragged into the second. It is the signal achievement of Franklin Delano Roosevelt that he, after all he had done to try to bring America out of the Depression, against the instincts and all the efforts of the people who did not want to see the United States in the war, took the opportunity of Japan attacking the United States at Pearl Harbour to enter the war. Three days later Adolf Hitler declared war on the United States.

If that had not happened—if the United States had not been in this conflict with us, and if Curtin as Prime Minister had not chosen a road that would change the fundamental frame of where our safety was seen to be, the Australia we know today simply would not exist. The probability is that the Japanese would not just have had a go at invading us but would in fact have invaded Australia. All the people who lost their lives on the Kokoda Trail, at Sandakan, in Burma, in the Pacific and Indian subcontinent theatres, those who fought in the deserts of the Middle East and those who were part of the defeat of the Nazis in Europe have my gratitude and the gratitude of all the people still living in my electorate who know that the immensity of what they went through was so great that we should be talking about it in this parliament. We should salute them. It should become a part of Australia’s general discussion of who we are, what we understand the world to be and what we understand of the dimensions of immense change that we confronted in the 20th century. We need to talk about these lessons.

talk.start.para: —On 7 May 1945 Germany surrendered, marking the end of war in Europe. We dedicated the following day, 8 May, as VE Day, and it is that which we take note of today, with great respect. The generation that went to war between 1939 and 1945 was made up of a truly remarkable group of people. They were a special type of person. These were people who grew up during the Depression. They grew up in the twenties and thirties, suffering deprivations every day of their lives as young people. They then, as young adults, went to one of the greatest conflicts in recorded time. When they returned from that conflict, they put their shoulders to the wheel to rebuild our country, as did other people of the same generation elsewhere in the world. I can think of few examples in recent modern historical times where a generation has been called upon to do so much and endure so much and has done so with such great fortitude, self-pride and distinction. It is indeed a generation that we should honour and be proud of.

speech.para: From 1939 to 1941, the European theatre of war was characterised by the devastating success of Nazi Germany’s forces. In this brief opportunity today, I want to concentrate in particular on part of the Australian contribution in that European theatre of World War II. Many other important sacrifices were made by all the peoples throughout Europe and throughout the world, but in terms of VE Day the entire continent of Europe was gripped in a war and a devastation that was unparalleled, and the sacrifices of that time should never be underestimated or forgotten.

I want to concentrate on the deeds of some of the Australians involved in that theatre of the Second World War. Having rolled through Europe for two years, largely unstoppable, the German war machine came to its first defeat and first halt in August 1941. Allied forces, made up principally of Australian soldiers from the 9th Division, met, stopped and forced into retreat Nazi Germany’s Afrika Corps, which was under the command of the famed General Erwin Rommel. That was the siege of Tobruk, which lasted four months. For four months the soldiers of the Australian 9th Division were left, largely without support from others, to defend themselves against dramatically superior forces. It was a siege in which the battle was fierce and hand-to-hand.

We get some idea of what that was like by looking at the citation for the Australian Victoria Cross winner from that battle. Corporal John Edmondson received the Victoria Cross for his deeds in Tobruk on 13 April, which was the weekend in which the siege began. It was the weekend in which the Germans launched their attack on Tobruk; it was the Easter weekend. On 13 April, Corporal Edmondson, was one of those who, along with others, performed heroically, and we get some insight into the events at that time from this account in his citation:

quote.para: During an enemy attack, platoon commander F.A. Mackell decided to dislodge the Germans with a bayonet charge, and he and Edmondson and five privates attacked. During the counter attack, Edmondson was wounded in the neck and stomach, but he advanced and killed one enemy with his bayonet. Later Mackell was bayoneting a German, who held on to him as another came up from behind. Edmondson, some metres away, immediately came to his assistance and, in spite of his wounds, killed both enemy. The party then returned to post R33 with a prisoner. Edmondson, badly wounded, died the next morning, 14 April.

speech.para: We get some insight into the close confines of battle when we read about being left with no option but a bayonet charge and hand-to-hand combat of that sort.

The defeat at the battle for Tobruk was the first defeat that the German war machine had suffered. Its blitzkrieg tactics, which it had used with such amazing success throughout all of Europe and which had devastated Europe for the two years prior to that, were masterfully countered by the Australian commander, Major General Morshead. It is worth having a read of the tactics adopted by Morshead in dealing with what had been, until that time, an unstoppable war machine, rolling unabated from one end of Europe to the other. At Tobruk, a greatly outnumbered and outresourced Australian Defence Force put an end to that. When the Australians were finally relieved by the Polish Carpathian brigade six months after the siege had begun, one of the battalions, the 2/13th, remained to fight its way out and to join up with the advancing British Eighth Army.

The 9th Division, which performed so heroically in that battle, went on to play an important role in the Allied victory at El Alamein. Many historians of World War II regard the battle at El Alamein as the turning point of the battle in Europe. If El Alamein was the turning point of the battle in Europe, it was the successful defeat of the German attack on Tobruk that provided the foundations for that turning point. The Australians who were in that theatre of war certainly performed with great valour, and I have had the great pleasure and honour of meeting with a number of members of the Rats of Tobruk Association from Queensland who fought in that campaign. It is indeed a great honour to see those people, who sadly are few in number today.

I want to acknowledge Kev Baker, the president of the association, and Jock Hunter, the secretary of the association. Kev regularly comes to Anzac Day services at Ithaca Creek state school in my electorate, the old primary school that I attended for seven years. The school has adopted the Rats of Tobruk and have erected a small cenotaph for ceremonies recognising them. Kev and his small band of members of the Rats of Tobruk Association regularly attend those ceremonies and visit other schools to talk to the students about their experiences. I also want to acknowledge Sid Toovey, another Rat of Tobruk. Sid was also a regular attendee at the ceremonies but he unfortunately passed away a few years ago. The Tooveys are a very well-known Queensland family.

The thing that strikes everybody when they meet people like Kev, Jock or Sid Toovey is that they are ordinary people like you and me who as young men were called upon to undertake extraordinary deeds. They rose to the occasion and did just that. One of the reasons they were able to do that was that they were supplied by what became known as the ‘Tobruk Ferry’, the naval service that kept the Port of Tobruk supplied, without which it would be hard to imagine that they would have been able to withstand the onslaught of the massive German forces.

We should not forget the serving personnel in the Navy who at great risk ran that ferry service. Though called a ferry service, the ships were not ferries, they were naval vessels. The HMAS Napier, HMAS Nizam, HMAS Nestor, HMAS Vendetta, HMAS Waterhen and HMAS Parramatta were all involved in that ferry service. They had been part of a Mediterranean British fleet, which had been there since 1939 and had become affectionately known as the ‘Scrap Iron Flotilla’. I guess it was not the most polished fleet in Her Majesty’s Navy and probably did not have the newest and best vessels. But there is no doubt that, without the ‘Scrap Iron Flotilla’ in the Mediterranean, the plight of the Allies throughout Africa and the adjoining European countries would have been that much more severe.

That ‘Scrap Iron Flotilla’, in addition to the ships that I just mentioned, included ships such as HMAS Voyager, a name well known through Australian defence history annals, HMAS Vampire, HMAS Gawler, HMAS Ipswich, HMAS Lismore, HMAS Maryborough, HMAS Geraldton, HMAS Cairns, HMAS Wollongong, HMAS Cessnock and HMAS Stuart. It is interesting to note that the HMAS Stuart in the ‘Scrap Iron Flotilla’ was commanded by Captain Waller, the designated commander for the Australian fleet. Captain Waller is the person after whom one of our Collins class submarines has been named. All of these people played an important part in turning the tide of war in Europe in 1941.

It should also not be forgotten that, prior to that time, many Australians had fought in the mainland European battles. I was taken by the emotion of people in Greece in 1990, when as a member of a parliamentary delegation I visited Greece on the eve of the 50th anniversary of the battles to defend their hometowns. It was quite moving to see their reaction 50 years later when they found out that there were Australian parliamentarians visiting. The gratitude which they displayed 50 years on to those Australians who had come from the other side of the world to help defend their nation against the fascist armies that were marching on their homes was really quite moving.

I also want to recall that on that same parliamentary delegation we visited Romania. We were in Romania on 11 November. As Australians on 11 November we wanted to take the opportunity to break our program to conduct a small private ceremony at an appropriate war grave. Our hosts, not really knowing whether there were any Australian war graves nearby, took us to a country field where there was a small cemetery. A number of RAF and US pilots who had been shot down had been buried in this cemetery. Sure enough, as we walked around this small cemetery—I can well recall Con Sciacca, the former member for Bowman, and I walking through the cemetery—there were the headstones of two or three Australians who had flown with the RAF and who lay in graves in a small countryside cemetery somewhere in the middle of Europe in Romania.

That brings me also to acknowledge the Victoria Cross recipients who were in the RAF. I will not go through the citations because time does not permit. Acting Wing Commander Hughie Edwards received the Victoria Cross for gallantry in an air raid over Bremen in Germany and Flight Sergeant Middleton received the Victoria Cross for gallantry in operations over Turin in Italy. Australians did play a role within the Royal Air Force in England as part of the multinational contribution that joined with the British in those dark days when England was also under serious threat.

This is an opportunity for us not only to rightfully remember with deep gratitude the sacrifices those Australian service personnel made during the European theatre of war but also, as with all of the ceremonies and opportunities, to recognise the terrible hardship, pain and suffering that war brings to people. To be honest, if you look through the annals of human history, you will see that many of those wars and conflicts were preventable. They arose because of bad decisions by diplomats, politicians and kings and queens. As legislators one of our responsibilities and obligations is to ensure that we do all we can to avoid such wars and conflicts in the future.

talk.start.para: —I rise to acknowledge the 60th anniversary of VE Day, the day that marked victory in Europe. It was not the day when we won the war in Europe. The war was won through the course of many battles both won and lost and the heroism of young men and women from around the world. VE Day was very much the day when the nation knew its boys would come home. In many ways it was the day the women, children and parents at home had waited for—the day they knew their husbands, fathers and children would return to them.

speech.para: Like many Australians I was born well after World War II and I do not have the experience of war of those who were alive at that time. But during the Vietnam War I was living in an army suburb and I experienced first-hand the absence of the men for the years of that war. I lived in a suburb where very young women with very young children learned to live in fear of the loss of their husbands and without the support of their men at home. I lived with them in fear for up to three years while they learned to raise their children without their husbands present.

I was also there when their men returned and I saw first-hand the damage done to families that had spent years forming their relationships without the presence of the fathers. I was there as the men came home strangers to their young wives and to their children—children they had left in the womb or as babies or toddlers were now four or five years old when they finally returned. I lived through the years after the Vietnam War while those families came to terms with the broken relationships—relationships fractured by the time the men were away at war. I lived also with the damage done to the men themselves—their broken bodies and, in many cases, their broken minds. They often came back quite different men from those who had gone away.

The Vietnam War, as horrendous as it was, was small compared with the Second World War, when it was not just a few suburbs that lived with the absence of the men in their lives but the whole country that lived without its young men. I lived, too, with the widows from the Vietnam War—again, much smaller in number—but it is incomprehensible to imagine that grief and loss magnified tens of thousands of times all around the country.

My experience of the Second World War itself came from my early childhood years in the experience of my grandfather, a World War II vet who returned from World War II as a stranger to his family. I know from speaking with my mother that when he returned he was quite a figure of fear to her and to her brothers and sisters for quite a few years. He came back a stranger. They had spent several years of their lives as young children without the presence of men. When he did come back, he was very much a stranger to them and quite withdrawn. It took them many years to recover the relationship with their father. Similarly, my grandmother found it extremely difficult in the early years following the return of her husband.

My grandfather came back from the war with one of his mates, whom I only knew as John. I have never known his second name. John came back from the war really missing great parts of himself. He was unable to live independently. He had been very much psychologically damaged by the war. My grandfather, who never really talked about his relationship with John, took his mate into his home following the war. John lived on the veranda and did odd jobs around the house. He mowed the lawn with a scythe, and that is what I remember most vividly—John being present but never really being there as a person, cutting the grass in the front yard with a scythe. For 60 years he lived with my grandfather and grandmother, a shadow of what he must have been when my grandfather knew him during the war. It was an extraordinary example of the mateship that developed between those who served on the front lines in World War II.

Similarly, my Uncle Arthur, whose story I also do not know very well because he really did not speak much about it, was interred in a Japanese prisoner of war camp during World War II and came back a changed man. During my life, he seemed to lose parts of his body and parts of his mind year after year, never really recovering from the devastating effects of World War II. So VE Day, for me, is not so much the day when we won the war; it is the day when families in Australia finally knew that their loved ones could come home.
Debate (on motion by Mrs Moylan) adjourned.

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 10 May, on motion by Mr Abbott:

motion.para: That the House take note of the document.

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak on a subject very near and dear to my heart. The Premier of Queensland gave full credit for the creation of the state’s coal and tourism industries to Sir Bjelke-Petersen. It was a very generous and truthful thing for him to do. I would have added the aluminium industry. The thing that is not appreciated in this age of national competition policy and free markets is that in the 1950s Australia imported coal. This was a coal-importing nation. By the late 1960s, early 1970s, Queensland had become one of the greatest coal-producing states on earth. How did they accomplish that? At the time, I was a young man of 29 elected to parliament, Ron Camm was the Minister for Mines and Energy—and I was a protege of Ron Camm’s—and I could not believe what they were doing.

speech.para: In today’s money they borrowed $3,500 million to build this giant railway line—the most efficient railway line in the world—going back to the coalfields. They built one of only six ports in the world that can take 200,000-tonne ships—one of the mightiest ports in the entire world. They built one of the biggest power stations in Australia, which produced the cheapest power of any power station in Australia. Through a brilliant manoeuvre by Camm and Bjelke-Petersen, they got the coal for free, so the power station was fired with free coal. It was effectively government money that was at risk with respect to the coal loaders as well. They put all this money out and they had no customers. There was not a single operating coalmine in Queensland, except to supply power stations. Sure, Utah said they were going to build one. There is a big difference between saying you are going to build one and actually building one and exporting coal.

Yesterday in the House the Treasurer answered my question by saying, ‘If the demand is there, private enterprise will build it.’ The demand was there all right, but there was no private enterprise coming to build it. The coal phenomenon may well have taken place but it would have been 20 years later—and I do not think that is an unreasonable figure—and it would have been much smaller than it is today if it had not been for what I thought at the time was enormous risk taking. I remember Ron Camm saying to me, ‘Are you going to water? Are you a little spineless wonder?’ I said, ‘No, I just have no desire to die young.’ I could have spent $3,000 million of the public’s money with no customers for the coal or the power. When we did those things, the coal flowed. Coal export revenue in Queensland went from $39 million in 1968 to $2.9 billion by 1988, the year in which Joh Bjelke-Petersen was stabbed in the back. That was a most extraordinary achievement.

When we built the power station we had all this super-cheap power available. The aluminium people came to us and said, ‘Hey, listen, we will develop Weipa and we will take all of that power off you because it is the cheapest power in the world. We can produce aluminium more cheaply here than anywhere else in the world.’ So the aluminium industry took off. When Bjelke-Petersen became Premier in 1966 there was no income from aluminium; when he left in 1988 there was $1,000 million.

The aluminium and coal industries, along with tourism, are carrying the Australian economy. This nation is on its knees. We are noncompetitive in virtually all areas. If you look at the statistics of the big 10 industries, you will see that the three industries that are now carrying the economy—four, including the iron industry, but it has nothing to do with Queensland—were built in Queensland and they were built principally by this man. He had a close relationship with people like Leslie Thiess, for which he was condemned—and let us not beat around the bush—because he was said to be corrupt. The relationship of those two great Queenslanders, great Australians and great men, however you measure great men, was condemned because they had a friendship and they worked well together. That friendship yielded for this nation the item that is now carrying the country.

Even back in those days, Rex Connor said, ‘Australia is no longer being carried on the sheep’s back, it is being carried in the coal truck.’ That is far truer today than when Rex Connor made that statement. There was no nickel industry in Queensland. We had no income from nickel. It was announced just last week that there was $570 million coming from the plant, which is in my former state electorate, so I am intimately familiar with what happened there. The government put up an exposure of $40 million, which grew to $120 million, which was an awful lot of money back in the early seventies. Mr Beattie pulled out of the magnesium plant for about $300 million, but that is the equivalent of about $120 million in the early seventies. They exposed the government and the taxpayers of Queensland on that nickel. That has yielded over a thousand jobs for the people of North Queensland for a period of over 30 years. We got all of our money back and made a lot of money out of it, as we did of course from the coal regions.

I will just cite you one example. What some people described as irresponsible risk taking turned out to be nation building. Where people like me were fearful that we were taking great risks and we should not have been taking them, these people had thought it all out and they were building nations.

If Bjelke-Petersen had never gone into politics he would have been a famous man as a farming innovator. He pioneered new forms of land clearing where he used a big ball between the two chains, a very important breakthrough. He was one of the first crop-dusters in the state of Queensland and he built one of the first threshing machines for peanuts in the state of Queensland. He was a great innovator and he was a great missionary as well.

He secured the land for Hopevale from the then Labor government back in the forties or early fifties. He secured that land for Hopevale and he went out on horseback for some three months. Many people criticised him for having a bad attitude towards the first Australians, the Aboriginal people. But talk to Leo Rosendale from one of the more famous first families, an Australian of Aboriginal descent. Lester, Leo’s son, was at the funeral and gave a small delivery. Leo Rosendale told me that they camped out for about three months. They were on horseback with swags and they eventually got a site for the town. He said that they cleared all the main street by hand themselves with axes. He said it was not all work. They had a lot of fun fishing and pig shooting and various other things. Hopevale has produced Pastor George Rosendale, one of the first Aboriginal people in Australian history to become a clergyman. It produced—a subject near and dear to my heart—Matty Bowen, the famous Australian Rugby League fullback. It produced Noel Pearson, and Eric Deeral, the first Aboriginal to be elected to a parliament in Australian history. And Hopevale was founded by Bjelke-Petersen and Leo Rosendale.

I had the privilege and great honour of serving as the Aboriginal affairs minister, one of the longest serving in Australian history, and I got a lot of praise—in fact, I think there are three textbooks used in university on what we did in those years and they are very praiseworthy of us. I suppose I got the lion’s share of the credit. Contrary to public belief, Bjelke-Petersen in the end—not at the start—was pushing that legislation just as much as I or any Aboriginal person in the state was. It was not very clever or brilliant. We just went out and asked them what they wanted. They wanted self-management and they wanted to own their own land in the same way as every other Australian owns their own land. They wanted to own their own houses, their own farms, their own businesses—they wanted private ownership. So we said, ‘Righto, we’ll do that,’ and that is what we did. We got very great accolades for it—I think there were three in one year. We did three 60 Minutes interviews on what we were achieving in that area in those times. When the incoming Goss government, for reasons best known to them, overturned that legislation it precipitated the worst rioting in Queensland parliamentary history. That rioting was a very fine tribute to the achievements of Bjelke-Petersen in an area where not only did he receive no praise but he received condemnation.

In the media there was a lot of emphasis placed on the Fitzgerald inquiry into corruption. In all of Australian history there have been few governments as determined to weed out corruption as determinedly as the Bjelke- Petersen government was. And it cost them. Their colleagues went to jail. Their government was destroyed. We were torn to pieces. Innocent men, like Angelo Vasta, whose son serves in the parliament now, were destroyed by what happened then. We did that in a genuine effort to weed out what we saw as some real corruption. How many other governments in Australian history have done that at great cost to themselves?

I was very much a party to the issue which Bjelke-Petersen was charged with: the Regency bid for the port building. I was the heritage minister in the Queensland government and was intimately familiar with the bids. In my opinion Bjelke-Petersen at all times was backing the Kern bid. He never backed the Regency bid—for which he was being charged. I cannot to this day think about it without feeling the rage rise—justifiable rage—about this issue. Here was a man who was going in one direction and was being accused of going in the exact opposite direction. That is a matter of public record. That is in the cabinet minutes and the submissions that were involved at that time.

There is one proof of whether you are corrupt or not. Old Ben Nickel, the famous policeman in Queensland, used to say, ‘Look at their houses, Bob. Look at their houses.’ One leader in Australia has a $5½ million private home. That was on the front of the Sydney Morning Herald. The Bjelke-Petersens live in a nice but what I would consider a very humble, restrained home. There is no lavishness there anywhere. In fact, there was a movable fan the day I was there—there was no airconditioning the last time I was up there; there is now, as I understand it. Things have improved a bit for them. There are only two members of parliament in Australian history who have left parliament without taking their superannuation. One of them is Ted Mack, who some of us served with—he is a very honourable man—and the other one is Bjelke-Petersen. Yet Bjelke-Petersen is accused of being dishonest! I do not know how much it would be worth today. He knocked back millions of dollars, that is for certain; and they needed that money desperately at the time.

Bill Gunn, the Deputy Premier, had discussions with the ALP and got agreement on an ex gratia payment. I was given the job of talking to Bjelke-Petersen because he was refusing to take the ex gratia payment, which was a pretty negligible amount of money but very valuable and important to that family who were struggling at the time. He said that, no, he could not take it. I said, ‘Well, you owe us an explanation here, Premier. We’ve worked very hard to get this for you and you owe us an explanation.’ He said, ‘Oh well, Bob, you know, I voted against it.’ I said, ‘Premer, you voted against superannuation in 1949. It is now 1988.’ He said, ‘Oh, Bob, just because it was wrong then does not mean it is right now—no, no, no, no.’ This was the man who was accused of dishonesty. He was a man of towering integrity and towering honesty—just the opposite of dishonesty.

In conclusion, the Prime Minister quoted Christopher Wren speaking about the great Saint Pauls Cathedral in London. He said, ‘My monument? Look around you: this is my monument.’ I say, ‘In Queensland, look around you.’ Look at the Gold Coast, where previously the tallest building was three storeys high and it went broke three times. Look at Brisbane, where the six-storey shire council chambers was the tallest building. Look at Townsville—almost the whole of Townsville was built by Bjelke-Petersen. Look at Cairns, it used to be a grubby little backwater. At a hotel in Cairns one morning I saw Bo Derek and another famous film actor. Mount Isa used to be a town of 6,000 people and is now a town of 30,000 people. Look around you at what this man achieved. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I would like to associate myself with the condolence motion moved with respect to the passing of the late the Hon. Sir Joh Bjelke Petersen KCMG, who lived from 1911 until April this year. Like you, Mr Deputy Speaker Somlyay, I was privileged to be present at the state funeral for Sir Joh. I have to say that I was pleased that there was such a collective community response to recognise the fact that this man made a very important mark on the state of Queensland, and indeed Australia, during his period of service.

speech.para: It is really good to see that former political opponents are prepared to recognise that as a society we owe a lot to Sir Joh. He in fact was probably the first person to stress that governments ought not to spend more than they earn. While there were certain accusations made with respect to his government, I think most people broadly would recognise that Queensland’s economic strength was as a result of sound economic management. At a time when Labor governments in southern states were building up incredible deficits and there was gross mismanagement, the Queensland government was in a very fine financial state. When the National Party lost office in 1989 and Wayne Goss was elected as Premier, he inherited a state that certainly had a very sound economy.

I think all governments around the country now to a greater or lesser extent recognise that governments, like individual households, have to pay their way. The budget that was handed down by the Treasurer showed that this government, since it was elected in 1996, has believed that the country ought to pay its way. While I do not want to politicise this condolence motion by talking about the budget, Sir Joh was Premier of Queensland and, as Treasurer of Queensland for some time, showed that the state coffers had to be appropriately topped up before expenditure could take place.

Many honourable members would recall that I was a member of the National Party, and I did meet Sir Joh on a number of occasions. I was very pleased that the Prime Minister was able to be at the funeral, and his words were gracious—as were the words uttered by the Premier of Queensland, the Hon. Peter Beattie. It was a fitting recognition that thousands of people travelled from right around south-east Queensland to be present at the funeral. My unabashed admiration for Lady Bjelke-Petersen was enhanced when, at 84 years of age and suffering a bereavement after her husband’s long illness, she was able to greet hundreds of people by name. She asked after their families and had an intimate knowledge of the individual circumstances of so many people. Despite her grief, she was able to help turn the funeral into a celebration of the life of Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen.

Not everyone agreed with Sir Joh all of the time, and I suspect that he would have been disappointed if people had. He was a person who was prepared to stand up and be counted. I knew members of Sir Joh’s family quite well, particularly his daughter Meg and his son-in-law Pastor Noel Noack, one of the three Lutheran ministers who officiated at the state funeral. When I was a solicitor in Ipswich, Meg and Noel were based in the Brisbane valley at a Lutheran parish and I came to know them quite well. In fact, I was their solicitor at the time. Over the years I have kept in touch, particularly when Noel was posted as the pastor at Immanuel Lutheran Church in Maroochydore, an area represented by you, Mr Deputy Speaker Somlyay, as the honourable member for Fairfax and later by me as the member for Fisher.

I am not saying that at all times I agreed with everything the Bjelke-Petersen family did, particularly in 1996 when John was endorsed by the National Party to run against me as the sitting Liberal member for Fisher. But it was a clean campaign and I certainly do not hold any grudges. I greatly respect the role that Sir Joh and Lady Flo have played in Queensland during their term of public service. I was talking to colleagues last night about Lady Bjelke-Petersen and they reminded me of what an excellent advocate she was for Queensland and what an excellent senator she was as well.

I do not intend to detain the Main Committee for long but I want to place on record the condolences from the people of Fisher and, because you are not able to speak, Mr Deputy Speaker Somlyay, the people of Fairfax as well to Lady Bjelke-Petersen and her family. Australia lost a giant, and I suspect that politics in Australia will never quite be the same again. As I said, people in many respects either strongly agreed or disagreed with Sir Joh. History will record him well, particularly as a sound economic manager, a can-do person and an individual who was prepared to be a very keen voice for Queensland. In doing so, particularly through the abolition of death duties, I consider he has had a major positive impact on the economy of this nation. I associate myself with the condolence motion moved with respect to the passing of the Hon. Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen KCMG.

talk.start.para: —With some deal of pride I rise to support this motion moved by the Deputy Prime Minister, and supported by members of this House, on the passing of Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen. I never knew Joh Bjelke-Petersen personally. I think I met him only once, and that was soon after the election where we had the famous ‘cricket team’ which was the opposition of Queensland: Joh defeated the Labor Party and reduced them to a team of 11. It was after, of course, the confrontation with the Electrical Trades Union.

speech.para: Having lived just across the border in New South Wales all my life and growing up in that area, I feel qualified to speak on what I saw happen to the state of Queensland. Joh Bjelke-Petersen was an inimitable character, a man of my father’s vintage. My father would have been about six years younger than Joh Bjelke-Petersen but they came from the same era, an era when there were few opportunities. They never had many opportunities for education, and they lived a very frugal life. They worked from a very young age very hard and built up their assets in the hardest way possible with some of that hard farming work. Unlike my father, Joh Bjelke-Petersen decided to go into politics after serving some time in local government. It was not until he became the Premier of Queensland that I really started to look at and understand some of the actions that he took.

Joh Bjelke-Petersen was not an educated man. He left school, I think, at the age of 12. He was a self-taught man. He was a man that obviously was quite skilled in his dealings with people, but he never, ever pretended that he was an educated man. I found quite extraordinary some of the lampooning that took place from some of the, I suppose, intellectual snobs of the media and politics from time to time. As the Leader of the Opposition said in his address, when he met him Joh in his inimitable way said, ‘Mr Minister, I’ll let Sir Lew speak on my behalf,’ or the public servant he might have had at the time. He never pretended he was anything other than a very humble, self-made man.

As I said, I lived across the border in northern New South Wales, and I remember the state of Queensland as being not a very developed state—not in those days. It was the abolition of death duties that started to change all that. We had the migration north of Sir Bruce Small, of Malvern Star fame. He built the Chevron Island complex, and he became Mayor of the Gold Coast and, I think, a member of the Queensland parliament representing the Gold Coast. It was the start of the movement north of people from the south—from Melbourne, Sydney and other areas—because other states had death duties and Queensland did not. It was, I suppose, one of those masterstrokes, one which improved the economy of Queensland.

In those days, there were none of the major mines that we have in Queensland—or in Western Australia, for that matter. There were none of those great mines. When I served as the Minister for Mines in New South Wales, I was constantly reminded of the fact that, if there had not been a Joh Bjelke-Petersen, if there had not been a Charles Court—that is, someone who simply cut through all the red tape and said, ‘These mines here will go’—we would not have these major mines in Australia. They are very significant mines. I have been to them; I have seen them. They are very significant, world-class mines and, to a great extent, Australia lives off them. They do Australia’s exporting in our mineral areas, and that is what we live off.

I recall vividly this next anecdote, in relation to the mines to the west of Bowen. One of the deals Joh did with the companies there was to say, ‘Well, you’ll build the railway line but you’ll also pay freight to the state of Queensland.’ There are stories about Joh that get around from his enemies, but he always had the state of Queensland at heart—always. I think he should be given credit for that.

In recent days I have seen some of the statements made by left-wing journalists in this country and, quite frankly, I think they are an absolute disgrace. For one thing, to leave publishing an article such as that until someone dies is a disgrace, an absolute disgrace. Another thing is that these people should be seen for what they are. These people hated Joh Bjelke-Petersen because he opposed them strongly. It is one thing to have a different point of view. It is another thing to hate someone just because he has a different point of view.

There was the great electricity strike in southern Queensland in the early eighties involving SEQEB. I was across the border and I was not involved in politics at the time, but I thought to myself, ‘Well, Joh, you’ve taken on too much this time.’ But, as usual, he saw it through. I have to say that he set a mark in that particular area for the rest of Australia, and the rest of Australia has followed. It is not a matter of crushing the unions; it is a matter of common decency. These people were lording it over the people of Queensland and holding them to ransom. Joh Bjelke-Petersen had the fortitude to take them on and he should be given credit for that. He wasn’t perfect; no-one is perfect. But I do not believe he was a dishonest man and I do not believe he was a corrupt man. He was a very simple man—and I do not mean that in a derogatory sense—but he was an honourable man. And I believe that, yes, there may have been people around the fringes who took advantage of the fact that he was a trusting person, but he himself was a very honourable man and he had the state of Queensland at the core of his belief.

Another thing I would like to say is that Joh Bjelke-Petersen, I suppose because of his background, did not believe in running up debt. One of the things that characterised the state of Queensland during his premiership was that he never ran up any debt. When we used to travel to Brisbane from across the border, we were envious of the road systems he had in south-east Queensland. He certainly was very careful in the way that he spent his money. But there was never any debt in Queensland, and successive governments have lived off that. They have lived off the fact that he never, ever ran up debt. It was his upbringing; he believed in that.

talk.start.para: —Fully funded super.

—Yes, there was fully funded super, as the member for Hinkler reminds me. When we went into government in New South Wales we had an unfunded super of $26 billion, which shows the comparison between the state of Queensland and state of New South Wales.

speech.para: There is another thing which displays some of the strength that the man had. Queensland had the Commonwealth Games and Expo. One of the things that shines through is that the Queensland government made a profit out of both the Commonwealth Games and Expo. No-one else has ever done that. The only reason for that was that there was a very tight hand kept on the costs of construction. I am sure that history will show that one of the current problems in New South Wales results from the lack of a strong hand being kept on the cost of construction for the Sydney Olympic Games.

As I said, I am pleased to be able to stand here today and offer this tribute to Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen. As I said, no-one is perfect. His enemies hated him because he was prepared to take them on. But I think history will judge him very well. It will show that he was a man who was prepared to stand up. He was a man who was prepared to develop the state of Queensland. I think history will see him as being one of Australia’s greatest premiers of modern times.
Debate (on motion by Mr Georganas) adjourned.

motion.para: That the Main Committee do now adjourn.

talk.start.para: —The test of any government—and, indeed, of any society—is the way it provides for the most vulnerable. All of us are diminished if we do not provide adequately for the most disadvantaged in our community—if we are selfish and fail to show the respect to others that they deserve. In everyone’s eyes, I think, we should be an inclusive society, providing everyone with the shelter and safety that they need within our community. So I studied the budget pretty carefully for evidence that the government in particular had responded to calls for support and services from those who represented the most disadvantaged groups: the mentally ill, the homeless, the people with severe and multiple disabilities and their families. I looked for some evidence that the claims for a fair go for everyone and the claims of support for family values were real.

speech.para: I have to say, having had as good a look as one can with the current state of the budget papers, that the response in this budget is best described as nonexistent. In the official budget announcements there was very little reference to—and in the budget papers very little detail about—one group about which I know members of this chamber have spoken on various occasions. I speak particularly of the group who have already been the subject of at least one motion in the House—a number of politicians have taken part in the Adopt a Politician Scheme—and that is people with multiple disabilities, the very severely disadvantaged. I hoped we would hear in this budget from the coalition that there would be additional support provided to this group, because I read some of the speeches that members gave and they were very admirable and seemed to understand the circumstances of parents of such people, particularly those caring for older children who are now well into adulthood while they themselves are ageing.

The family I have the privilege of speaking for, because I am part of the Adopt a Politician Scheme, represent, in their generosity and dedication to their daughter, a lot of the values that we should espouse as a community. A budget should be framed to address the needs of a family like this one. It should represent the fairness and decency that this family shows to their daughter. I am talking about Ron and Patricia Read who are 54 years old and have a daughter, Annette. She is a delightful young lady of 33, about the same age as my own son, and she lives at home with her parents, as she has always done. She was born with an intellectual disability, cerebral palsy, epilepsy and hydrocephalus. So she has multiple disabilities and needs 24-hour care—and she has needed it since she was born. She has a shunt inserted to drain fluid from her brain.

She has assistance during the week through a program called Interchange, which is a daily activity program, and that provides her parents with some relief. She is also involved with Take Time and participates in the activities of the Activ Foundation, but she does need 24-hour care and supervision, partly because of her fitting and partly because she just needs help to live independently. She can take part in cooking and washing and so on, helping her mother to some extent, and she is proud to do so, but frankly—and her parents would be the first to acknowledge this—she is not in a position to provide fully for herself. Because of her disabilities, she is also vulnerable to exploitation, so she needs supervision. Sometimes her parents will tell you her behaviour is somewhat inappropriate.

They know that they are not going to be able to care for her forever, and they are now looking for some respite for the longer term and to be able to plan carefully for their future. They know that Annette needs proper long-term supervision and they are looking to place her into some form of supported accommodation—a group home. They know that this is the right time for her too to show her independence. She cannot simply develop that on the day they are no longer there or no longer able to support her.

So I looked in the budget for some evidence that the government had heard its own members, who I know have spoken for families like Annette’s, for people like Ron and Patricia Read. She needs supported accommodation, not just respite care—although that is welcome and needed. I am sure that the one-off payment to carers will be spent extremely well by the Reads. Like many other people who care for those with disabilities, they are not well-off either. But what they need is certainty and security. They need the Commonwealth government to put more funding into supported accommodation. We know there is serious unmet need. There is a backlog of people —in my own state the figure is around 300—in need of accommodation. The Reads are amongst many who have been knocked back because the places are not available. They are amongst the youngest of the parents facing difficulties, but both have physical health problems which make it extremely difficult for them, for instance, to lift Annette when she fits, as she regularly does.

I call upon the members of the government that is in power at the moment to re-examine the allocation of funds. The Commonwealth-state disability agreement does not provide sufficient long-term certainty for families like this. They deserve our attention. They deserve the resources. They have put in the hard yards, and they will continue to do so. Please, now is the time to act—not in 10 years time. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Mr Deputy Speaker, as you would be aware, my electorate of Fisher is located right in the middle of the most beautiful coastline in Australia: I refer, of course, to Queensland’s Sunshine Coast. It is an area that is known for its clean beaches, relaxed lifestyle—
—Great lifestyle.
—Did you say excellent representation, my friend?
Mr Martin Ferguson interjecting—

—And it is known for its friendly people, and that is why so many Australians choose to take their holidays in the region. But it is an area that at times is almost a victim of its own beauty and its own success. It is an area that is so popular with visitors that many of them decide to stay on—and we certainly welcome all of them as they move from the rustbelt areas of southern Australia, such as those represented by the honourable members immediately opposite me at the moment. The Sunshine Coast is a really great area, and many of these new residents choose to pull up stumps from their existing homes and relocate to our beautiful region.

speech.para: As a result, my electorate of Fisher and the neighbouring electorates to the north and south are experiencing incredibly high population growth. In fact, Mr Deputy Speaker, you might be surprised to know that the population is expected to almost double in the next 10 to 15 years. Builders are very pleased, because there is an ongoing boom that for several years has barely slowed down. This of course has created a great deal of employment opportunity, which has helped boost our local economy, and certainly that is a good thing. The builders, the brickies, the plasterers, the landscapers and people in related industries have all been further buoyed by a steady influx of new residents from the baby boomer generation. Many retirees from Sydney and Melbourne, in particular, are very keen to make the lifestyle change and the switch to my electorate.

But with all good things there is often an unenviable flip side. The population growth is placing massive pressure on infrastructure. Roads are often forced to deal with an overload of vehicles, and this is particularly challenging during the holiday season. Some 80 per cent of people who travel to and from the Sunshine Coast do so by road. I have certainly been campaigning to increase the width of the Bruce Highway to six lanes all the way from Brisbane to the Sunshine Coast. The government has spent hundreds of millions of dollars improving the Bruce Highway, and the Treasurer and the government more generally deserve to be congratulated for this. I must say that I am particularly pleased that commitments are being given to upgrade the Bruce Highway to six lanes as far as Caboolture, which will remove the very worst bottleneck between Brisbane and the Sunshine Coast. If we are able to improve the access as far as Caboolture, it means that the whole trip from Brisbane to the Sunshine Coast will take a very much shorter amount of time, which is a very important step forward.

I do not think that our forefathers ever envisaged that many of the coastal towns in my electorate would really ever grow to become much more than sleepy fishing villages. In fact, the hinterland towns on the Sunshine Coast were once called the railway towns because not much happened there other than the fact that they were a base for the railway which went from Brisbane to North Queensland. But now of course the opposite is the case, and both the coastal localities and the hinterland localities are rapidly growing. I am not surprised at the influx of new visitors. We on the Sunshine Coast are spoilt. We have it good. It is an absolutely wonderful environment and a tremendous place to live, and I suppose that we ought not to object when many other people decide to join us and enjoy our beautiful lifestyle.

The challenge facing the region and the federal government is to ensure that the provision of infrastructure keeps up with this phenomenon known as the sea change. Other coastal towns on the eastern seaboard have also noticed the increasing number of new residents who have made the decision to move out of the rat-race and to live somewhere with a great lifestyle. The airport in my region already conducts direct flights daily to Sydney and Melbourne. But if the growth and demand continue it will need a new runway to cope with larger planes and more frequent flights. The Bruce Highway, as I said, must be widened to six lanes, and I am certainly pushing for this to occur. It really is important, from the point of view of access to and from the Sunshine Coast, that this happen.

Sadly, two people were killed in a car crash on the highway north of my electorate. The crash is under investigation, and my heart goes out to those family members who have lost loved ones. It was a terrible tragedy.

The influx of people to the coast and the ever increasing number of vehicles using the Bruce Highway need to be recognised by all levels of government, including the state government. When that time comes and the improvement work continues, residents will be able to travel more freely and without the headaches that accompany the current gridlock, which affects so many other major regions. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I must say I was delighted to see the member for Fisher being made to sit down on his backside for a change, because this afternoon I want to raise something which I think is exceptionally important.

speech.para: There was one statement by the Treasurer in his speech of this week—the budget speech of 2005-06—that I did agree with. It was his statement that our population is entitled to a first-class health service. To have a first-class health service you have to invest in the future. For that reason this afternoon I want to refer to a report of December 2004 entitled Sustaining the virtuous circle for a healthy competitive Australia. It is an investment review of Australia’s health and medical research. In referring to it I would like to point out that, as a result of the health and medical research strategic review of 1998, we put in place a health and medical research budget of $613.7 million over five years. Over the next 12 months we as a community have to consider whether or not we extend that investment in medical research in Australia.
I simply say: that extension is an absolute must. For that reason, I refer to the first paragraph of a foreword to the report of December 2004. In presenting this report, it stated:

quote.para: Australia is a world leader in health and medical research. On a per capita basis, our research output is twice the OECD average, even though we spend much less, per capita, than the U.K. and the U.S.A.

speech.para: It then went on to make what I suppose could be called a challenge to the Australian community:

quote.para: Investment in health and medical research makes good economic and health sense. It generates significant returns both in terms of health benefits—longevity and increased quality of life for Australian people generally; and economic benefits, through increased knowledge based jobs and economic activity.

speech.para: I raise these issues because I would hope that over the next 12 months the Howard government seriously considers this report on the performance of our health and medical research fraternity over the last four years. I simply consider that we as a community have to accept that Australian medical research is a world-class investment. We have to face up to the fact that, unfortunately, medical research funding in Australia is currently static. Unless we make some hard decisions about continuing this program with increased funding in the future, our competitive edge will be lost, because we have not invested in our future. I think that is exceptionally important, because those benefits will benefit Australians. In essence, it is about guaranteeing not only that we create good jobs in terms of health and medical research, which in turn contribute to Australia’s economic performance, but that we also do something about the health of our community.

In terms of the wellbeing of our community, I note that a 2003 report from Access Economics found that for the 40 years to 1999 our eight-year gain in life expectancy plus improved wellness was worth $5.4 trillion to Australians. This research is actually a smart investment, in terms of both looking after Australia’s future and also, I suggest, reducing what we would normally have to expend on health activities throughout our lives. It is about knowledge. It is about the development of new drugs and new medical practices. In essence, it is about translating our capacity into the guaranteeing of a better quality of life for all Australians. It is no different to investing in the skilling of Australians. It is no different to investing in overcoming infrastructure bottle necks in Australia. It is about, I suppose, guaranteeing that we have a decent work force across all health areas, a work force that is capable of undertaking the biotech and socioeconomic research that will guarantee a decent health outcome for the Australian community.

It is also about targeting some of the major challenges that confront Australia on the health care front, including ageing, obesity, diabetes, heart failure, bird flu, bioterrorism and the special problems which confront our Indigenous communities. I use the adjournment debate today to praise the report on the performance of our health and medical research teams across Australia and to plead with the government that, in the development of the next budget, due in 12 months time, it actually seriously takes this report on board. We have to put in place a new program which will continue funding and guarantee the excellent results and performance of the health and medical research community that in turn benefits all Australians. I commend the report to the House. (Time expired).

talker.name: Stone, Dr Sharman, MP
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Finance and Administration
talker.name: Dr STONE

talk.start.para: —I have recently returned from Thailand and Cambodia where I was able to advance our work on the free trade agreement with the Thailand government. One of the areas remaining to be fleshed out there in the TAFTA, as we call it, is the Thailand-Australian agreement on access to each country’s government procurement markets. I want to thank the Department of Finance and Administration for the excellent work they have done in supporting this ongoing work in the development of this procurement agreement, and of course the work that our minister and DFAT have been doing over many years. In this particular instance I also want to thank most sincerely the Australian Embassy in Thailand led of course by our ambassador there, His Excellency Mr Bill Paterson. We are very well served by our Australian representatives in that country and I want to put on the record the extraordinarily good work they do in what is our excellent relationship with Thailand.

speech.para: I then went on to the kingdom of Cambodia to the 21st Asian parliamentarian meeting on ‘Population and Development: Population in Emergency’. In particular we looked at the role that Australian and other regional governments can take in responding to something like a tsunami. There in Cambodia I was also able to continue the work of helping that country whose great need is to better address its new and emerging financial management systems. The Cambodian government is most anxious to improve their ability to have transparent, accountable and competitive rules governing their government’s activities that can then leaven the whole of the economy. I met in particular with Dr Aun Porn Moniroath, Secretary of State for their Ministry of Economics and Finance. He was most appreciative of the support he has had, again from the Department of Finance and Administration officials who have done all they can and will continue to support him in helping to build the capacity of that government as it develops its new financial management framework.

I want to put on record in particular the extraordinarily good work the Australian government is doing through AusAID in helping to fund the Asia Regional Cooperation to Prevent People Trafficking. By people trafficking I mean the recruitment, transportation, transfer, harbouring or receipt of persons. People traffickers do this via the use of threat, force or coercion, abduction, fraud, deception, abuse of power or the giving or receiving of payments to gain control over another person. What do they do with the people they traffic? There is prostitution or other forms of sexual exploitation, forced labour, slavery, servitude or the removal of human organs.

In Cambodia the problem of people trafficking is very serious and the Australian government is doing much to help. In Cambodia trafficking takes many forms, particularly in the sex industry. But there is also the trafficking of children for begging, soliciting or selling flowers, for example, and the adult population—sold or coerced—are used as slaves in agriculture, factory work, construction and fishing. Children are also trafficked for domestic labour, theft and transportation and of course babies are trafficked for adoption to foreign countries. The problem extends through Cambodia, Laos, Burma and Thailand, and we have excellent cooperation with those nations in trying to deal with this extraordinary human tragedy.

In the antitrafficking team I want to commend the work of Janet Ashby and our own Australian embassy officials led very capably indeed by our ambassador there, Her Excellency Mrs Lisa Filipetto, who has done important work before in Vietnam and is now in Cambodia. She is helping a dedicated team which includes very strong support from Ms Kim Stewart, First Secretary, who works with the Australian Federal Police. I also want to put on record the courageous work of the Brigadier General Un Sokunthea, head of the Department of Antihuman Trafficking and Ministry of Interior. She has been working with the Australian Federal Police in trying to address gender imbalance and gender discrimination in her own police department. She is also targeting those who perpetrate this extraordinary crime against humanity, this people trafficking. I was pleased to see the support the Australian government has given in computer hardware, in motor bikes and in building the capacity of the police department so that they can emerge from their country’s very recent past which was so destructive of the population and as they move to deal with the poverty that feeds the people trafficking. We all need to do more. I want to commend what our Australian government officials and NGOs are doing in this area. People trafficking is very lucrative. It is the second most profitable crime after drugs and we have to bear this in mind. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I rise this afternoon on behalf of many of my constituents who have written to me or telephoned my office to express their anger at the appalling and inexcusable way in which the Howard government is failing to protect the rights of Australian citizens and for its growing shameful record on human rights. It seems like a week does not pass without new reports of Australian citizens being mistakenly incarcerated or deported by their own government. Equally, the senseless cruelty which now characterises the administration of Australia’s immigration policies is unacceptable.

speech.para: The Howard government’s human rights record for this year alone paints a very disturbing picture. In February this year we learned that an Australian citizen, Ms Cornelia Rau, had been arrested, suspected of being an illegal immigrant. She was held in a Queensland prison under Australian immigration laws for six months and then transferred to the Baxter immigration detention centre in South Australia, where she spent a further four months, often in solitary confinement for 18 hours a day. We subsequently learned that Ms Rau is suffering from a mental illness, which surely highlights the urgent need for an examination of medical assessments in detention centres.

Further, we now know that Ms Rau was not an exceptional case. It is bad enough that an Australian citizen can be unjustly detained in this way. This morning we learnt that another Australian woman, Ms Vivian Alvarez Young, wrongly deported to the Philippines four years ago, has been found in the Philippines by pure chance. Expatriate Australian, Father Mike Duffin, found Ms Young while working as a Catholic missionary in the Philippines. He is reported in today’s Australian newspaper as being highly sceptical about the government’s efforts to find her. He is quoted as saying:

quote.para: “If the Government says they don’t know where she is, it’s a bit hard to believe,” ...
“Who says they’re actually trying to track her down?”

speech.para: This is scandalous, and I join my colleague the member for Reid and shadow minister for immigration in calling for a royal commission into this matter.

As I said earlier, this is not just a matter of the Howard government failing to protect the rights of Australian citizens; equally I and many of my constituents are disgusted by the cruel way in which the government is executing its immigration policies. I am horrified by the most recent example of the Howard government threatening to deport approximately 50 East Timorese migrants who have been seeking asylum in Australia and who have lived here for 10 years. I have received letters from constituents living in my electorate of Lowe in the suburbs of Abbotsford, Concord, Croydon and Burwood, all expressing their anger about this terrible and unnecessary decision. I will read part of just one of these letters:

quote.para: Dear Mr Murphy, I am pleading for the fifty or so East Timorese who were given letters on the 26 April from the Department of Immigration.

Some came to Australia in 1995 as survivors of the Santa Cruz Massacre, Dili 1991. Since then, they have learnt English and actively looked for work. They have held stable jobs, been diligent workers, paid taxes and supported their relatives still in East Timor.
Others are young families that have supported their children ... bringing them up in a stable loving home, encouraging them at school.
Another family have four children who are now in High School. They are of great integrity and have worked under very difficult circumstances to gain honest jobs.
There are no ‘serious character grounds’ for the people that I have mentioned. I know these people personally as, since February 1994 I worked in their Culture Centre teaching English.

They have no prospects of employment in East Timor if they are returned there. Why have these fifty East Timorese been singled out when others, including family members, have been given permanent residency in Australia? I am desperately asking you to intervene in this situation and grant residency to some wonderful future Australians. Please act promptly as the 28 days expire on 23 May 2005.

speech.para: Mr Deputy Speaker, this letter speaks for itself. I believe that, after 10 years living in Australia, human decency demands they be allowed to stay here.

talk.start.para: —As we approach 26 May, it is appropriate to reflect on approaches to reconciliation in Australia and the way forward for our Indigenous people. The first Sorry Day in 1998 was held in the wake of the federal government’s ‘practical and realistic response’ to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission’s National Inquiry into the Separation of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Children from Their Families. The $63 million package of initiatives, provided over four years, was announced by the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, Senator Herron, on 16 December 1997.

speech.para: Since that time, ongoing improvements have been initiated by the Howard government in terms of practical reconciliation and assistance to Indigenous Australians. There are still areas, particularly on the welfare front, where improvements are required. The comments by Noel Pearson reported in the Australian this week—and, I guess more importantly, the reaction to them—highlight the range of views and feelings in the community about this important topic.

One area that has been particularly successful, however, and is often overlooked or understated is the proactive support of the Howard government in providing opportunity for Indigenous children in our education system. Principals who I have worked with in Wakefield have welcomed the very real support they have received through measures such as the in-class tuition programs, the Parent School Partnerships Initiative, tertiary tuition and tuition for students in years 10, 11 and 12, homework centres, supplementary recurrent assistance, English as a second language, Indigenous education projects, short-term special assistance, and away-from-base assistance.

In South Australia there are 10,600 Indigenous Australians under 18, many of whom directly benefit from measures that address the education and development of our young people. Of those, 1,300—or just 0.97 per cent of the population—live in the electorate of Wakefield. Despite these relatively small numbers, in South Australia alone over $3.8 million was spent on these programs in the financial year 2004-05. In addition, specific funding has been provided by the Howard government to local groups for specific projects that support young Indigenous people. I was very happy this year to advise the city of Playford, for example, that they had been given $90,000 to purchase a bus to enable preschool Indigenous children to access early learning opportunities. Likewise, I was pleased to advise the Elizabeth Downs Primary School and the Smithfield Plains primary and high schools of new funding to establish homework centres to improve outcomes for Indigenous students.

Does any of this provide real outcomes? The answer is a resounding yes, not only in terms of educational outcomes but in terms of the real healing of relationships and attitudes—certainly I see it in the community of Wakefield.
